TITLE: It all started with a single coin flip!
TEXT:
It all started with a single coin flip!

It gave birth to the concept of a Bernoulli trial, which formed the basis for the famous Binomial probability distribution.

From the Binomial distribution arrived the below discrete distributions to torture the students taking stats classes:

Multinomial
Hypergeometric
Negative Binomial
Geometric
and the final thorn in the side of the probability distributions, Poisson

I struggled until yesterday to make sense of the Poisson distribution and how I could relate it to the Binomial distribution.

If you are struggling with it like me, I just have the right resource to end this madness once and for all.

It requires reading the latest post on my blog (link in the comments), where I explained how we could relate Poisson distribution to the Binomial.


#statistics #dataanalytics #datascience

TITLE: ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt accept the null hypothesis. You could only fail to reject it!‚Äù
TEXT:
‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt accept the null hypothesis. You could only fail to reject it!‚Äù

The essence of hypothesis testing lies in this statement.

When you get a p-value that exceeds the level of significance, it means your sample hasn‚Äôt provided enough evidence for you to reject the null hypothesis.

But it doesn‚Äôt necessarily mean there is enough evidence to accept that null hypothesis.

I know! Our common sense tells us that failing to reject something means accepting it, but common sense doesn‚Äôt always work in the world of statistics. (Else, why would people roam with dice in their pockets!)

Sometimes when we fail to get significant results, it might be because our sample is imperfect.

Our sample might not be a truly random one, or our sample might be too small to meet the assumptions of the central limit theorem.

No wonder we get p-values exceeding the significance levels in such cases, preventing us from rejecting the null hypothesis.

Our next logical step would be seeing how this data was sampled or collecting more data to find enough evidence to embrace the null hypothesis.

#statistics #dataanalytics #datascience #statisticalanalysis

TITLE: It is easy to get lost in the world of correlations!
TEXT:
It is easy to get lost in the world of correlations!

But make no mistake, you have valuable information about your data by looking at the correlations between the variables.

And if you're planning to build a linear model using supervised machine learning, the presence of correlated variables will exacerbate the model's accuracy.

Hence, looking at the correlations between continuous variables is almost a non-negotiable task, and one of the ways to do it is by calculating the Pearson correlation coefficient for these variables.

Pearson coefficient is the default mode for many, including me, for testing correlations. 

But Pearson coefficient has found its kryptonite in the form of the non-linear relationship between the variables. 

Pearson coefficient makes sense only when there is a linear relationship between the variables and is not very useful when the variables have a non-linear relationship.

Hence it is high time we adopt other measures of correlation in addition to the Pearson coefficient to ensure we are not missing out on valuable correlations in the data.

#statistics #machinelearning #dataanalytics

TITLE: As a kid who grew up in a small town in India, my goals list looked like the below:
TEXT:
As a kid who grew up in a small town in India, my goals list looked like the below:

Own a computer.
Move to a city.
Work in a corporate job.
Fly abroad.

I was fortunate enough to check off all these things from my list, but moving to the United States as an international student has expanded my view of the world.

Sometimes, it is hard to believe that I am no longer at home, and sometimes, it is hard to feel at home here.

I realize this struggle is a rule rather than an exception after looking at those walking down the same path alongside me.

And to take my story further, I have a request that might sound too familiar to the people on LinkedIn.

I am looking for internship opportunities in the data science & analytics roles for the summer 2023 term. 

Before moving to the United States, I worked for four years in India as an SAP consultant.

Hence, I am no stranger to the world of endless meetings that could have been simple emails, volatile business requirements, and tasks with unrealistic deadlines.

Also, did I mention that I am from a civil engineering background? (I might or might not have said it a few million times in my previous posts.)

Moving into a tech career from a non-tech background asked a lot of me, but I always gave my 100%, which took me on a fascinating and sometimes weird journey over four years. Three great companies: Accenture, Infosys, and Deloitte, saw my potential and took a chance on me during this period.

I decided to move it up a notch by starting a self-learning journey in data science six months ago (because data is the new oil, right?).

Meanwhile, I learned a decent amount of Python, SQL, and basic machine learning stuff (I know that logistic regression is for classification problems and that I should always separate test data from training data.)

But let me be honest and admit that this learning journey was scary and boring at times.

To keep me consistent and entertained in this journey, I started creating memes and writing funny stuff about things I learned.

The stuff I post on LinkedIn might be funny and sometimes outright dumb, but people who worked alongside me in any capacity would attest that I am a serious professional.

After reflecting on my dreams while growing up and where I am currently, I sometimes wonder if I have peaked already in my life and career.

But something in me tells me it is not the case. I set out on a new journey to find it out, and I would be more than grateful if you could help me by providing any referrals or leads for the internship opportunities.

Thank you!

#datascience #dataanalytics #summerinternship #internship #machinelearning

TITLE: One day in 2020, I was feeling off and depressed.
TEXT:
One day in 2020, I was feeling off and depressed.

The weather on that day was gloomy as clouds covered the sun.

I decided to switch on some music to beat the blues, and the British band Coldplay has always been my go-to choice during difficult times.

The below lyric from one of the Coldplay songs I listened to that day caught my attention and stayed in my mind.

"I have no doubt. One day the sun will come out!"

And this week, I flew to the United States for the first time in my life and caught a glimpse of the Oklahoma sun which made me think about this lyric again.

It is almost as if the sun never goes away here (the sun sets at nine freaking PM!)

Though the sun shines brighter and longer each day, I couldn't stop reflecting on how much the group of international students I have been part of had to go through to enter this phase.

We had to deal with emotional goodbyes, hectic flights, difficult immigration experiences, feelings of self-doubt, homesickness within a matter of few days.

The road that led us here has been tiring, but I believe this Oklahoma sun we saw signals the start of better days!

Pic Credit: Shubhi Gupta

#internationalstudents #unitedstates #highereducation

TITLE: I often felt lonely during the early stages of my data learning journey.
TEXT:
I often felt lonely during the early stages of my data learning journey.

All those who seemed to be on the same path alongside me were building awesome projects and landing amazing job offers while I was struggling to figure out how to use a CTE without breaking my query!

I do know that comparison is the thief of joy. But knowing it only made me feel bad about comparing myself to others and added to my existing feelings of insecurity.

While the entire world was relishing the bright sunny days on LinkedIn, it felt like I was in a different time zone covered in darkness.

What helped me during such dark times was talking to fellow beginners who started their learning journeys and hearing the stories of professionals who once went through the same emotions.

It is no secret that humans crave social interaction and approval. Without these two necessities, we sink into the quicksand of loneliness and depression.

And it is the exact reason why finding a community where you feel like you belong can help you stay afloat in the deep waters of the data world.

I recently became a part of a 450+ member discord group organized by Data In Motion, LLC Motion, thanks to Kedeisha Bryan.

To paraphrase the words of Sonali Kumar, Data in Motion helps you bring structure to your self-learning journeys by letting you focus on the vital tools and concepts needed to kickstart your data career.

As a part of this community, you could access many valuable resources like resume reviews, live study sessions, regular SQL, Python & data visualization challenges, and many more.

I am pasting its discord group's invite in the comments. I wish many self-learners like me utilize the power of this community to aid their efforts.

Remember that you don't have to feel lonely all by yourself in this data world. You have 450+ members of this community alongside you with whom you could feel lonely üòú

#datascience #dataanalytics

TITLE: I was the happiest man on the planet yesterday.
TEXT:
I was the happiest man on the planet yesterday.

I got a great deal on a domain from GoDaddy as its first-time user.

With the brightness of thousand blazing suns shining on my face, I went to my modest and free WordPress blog to try and figure out a way to connect it to that domain.

But my happiness was destined to be short-lived and transcend into disappointment. 

WordPress asked me to purchase a premium plan to integrate the domain, which costs 5X the amount I paid to GoDaddy.

I posted more than 100 times on that blog until now. I could rant heartfully on it without the fear of upsetting people because it had hardly ten followers. It was the only place I could go to find comfort in the online world. 

But I decided to walk away from that blog to appease the gods of custom domains.

I tried to build a new website from scratch and host it on platforms like GitHub pages or Netlify. But my web development skills were only matched by my swimming skills, and you could figure out the extent of these skills when I say I stepped into a swimming pool only twice in my lifetime.

So, I naturally screwed up and wasted my entire day on it!

I was about to give up entirely this morning until I learned about Blogger, Google's blogging platform.

Sun rose again in my kingdom. I went ahead and set up a new blog on it, made a few test posts, and linked it with my custom domain successfully.

Or at least, that's what I thought! 

It just dawned upon me that I couldn't view that blog on my computer. 

I was able to open it on my mobile phone and other PCs, but there is still trouble when I try to open that domain on my computer.

I tried to ping the domain in the command prompt, did a DNS flushing, and pulled out all sorts of rabbits from the hat, thanks to the detailed how-to guides online.

But there is still no luck.

While I lose my head trying to figure out what's wrong with my computer, you could try giving the four data science articles I copied from LinkedIn a read on my new blog!

Check out the link in the comments.

#blogging #wordpress #webdevelopment

TITLE: I know you could recite the formula for sample standard deviation even in your sleep.
TEXT:
I know you could recite the formula for sample standard deviation even in your sleep.

That (n-1) in the denominator inside the square root must be no stranger to you.

There's a good chance you already know that a sample has n-1 degrees of freedom, which is why we use it in the denominator instead of a straightforward "n."

It is a no-brainer that using the .std() function to calculate the standard deviation for a NumPy array is a piece of cake for you.

But if you haven't heard about the "ddof" parameter in this function yet, let me caution you against using the .std() directly to calculate sample standard deviations.

This parameter accounts for the degree of freedom while calculating standard deviation, and its default value is zero.

If you aren't setting it to "1", you are calculating population standard deviation instead of the sample statistic.

Hence, always cross-check that you are setting the appropriate value to the ddof parameter while using the .std function.

#python #datascience #dataanalytics #statistics #dataanalysis

TITLE: "You‚Äôll find it comes in waves. When the ship gets wrecked, you‚Äôre drowning, with wreckage all around you.
TEXT:
"You‚Äôll find it comes in waves. When the ship gets wrecked, you‚Äôre drowning, with wreckage all around you. 

For a while, all you can do is float. Stay alive. 

In the beginning, the waves are 100 feet tall and crash over you without mercy. 

They come 10 seconds apart without giving you the time to catch your breath. 

After a while, maybe weeks, maybe months, you‚Äôll find the waves are still 100 feet tall, but they come further apart.

And when they come, they still crash all over you and wipe you out. 

But in between, you can breathe, you can function. 

The waves never stop coming, and you don‚Äôt want them to. 

But you learn that you‚Äôll survive them. 

And other waves will come. And you are going to survive them too."

- This is a Reddit user's description of grief as mentioned in the 'Despair' chapter of the book Big Feelings: How to be okay when things are not okay. (Pages 160-161). 

If you have been struggling recently, please seek the support you deserve from your friends, family, and mental health professionals.

If someone you know is at their lowest point, please reach out to them. (A kind reminder to be non-judgemental and not utter the phrase think positive to offer unconditional support.)

Remember that life is a complicated juggling act.

You don't need to put in 20 reps at the gym every time or have a bank balance with numerous zeroes to feel worthy.

Sometimes, just surviving is enough to count as a win!

#mentalhealth #depression #wellbeing #bookaweekchallenge

P.S. Kudos to Liz Fosslien and Mollie West Duffy for the amazing illustrations and for being completely honest about their struggles in their new book, Big Feelings. I can't recommend their book highly enough if you are going through rough times.

TITLE: If you took a student loan in USD, there's a good chance you noticed a spike in the monthly interest accrued since March.
TEXT:
If you took a student loan in USD, there's a good chance you noticed a spike in the monthly interest accrued since March.

It is because of that variable portion of the interest rate fluctuating like crazy in recent times.

The fixed portion of the interest rate depends on the things in your control, like the ranking of the university you chose, your financial situation, your credit history, the total duration you take to repay the loan, etc.

But the variable portion is not in your hands as it depends on the benchmark rates published by considering the indicators of inflation rates and market situations.

Since July 2021, most lenders have started using a forward-looking interest rate called "CME Term SOFR" as the benchmark rate to calculate the variable portion.

This rate comes with an additional parameter of tenure, based on which the rate value differs.

These tenures could be one among the following: one month, three months, six months, and twelve months.

Let us say a lender opted to use CME's three-month SOFR rate as the variable interest portion. 

That lender divides the financial year into four blocks of three months each. 

The variable interest rate for each of these blocks is the three-month term SOFR rate published by the CME group (an agency publishing these interest rates) for a date one or two business days before the start of that current block.

The best part is that this variable rate remains constant during this three-month tenure. 

But on the flip side, the nature of this tenure SOFR is forward-looking and proactive, which is a bad sign under certain circumstances.

Every time the inflation rate is soaring, the fed increases interest rates to make it difficult for people to borrow money. The rationale behind this move is that it reduces the demand for goods and services and decreases their prices.

CME Term SOFR doesn't need to wait until the fed hike the interest rates. Even a slight hint of inflation is enough for it to go up.

During COVID time, the fed decreased the interest rates to reduce the burden on the people and subsequently boost the economy. 

It meant between March 2020 to October 2021, CME Term SOFR rates were less than 0.1.

From January 2022, there has been a steady increase in this rate. Within eight months, it shot up to around 2.5 %.

If the student loan you took between late 2021 and early 2022 adopts this term CFR for variable rate calculation, you will find at least a 2% increase in your overall interest rate today.

If it hits you like a punch to your gut, there is more bad news for you because several experts predict that this variable rate might shoot up to 4% by the end of this year!

#inflation #highereducation #loans #sofr

TITLE: How to be okay when things are not okay?
TEXT:
How to be okay when things are not okay?

How to get on with my day despite that sinking feeling in my heart?

How to set my inner self when my entire outer world seems to be falling apart?

I started reading Liz Fosslien and Mollie West Duffy's new book, Big Feelings: How to be okay when things are not okay, to find answers to all the above questions.

Like several other readers of this book, I am in awe of the beautiful and simple illustrations of emotions presented throughout the various chapters. (You will recognize those pictures as the ones you already saw on social media and loved for their humourous and insightful tone.)

I found this book to be not just another addition to the vast array of positive psychology literature. 

It is an honest attempt to segregate various emotions by shining light on the subtle distinctions, which could help the reader to identify and deal with them constructively.

Here are a few of my favorite bits from the initial 50% of this book I completed reading so far:

"When harnessed effectively, anger can give us the strength we need to make things right." - Big Feelings (p. 84). 

We are more likely to associate anger with a negative feeling we need to suppress to avoid punching someone in the face, but this book puts a new perspective forward by talking about how we could tap into the energy in the anger to gain the courage needed to stand up for ourselves.

Red Bull might not give you wings, but I am convinced that learning to channel the emotion in anger gives you a cape and makes you a superhuman with powers. (I lifted the image of this post from this book as it brilliantly illustrates my point.)

‚ÄúSometimes life taps you on the shoulder with a feather, sometimes hits you with a brick, and sometimes runs you over with a bus. Learn to listen when it‚Äôs just a feather.‚Äù - Big Feelings (p. 91).

Naveed Ahmad (Co-founder & CEO of Flourish) quoted it while talking about the signs of burnout in this book.

Burnout has become a ubiquitous emotion these days. For some reason, many work cultures tend to equate burnout to feelings of dedication towards the work.

Life has a few simple ways to alarm us that we are burned out (like constant tiredness or insomnia), but if we continue to ignore them, it would not be long before a bolt of lightning strikes at once with no warning signs of thunder!

I am trying to complete reading the next 50 percent of this book by the end of the week. 

Meanwhile, I highly recommend that you get your hands on it if you are looking for a book to help you understand and deal with your emotions.

#bookaweekchallenge #burnout #emotions #wellbeing

P.S. Below image is an illustration found on page 61 of the book "Big Feelings: How to be okay when things are not okay" written by the authors Liz Fosslien and Mollie West Duffy and published by Canongate Books Ltd.
PROFILE_MENTION: Liz Fosslien, Mollie West Duffy, Naveed Ahmad

TITLE: "Small habits don‚Äôt add up. They compound."
TEXT:
"Small habits don‚Äôt add up. They compound."

And it is a wrap to my reading of a book that stayed true to its title until the very end, a book that only asked its reader to use the power of tiny improvements to build consistent habits.

You probably read the summary of Atomic Habits and its four rules a billion times on the internet. So I would not go into that.

But one of my favorite parts, which is often overlooked, and lies in the shadows of the brilliant four rules, is in the penultimate chapters.

If you are familiar with a new worldwide changing view that passion is overrated, and if you agree with it, this will appeal to you üëáüèª

"The only way to become excellent is to be endlessly fascinated by doing the same thing over and over. You have to fall in love with boredom."

- Atomic Habits, Chapter 19.

Passion is a marketing gimmick to promote the flourishing of an era filled with devices that offer novelty consistently.

Boredom is one of the innate truths of life, and any path to self-mastery should ideally begin with learning its importance.

It is crazy how learning to embrace boredom can impact various aspects of your life ranging from your career to relationships.

I felt Atomic Habits became complete by touching upon this topic, and it would be within my top ten must-read book recommendations for anyone willing to form a reading habit.

#bookaweekchallenge #atomichabits #boredom #wellbeing

TITLE: Do you eat, work, and take short naps all on the same couch?
TEXT:
Do you eat, work, and take short naps all on the same couch?

I don't know about you, but I certainly do, and here's why it might be unproductive üëáüèª

Thanks to Pavlov's dog experiment, we know that our brain associates a cue with a specific action if both repeatedly occur in tandem.

If you are sitting at the same place and doing the same actions every day,¬†each of these actions competes to become associated with the cue of entering that place.

When we group actions that require varying efforts with a specific cue (like location in this case), the easy ones take away the prize of being wired with that cue in our brains.

Actions like sleeping or eating require less effort in general compared to the tasks of focusing on work or reading. 

Hence, it is a no-brainer that your brain would let you nap or grab a bite over working on a portfolio project that would increase your job prospects while sitting on the couch.

Author James Clear suggests in his book 'Atomic habits' a simple action one could always follow to avoid being stuck in such a situation.

You could divide your space into various parts and assign individual tasks to each of them. (For example, nap only on the bed, eat only on the dining table, work only at your desk, etc.)

Over the next few days, try to religiously follow your plan of action by restricting each location only to the use of the tasks you initially assigned.

It takes time for the brain to become wired as per your design, but once it happens, you will find your efficiency improved in all those actions.

And you would finally stop checking the work emails while eating lunch (it is the dream, isn't it?)

I have heard about the benefits of doing one action at a time a million times in my life until now, but Atomic Habits is probably the first source that adds a spatial dimension to it and talks about doing one action at a location!

What other measures did you implement successfully to improve your efficiency while working or studying?

#productivity #work #atomichabits #bookaweekchallenge

TITLE: If there is only one actionable piece of advice you need to follow to improve your consistency in sticking to your habits, won't you want to know it?
TEXT:
If there is only one actionable piece of advice you need to follow to improve your consistency in sticking to your habits, won't you want to know it?

Yes, you would!
¬†
Author James Clear has provided not one but two such gems in the book Atomic Habits, which I will describe below üëáüèª

The implementation intention:

Instead of saying, "I will exercise more from tomorrow," say, "I will lift weights at 7:00 AM tomorrow in my local gym."

This strategy involves setting the time and place of implementation to support your intention.

But if you are someone like me who is quite forgetful at times, you could follow the next strategy.

Habit stacking:

"I will lift weights after drinking my morning coffee tomorrow."

It involves stacking a new habit onto an already formed one. 

The intentions we set without following these strategies are usually too vague.

The energy we would need to act upon such vague intentions is more than the energy we would require to convince ourselves to procrastinate. 

As fundamental human behavior goes, we always prefer to do actions that conserve our energy.

Hence, the simple act of eradicating vagueness improves our odds of sticking to our intentions and routines.

And it leads to the formation of concrete habits in the long run!

#atomichabits #bookaweekchallenge #habitbuilding

TITLE: I don't feel the Monday blues!
TEXT:
I don't feel the Monday blues!

Am I a superman? ü¶∏‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

TITLE: "Conscious mind is the bottleneck of the brain."
TEXT:
"Conscious mind is the bottleneck of the brain."

Author James Clear puts these words nicely in Atomic Habits to explain how our attentional capacities are limited.

While he used it primarily to make a point regarding how habit formation can ease the load on our conscious mind, it made me think about the importance of paying selective attention.

We live in a world where devices can pay better attention than humans. 

Think about Alexa, Siri, and all those creepy product advertisements that seem to pop out of nowhere after you've talked about them.

If this trend continues, it won't be long before Alexa starts setting your to-do list and shouts out commands to you.

We need to do something about it, and I believe taking a step towards gaining control over our online lives is a good start.

To achieve it, we should master the skill of paying selective attention.

It helps you swim in the ocean of clickbait without drowning.

By the way, what are some of your favorite strategies for filtering the information you consume online?

#attention #atomichabits #bookaweekchallenge #wellbeing

TITLE: "You do not rise to the level of your goals. You fall to the level of your systems."
TEXT:
"You do not rise to the level of your goals. You fall to the level of your systems."

The fans of James Clear's famous book, Atomic habits, would instantly recognize this quote.

And I admit that this single quote was enough for me to jump on the bandwagon.

I started reading Atomic habits, a book that has been on my wish list for longer than the time Rose waited for Jack in Titanic. (I did not mean it literally.)

For someone that reads a large number of self-improvement books, I expected to find a lot of cliched wisdom scattered across the pages of this book.

But I am pleasantly surprised to find pearls of wisdom organized succinctly throughout the initial two chapters.

Here are a few of my favorite bits:

The graph in the image talks about the non-linear relationship between the results and the sustained efforts over time.

Many of us naively expect proportionate results when we put in the effort each time, but more often, the results we see in the initial phases are underwhelmingly low. 

It pushes us to fall into a valley of disappointment (I love how the author describes it geometrically as the distance between linear and non-linear curves) which becomes the precursor to halting the efforts.

Learning how to navigate through this valley of disappointment without giving up is the first step one could take toward building consistent habits in life.

#atomichabits #bookaweekchallenge¬†#selfimprovement

TITLE: Did you make many great connections on LinkedIn today? ü§î
TEXT:
Did you make many great connections on LinkedIn today? ü§î

Here's the next ideal step you might want to take üëáüèª

Greet your new connections via direct messaging and thank them for connecting with you. ü§ùüèª

But if you are on a tight schedule üèÉüèª‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è, it might not always be feasible to greet each person individually. 

Moreover, there will be days when your posts perform incredibly well, resulting in an unusually high number of new connections on LinkedIn in a single day. ü§∑üèª‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è

The most logical step you take on such days is to skip the part of sending introductory messages altogether.

But you are losing a chance of making a great first impression with your new connections ü§¶üèª‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è, who might one day help you find a new job or set up your own business.

What if I tell you that there's a way for you around this problem? üí° 

It involves as little effort as copy-pasting two strings in a Jupyter notebook and running all its cells with a single click. üéØ

(If you are unfamiliar with Jupyter notebooks, it is an easy-to-use and interactive web platform for running Python code.)

naas.ai provides a notebook template that you could use for automating the task of sending introductory messages to all new connections of any current day üìÖ

The best part is you'll need to know little to no coding for using that template. ‚úÖ

You could try it out for free by following the below steps üëáüèª

1. Go to the link of the notebook I pasted in the comment.

2. Click on the green "Open in Naas" text. It will direct you to a login page.

3. Set up your credentials and log in to Naas. (It is free - you have 100 free credits you could use every month.)

4. Start the server, and you will find the notebook open in the Naas environment.

5. Go to the "Get your cookies" section and click on the 'How to get your cookies?' hyperlink. It will route you to a document that describes the process of getting your LinkedIn cookies in detail.

6. Replace the variables in that section with actual cookies data, go to the 'Run' menu at the top, and select 'Run all.' 

I might have made it sound more complicated üòÖ, but it is simple once you start doing it. Give it a try, and reach out to me if you need help at any stage! ü§ó

P.S. A big shout-out to Florent Ravenel for refining the code of this notebook. üëèüèªü§ùüèª

TITLE: I was naive and clueless when I started my learning journey to enter the data world.
TEXT:
I was naive and clueless when I started my learning journey to enter the data world.

And fast forward to today ‚ö°‚è©

I am still naive, but I found a few clues that set me on a data career scavenger hunt.

Most of these clues were generated by:

1. Interacting with the content of established data professionals on   this platform.
2. Posting content regularly
3. Making blunders in my posts and getting schooled by experts here.

But there's always a regret in me that I could have made a bit more progress had I known what I was getting into during the initial phases of my journey.

Michael Dillon's book, 'How to find a job in Data Analytics?' could have helped me with that. It is filled with clues to help a complete beginner make sense of the data world.

I picked its ebook this week to read and completed a significant portion of it until now.

It's not a hand-holding guide until you find a job in data analytics.

But it helps you plan your baby steps in the data world or, for that matter, decide if a data career is for you.

You won't find it every day where 46 data professionals are sitting at a single table to discuss their career journeys, but Michael managed to capture its essence in his ebook of 137 pages.

So, give it a try by purchasing your copy today (the link is in the comments).

TITLE: Analysing 100+ most successful decks is a sure-shot way of not getting anywhere with your own pitch deck.
TEXT:
Analysing 100+ most successful decks is a sure-shot way of not getting anywhere with your own pitch deck.

A lot of clients come to me after.

‚≠ï 30+ frustrating attempts of building pitch themselves.
‚≠ï Trying various automation platforms.

And I see everyone doing the same mistake of starting by analysing 100+ most successful decks to replicate them.

What's wrong with that? 

‚ùå You want to include everything best of all the decks.

‚ùå It creates a never-ending loop of endless data & info collection.

‚ùå Pitch decks you find on the internet are mostly old enough to be shared publicly.

‚ùå The pitch narratives you enjoy the most are an outcome of an elaborate process you don‚Äôt know.

ü§Ø Everything compounds to frustrate & confuse you like hell.

üíé Every founder and company have faced circumstances and challenges which shape their business story and they cannot be replicated.

So, no shortcut here, you have to
 
‚úÖ Go through your own discovery process. 
‚úÖ You may seek help to guide you to save time. 

But your story will always remain yours and will be unique.

TITLE: Why VC's rushing to fund climate tech startups?
TEXT:
Why VC's rushing to fund climate tech startups?


üí° A little back story: 

-> Climate tech was once cleantech. 

-> VCs invested 25 billion in cleantech & lost half of it. 

Reasons:

‚≠ï Undefined markets & technology. 

‚≠ï Hard tech like solar panels & batteries require a lot of capital. 

‚≠ï  Needs consistent funding before becoming profitable. (Also called the valley of death)


Things only started to change after 


‚ôª Paris Agreement in 2015 when governments started allocating funds & Promoting climate tech" for their sustainability goals.
 

So, what is driving funds in climate tech now? 


‚úÖ Demand for low-carbon products among businesses, consumers, and governments.


‚úÖ 43 climate-tech startups are now unicorns, the winner being TESLA with a 1 trillion valuation. 


‚úÖ  We all still need the earth to live more than money & profits while climate change is becoming more and more evident and visible. 

----------------------------------------------------------------

We are actively working with climate tech startups to tell stories that ignite minds & increase impact 10x so that we can keep the momentum going.

TITLE: Before your startup cap table becomes a mess know the fundamentals.
TEXT:
Before your startup cap table becomes a mess know the fundamentals. 

When planing to raise capital for a startup it is important to invest some time to.


üîµ Understand the basic mechanics of different ways to capitalize on your companies equity &

üîµ How those impact founding team equity and cap tables overall.


Because once you agree to the terms and sign the documents there is no going back.


Here is a list of a few terms knowing which will come in handy during the fundraising process.


üî∑ For non-priced rounds -> When company valuation cannot be clearly calculated.

      üîπ POST MONEY SAFE
      üîπ PRE-MONEY SAFE
      üîπ CONVERTIBLE NOTES
      üîπ CONVERTIBLE DEBT (including maturity dates & interest rates)
      üîπ Discount
      üîπ Uncapped safe


üî∑ Dilution:
       üîπ ESOP


üî∑  New money (after seed rounds):
     üîπ  Price per share.
     üîπ  Capitalisation.
     üîπ  Number of shares left with you.


A lot of these terms & solutions were coined by YC to help founders raise capital early, easily & quickly. 

YC library is a great place to start your discovery with. 

Startup Jedi -  A cool place to read about startups & VC trends.   

The article on SAFE by Anna Mastykina is also a great read. 


Let me know if I missed something or any other great resources.


Image credits: Startup Jedi.

TITLE: "What's your startup's valuation?" 3 Things to know before responding to this question.
TEXT:
"What's your startup's valuation?" 3 Things to know before responding to this question.


As a founder, one question that you'll inevitably face when seeking funding is: "What's your startup's valuation?"


This can be a tough question to answer, especially if you're an early-stage company that hasn't raised funding before.


Here are a few tips for how to respond when a VC asks about your startup's valuation:


Start from a place of understanding that it's their full-time job, they will be way better at it than you so 


----------------
1. Don't just throw out a valuation number. 
-------

A smarter way to respond to this question: 

We are letting the market price this round we‚Äôll end up putting together a deal that makes sense with the right investor. 

However, some of the others we‚Äôve spoken with have said they might approach valuation somewhere in the range of 

(quote the approaches you‚Äôve gathered) 

on our next round, with some of the drivers being 

(quote the valuation rationales you‚Äôve gathered) 



-----------------
2. Share your valuation process and be realistic about your valuation.
--------

Don't be afraid to negotiate and find a number that works for both you and the VC.



-----------------
3. Don't get caught up in the valuation number.
--------
Focus on building a strong relationship and making a compelling case for your startup.


----------------- ----------------- --------------- ------------- --
Seek advice from trusted advisors if you're unsure how to approach the conversation.


Overall, the key is to be prepared, transparent, and open to negotiation when a VC asks about your startup's valuation.

#fidle #fidleit #pitchdeck #presentation #funding #valuation

TITLE: How does your pitch look and feel aka perception -Comes last,

Thus everything you choose to do or not do tells something about YOU.

‚úÖ Simple words ‚Üí A founder knows how to communicate.


‚úÖ Got fundamentals right ‚Üí A founder who knows their stuff.


‚úÖ DD documents ready ‚Üí A true professional, easy to work with.


‚úÖ Branding, layout & design ‚Üí Founder values my convenience, and time | understands branding | is obsessed with this idea.


Conscious brains like fundamental 

While  

Unconscious brains set the gut feeling. 


It's good to have them both play on your side when raising capital for your business.

TITLE: Before you read about pitch decks online, make sure it‚Äôs meant for you.
TEXT:
Before you read about pitch decks online, make sure it‚Äôs meant for you.

I don‚Äôt understand why people write articles, on pitch decks but don‚Äôt mention which funding round they are talking about.

I mean before writing advice on a good deck isn‚Äôt it fundamental to mention for which round it is meant to be?

I don‚Äôt believe in one fit for all templates, but many people base their decks on those.

This is misleading and wastes a lot of founders‚Äô time as even the very basic template structure changes 

According too.

üí∞ Funding stage &

üìà The industry you are working in

KPIs & metrics that work for a Series-A business won‚Äôt serve any good for a pre-seed business.


Below is a very brief description of pitch deck purposes at different stages.


‚úÖ Pre-seed: Great team, market dynamics/competitors, insight/differentiation, and an execution plan.

‚úÖ Seed: Same as above, plus a minimum viable product (MVP) and some early customers and signals toward product-market fit (PMF).

‚úÖ Series A: You‚Äôre 75% toward PMF with early pilots/paying customers ‚Äî not fully worked unit economics but can prove demand.

‚úÖ Series B:¬†You have 100% PMF with stable unit economics, and are looking to raise to scale sales operations, plus the next product in your pipeline.



Next time you refer to any information or advice on the internet make sure to see if it is relevant to your stage company, Industry & location.

TITLE: Founder equity is a major deciding factor for overall company success.
TEXT:
Founder equity is a major deciding factor for overall company success.


Less dilution = more chances to create the impact.
Less dilution = more chances to do what was actually intended.
Less dilution = more decisions with customers in mind than revenue.


Businesses which are most affected by equity dilution are in the climate-tech space.


lines between profitability & climate (being a priority) get blurred really easily.


While,  Founders act as the soul of the company, the guiding force.


Without decision-making power, everything gets unnecessarily messed up and overly complicated.


Protecting founder equity starts with the right positioning of the company from the start of the fundraising process.

TITLE: The significant upside of bootstrapping before fundraising
TEXT:

A bootstrap business generates way more leverage for the founder than people tell.


Better traction = Better valuation.
Better traction = Better negotiation position.
Better traction = Less dependence on outside capital.



It's hard initially but kinda turn‚Äôs the tables around during fundraising.

TITLE: It is more than ok to not quit your day job before raising a SEED round.
TEXT:

A day job buys you TIME to


‚úÖ Build & iterate.
‚úÖ Find early adopters.

TITLE: Getting traction slide right is easier than you think (Even without a hockey stick graph) üìà
TEXT:
Getting traction slide right is easier than you think (Even without a hockey stick graph) üìà


A lot of founders struggle with their traction slide especially if the graph doesn‚Äôt look like the ideal hockey stick graph.


But that should never be the case there are many ways to build a strong case for your business potential,


You need to be able to identify your growth metrics and put them forward together.


Here are a few ways you can nail your traction slide,

‚úÖ Product progress +
‚úÖ Customer acquisition +
‚úÖ Churn rate (if < 3%). +
‚úÖ Visible growth +
‚úÖ Predictability (Monthly Recurring Revenue) is also worth highlighting.


An investor will read this as "Even if the numbers are small the growth rate is something we can build upon".


That's the kind of incentive you would want to create in your traction slide.


#startup¬†#enterpreneur¬†#fundraising¬†#pitchdeck¬†¬†#presentation¬†#venturecapital¬†#fidleit¬†#traction

TITLE: Learning to say "no" is critical.
TEXT:
Learning to say "no" is critical.

But most of us struggle with it...

As Warren Buffett famously said:

"The difference between successful people and really successful people is that really successful people say no to almost everything."

How do we start?

First, we have to understand our non-negotiables.

For example, at¬†VITALIZE¬†we invest in B2B software in the Future of Work, and we say "no" to all the startups that aren't a fit. 

Your personal non-negotiables could include:
- The hours you work
- Set time with family
- Time for self-care
- The type of work you do

Next, we have to internalize that saying "no" frees us up to say "yes."

Of course, every "no" has an opportunity cost.

As an investor, this is ever-present, as we don't want to miss out on "the next big thing."

However, there's always another opportunity.

There are many ways of saying "no":

The x but y "no"

When you want to help, but you can't fully support the request:
"I can review the proposal once you have a draft."

You're not committing to the request itself, but instead, you're saying "no" by setting the terms of what you WILL do.

The deferred "no"

When you're interested in the request at some point, but don't have the time now:
"I can't right now because of X, but if you follow up in a few months and I'm able to, let's chat then."

The relational "no"

When you're leveraging other relationships to say "no":
‚ÄúStudents are my top priority professionally, and since I teach more than 300 students per year, I don‚Äôt have the bandwidth to take on additional mentoring."

I got this one from the always-insightful¬†Adam Grant. 

The "no" after "yes"

When you overcommit:
"Last year, when I said I could join your panel, I thought I'd have the availability. However, after taking a closer look at my calendar, I'm realizing I overextended myself and will not be able to make it."

The deflection "no"

When you think someone else will be better for the request:
"Thanks for thinking of me, but I'm not the best person for this. However, X is great at Y and might be helpful. I'm happy to make an email introduction if you're both okay with it."

The alternative "no"

When you still want to help, but don't have time:
"I'm flattered you want to talk to me about X, but I'm overextended at the moment. However, I wrote a few articles about X here and think they'd be helpful."

The on-deadline "no"

When you have a big project you need to focus on:
"I appreciate you reaching out, the opportunity sounds great, but I'm on deadline for my [book/course/fundraise] and have to pass. Thanks for thinking of me."

--- 

For more ways to say "no" view the latest Just Go Grind newsletter and subscribe below üëá

30+

TITLE: Having worked with 100+ founders, I have noticed one common trait among infamously successful ones.
TEXT:
Having worked with 100+ founders, I have noticed one common trait among infamously successful ones.

When it comes to creating effective and impactful solutions, the key is to always keep the people in mind.

Whether you're an entrepreneur, CEO, or startup founder, it's essential that you always think about how your decisions will affect those around you.

Of course, this isn't always easy.

There are a lot of factors to consider and it can be tough to please everyone.

However, if you take the time to really think about what's best for the people, you'll be able to create solutions that are truly impactful.

So next time you're facing a tough decision, remember to put the people first.

It might not be easy, but it's worth it when you see the positive difference you can make in their lives.

TITLE: Fundraising reality I learned after working on several startup fundraising & pitch deck projects in the last 3 years.
TEXT:
Fundraising reality I learned after working on several startup fundraising & pitch deck projects in the last 3 years.


Funding does not determine startup success, but whom you raise from does.


Many people believe that securing funding from investors is the key to a successful startup.


Although funding is important, it's not the end-all and be-all of a successful startup.


Raising money from the right people is the key to success.


According to a recent survey by dealroom (on European startups), this is the case.


Companies that raise from top-quartile Seed investors are significantly more likely to convert to Series A and do so more quickly.


Don't just focus on raising money if you want to start a successful startup.


Your vision can become a reality if you find the right investors.

TITLE: Be clear about your monetisation potential and show your math!
TEXT:

Can you answer 3 questions in your financial slide without actually saying them?


1.) Where will you be in 5 years?

2.) When will your company achieve breakeven?

3.) When will you need the next round of funding?


If you can't answer these questions, then your financial slide is probably missing something important.

Make sure you include all the key information to paint a clear and logical picture of your business.

TITLE: An angel investor puts $10,000 into a friend‚Äôs business. It‚Äôs pre-product and pre-revenue, so he gets 1% of the company, pricing the round at $1m post-money.
TEXT:
An angel investor puts $10,000 into a friend‚Äôs business. It‚Äôs pre-product and pre-revenue, so he gets 1% of the company, pricing the round at $1m post-money.

The company grows like crazy and eventually sells for $10bn. The angel investor makes $100m right? 10,000x his investment?

Nope, he makes $0.

Possible? Yes. 

‚Äî-

The math is way oversimplified here, and I‚Äôm looking forward to being put in my place by the analysts, but this can and does happen‚Ä¶

Although it‚Äôs exciting when the startups you‚Äôve backed raise subsequent rounds at colossal valuations, it‚Äôs not unusual for angel investors to get burned. 

As institutional investors join later rounds, they generally expect preference shares, giving them special treatment if things take a turn for the worse. Angel investors, meanwhile, are stuck with ordinary shares. 

As the company raises more rounds, the preference terms get more punitive: 2x liquidity preference, 3x liquidity preference, anti-dilution clauses‚Ä¶ it can get complex. 

If everything goes to plan and the startup‚Äôs valuation rises steadily, all is well. If, however, the startup raises at a lower valuation than it did previously (a down round) the anti-dilution clauses kick in. Those with ordinary shares dilute at an accelerated rate, while those with anti-dilution clauses are protected. 

It‚Äôs even worse if the startup‚Äôs valuation crashes between a large round and a liquidity event like a sale or an IPO. 

Let‚Äôs say the startup raised $3bn at a $20bn valuation. Not impossible. But to get the deal done the founder had to give a 3x liquidity preference.

Later, things get tough. The company can‚Äôt raise its next round, so eventually the founder accepts a $10bn acquisition offer. Still a good result in most people‚Äôs eyes.

Actually it‚Äôs not. 

The $3bn investor walks away with $9bn (3x what they invested), leaving $1bn for the other shareholders. Those with 1x preference shares get their invested capital back. To get the deal done, the acquirer looks after the founder and a few of the key people.

The angels? It could be zero. 

‚Äî-

I know investors and employees whose shares ended up being worthless in situations similar to the above.

If you‚Äôre an angel and have the option to sell shares in a secondary market, even if you have to take a haircut on valuation, give it some serious thought. 

#angelinvesting #preferenceshares #downround

TITLE: "Grind they say. But for entrepreneurs, the grind is never a problem. Rather, the problem is what to work hard on."
TEXT:
"Grind they say. But for entrepreneurs, the grind is never a problem. Rather, the problem is what to work hard on."

As an entrepreneur, you're used to working hard. 

You've given up a lot to get where you are today, and you're not afraid of putting in the extra effort to achieve your goals. 

But sometimes, it can be difficult to know what's worth grinding for. 

Is it that new client? Is it that big project? Is it simply getting through the day?

The answer is different for everyone, but one thing is certain: the grind is never a problem for entrepreneurs. 

So if you're feeling stuck in a rut, remember that not everything is worth grinding for. And once you find it, DELEGATE.


#pitchdeck #presentation #startup #enterpreneur #fidleit #business #fundraising #startupfunding #investor #venturecapital

TITLE: What are Benelux unicorns made of? ü¶Ñ Our Antler team in Amsterdam has just published the latest Unicorn Mapping report, focusing on the Benelux region.
TEXT:
What are Benelux unicorns made of? ü¶Ñ Our Antler team in Amsterdam has just published the latest Unicorn Mapping report, focusing on the Benelux region.

We took a systematic look at the most exceptional founders since 1990 in the Benelux region and identified patterns that led up to these success stories.

Here are the 3 insights that triggered me the most:
üí° The average time from 0 to unicorn has dropped from 20 to 11 years - and there are multiple cases of startups achieving this in <5 years
üí° Only 1 Benelux investor invested in >1 Benelux unicorn before it was a unicorn. Congrats Newion and to all the other local investors, time to step up (y)our game!
üí° Only 3 out of 71 Benelux unicorn founders are women. This is a MASSIVE wasted opportunity for our economy, society and investors.

TITLE: Before you invent something new, it's always a good idea to explore the world for existing practices that could be mainstreamed.
TEXT:
Before you invent something new, it's always a good idea to explore the world for existing practices that could be mainstreamed.


This is especially true in the sustainability space, where there are often already-existing solutions to the problems you're trying to solve.


Looking at existing practices in a different corner of the world can help you save time and money, and it can also help you avoid reinventing the wheel.


So next time you're facing a sustainability challenge, take a look around and see what others are doing before you start from scratch.


#sustainability #pitchdeck  #presentation #funding #startup #enterpreneur

TITLE: Stop trying to be sustainable.
TEXT:
Stop trying to be sustainable.

Start becoming regenerative.

Being sustainable is no longer enough.

Sustainability was the answer maybe 20 or even 10 years ago.

But not today.

We‚Äôve reached a point where focusing only on not damaging the environment won‚Äôt save us.

We need to start giving back and restoring nature and its biodiversity.

The sustainable way:

- Use sustainable materials
- Minimize waste
- Reduce emissions
- Phase out fossil fuels

The regenerative way - all of the above plus:

- Restore biodiversity
- Plant trees
- Help endangered species to prolifer again
- Train people with green skills
- Embed regeneration in every organisation and institution
- Implement a circular economy
- Create regenerative companies and jobs
- Help local communities become more resilient


Regenerative > sustainable.

What else can we do to foster regeneration?


PS: Image by SPHERA Sustainability Consulting

#regenerative #sustainability  #biodiversity

TITLE: There's never been a better time to be a climate tech founder.
TEXT:
There's never been a better time to be a climate tech founder.

With the world increasingly focused on the climate crisis, there's more interest and investment in climate tech solutions than ever before.

If you're working on a solution to help mitigate or adapt to climate change, now is the time to get started.

There's more awareness of the problem than ever before, and that means there's also more interest in solutions.

-Investors are looking for promising startups to invest in.

-Customers are looking for products and services that can help them reduce their impact on the environment.

So if you're working on a climate tech solution, don't wait any longer to get started.

Now is the time to take advantage of the growing interest and investment in this space.

TITLE: The future of healthcare is entrepreneurship.
TEXT:
The future of healthcare is entrepreneurship.


Our health care system is already broken: Will it be sustainable for 8 billion people?


Innovative solutions are key to improving healthcare access and quality while reducing costs.


But these solutions don't just come from big pharma or medical device companies.


They come from entrepreneurs who see a problem and have the vision and drive to solve it.


But being an entrepreneur is not easy.


It takes a lot of hard work, dedication, and resilience.


That's why we need more people supporting entrepreneurs ‚Äì whether it's through mentorship, funding, or simply spreading the word about their work.


So let's continue to encourage entrepreneurship in healthcare and support those who are working tirelessly to make a difference.


Below I share a list of 50 investors supporting #healthtech  companies.









#enterpreneur #pitchdeck #presentation #startup #fundraising #investors

TITLE: Some financial realities of my early-stage founder journey
TEXT:
Some financial realities of my early-stage founder journey
(yes, that‚Äôs a graph of my actual bank balance)

- Work in corporate for years, save enough for a house deposit

- Watch as my pay + bonuses increase each year, making it harder to walk away. I was 27, in the top 25% of earners, and accelerating.

- Quit my job without even having a business idea. The only way I could make the jump: rip myself away from comfort.

- Immediately go from saving, to spending THOUSANDS each month just to exist. Ultimate accountability. Financial free fall.

- Spend almost my entire life savings over the next 3 years just existing (food, rent, basics)

- Fight tooth and nail to get to first revenue, then first funding round.

- Get paid ¬£0 for almost 2 years

- Then minimum wage for 1.5 more

- By year 4 of the startup, reached  the same salary I was on when I got my first grad job

- That lasted a few months‚Ä¶ Then Covid hit, and my pay got slashed again

/

Some other mundane truths‚Ä¶ I:

- Bought no new clothes for 5 years

- Did powerpoint-jockey work on the side for the first year

- Got wet feet because there were holes in my boots

- Ate the same ¬£3 meal deal from Tesco every day for years

- Lived in multiple crowded shared houses, sometimes in rooms where I could touch each wall when stretching out my arms

- Experienced mental health struggles, but didn't see a therapist because of the cost

- Watched as friends bought houses, made investments, had children. The relatability chasm grew.

- Would pay for drinks + meals for prospective investors when they wouldn‚Äôt offer to pay (which was often). I‚Äôd cut back on my own social expenditure to afford it.

- Didn't attend birthdays, weddings, trips because I couldn‚Äôt afford the travel & accommodation

/

There‚Äôs been a lot of discussion about founder pay from the perspective of investors or ‚Äòstart up observers‚Äô.

There hasn‚Äôt been a lot of discussion about what it really feels like as a Founder making the leap.

No matter where your pay checks eventually come from (be it investors/VC, revenue, side-hustles‚Ä¶), when you first choose entrepreneurship, you choose to strip away all sense of safety.

To begin with, there is ZERO. And your income will continue to be zero until you bend the universe to make it more than zero.

There‚Äôs no zoo keeper to feed you, no cage between you and everything else. 

It‚Äôs just naked you, vs big cruel, wants-to-kill-you jungle.

/

Personally, I wouldn't change any of my experience... it was all part of the 'leap of faith'. 

It might read like a sob story, it was actually really bloody fun, and a privilege. I loved it.

All the forgone income bought me knowledge. That knowledge is compounding every day, and will pay back HUGE ROI. I‚Äôm certain.

This isn‚Äôt meant to glamorise the financial struggles of being a Founder.

It‚Äôs supposed to light a fire in anyone who reads this and thinks - yeah, I‚Äôm up for that üî•

#startup #founders #foundersalary #founderpay #entrepreneurship

TITLE: We‚Äôre selling Gaia‚Äôs investment platform to Female Invest! üå±

I‚Äôve long admired the work of Camilla, Emma, and Anna-Sophie and how they‚Äôre fighting for more equitable financial markets.

Today, we‚Äôre thrilled to announce that Female Invest has bought Gaia‚Äôs investment platform and that key talent from Gaia will join the team at Female Invest.

We set out to build Gaia with a vision of creating a new financial system that aligned people, planet, and profit. That‚Äôs also what Female Invest is working towards and so I couldn‚Äôt imagine a better new home for Gaia.

I can‚Äôt wait to see what the team at Female Invest will do with the platform.

Personally, I will take some time to recharge while exploring what‚Äôs next. I‚Äôm excited to dive into a new problem space and apply some of the (many) learnings from building Gaia.

TITLE: Things not to do in your problem statement slide.
TEXT:
Things not to do in your problem statement slide.


-Not declaring the problem in quantitative terms.


-Not giving the audience/investors a chance to get into the shoes of your customers & understand their pain points.


-Not articulating in a deep way the problems that your customer is having.


-A lack of focus on one or two major problems and instead trying to cover everything.


-Inclusion of a high-level explanation of the problem you are solving.


-Including to high-Level explanation of the problem you are solving.


-Making it full of assumptions that are hard to believe without any conclusive evidence.


Below are the examples to problem statement from successful startups pitch deck which they were able to raise funding.



#pitchdeck #presentation #startup #fundraising #investor #enterpreneur

TITLE: "700+ #climatetech investors list"
TEXT:
"700+ #climatetech investors list" 

The French culinary phrase ‚ÄúMise En Place‚Äù refers to having all your ingredients ready before you cook.

Similarly, it‚Äôs important to have all your documents ready to go before you start fundraising.

Documents to keep ready & organised.

1.) Pipeline for investors - A lightweight list of potential investors to contact, which can be shared with mentors and allies who can help with introductions.

2.) Process starter email - The content you will use to personally engage key mentors in your process.

3.) Investor CRM - What you use to actually manage the process.

4.) Forward-able email - Personal context + written one liner + 1-2 overview paragraphs. (Mentors will forward this to investors.)

5.) Emailable pitchdeck - Be careful with this, don‚Äôt send by default

6.) Meeting pitchdeck - Be ready with it but don‚Äôt force it (Share only when asked for)

7.) Financial model - Super important especially for meetings. Know the impact of key assumptions.

8.) Cap table - Necessary for due diligence

9.) Data room - A shared drive that contains financial model, cap table, founder bios, meeting deck, any IP documents, anything else you want investor to see.

What not share without being requested or knowing the investor (assume that your email can be shared with others too)

-Financial model.
-Cap table.
-Competitive advantage.
-Revenue/projections.
-Data room.
-Meeting deck.

Link to the list in the comments.

TITLE: $64B of new dollars for climate in 2022
TEXT:
$64B of new dollars for climate in 2022

Amidst the crypto crash and backdrop of the market downturn, venture capital funds broke a record - for the¬†largest amount of capital¬†raised.

($151b) in any prior full-year, and the year‚Äôs not done yet! The surge has lined the pockets of venture funds with¬†nearly $300b of dry powder, a cash pile that‚Äôs ready to deploy.

These dedicated funds will delay any ensuing waves and maintain stability of capital flowing to climate cos.

Here is what Mia Diawara, a partner at¬†Lowercarbon Capital, a climate-focused VC fund that has backed a wide range of new tech, says they look out before funding a startup.

1. Stage fit‚Äîwe like to partner with teams early, generally at the pre-seed or seed stage of company building.

2. Thesis fit‚Äîwe‚Äôre looking for founders making products that are better, faster, sexier, cheaper than the carbon-intensive incumbents.

3. Climate impact‚Äîfounders should be tackling industries that represent a big chunk of global emissions, or areas where the impacts of climate change will be most significant. And

4. Storytelling/communication‚Äîfounders need to understand and be able to communicate in clear, compelling terms why now is the time, and why they have an unfair advantage that makes their success inevitable. Being able to nail the delivery of those two points is a proxy for a founder‚Äôs ability to sell their product further down the road..

To get the 4th one right you can contact FIDLE

TITLE: The most comprehensive list of active seed funds
TEXT:
The most comprehensive list of active seed funds 

If you're an entrepreneur or CEO, you know how important it is to find the right investor fit for your company.

But with so many options out there, how do you know which one is right for you?

Here are three tips to help you find the best investor fit for your business:

Know what you're looking for:

It's also important to know what kind of investment you're looking for before meeting with potential investors.

Are you looking for seed funding? Or are you further along in your journey and looking for Series A or B funding? 

Knowing this will help you narrow down your search and focus on finding investors who are a good match for your needs.

Do your research:

Before meeting with any potential investors, it's important to do your homework and research their background and investment history.

This will help you get a better sense of whether they're a good fit for your company.

Be prepared to pitch:

When you meet with potential investors, be prepared to pitch your business in a concise and engaging way.

link in the comments.

#ceo #business #entrepreneur #investment #funding #research #pitchdeck #presentation

I love pre seed conversations. 

The founder is laser focused on the problem statement and the target market.

Instead of focusing on traction and metrics (boring and deceiving at early stage), founders and investors converse on possibility and potential. 

I especially love the "AHA" moment when the founder's vision hits me and we both nod our heads in agreement - "this could work."

Tips to get quick commitment:
Come to an investor with a flushed out vision, not a "I need money fast for x,y,z problem."

Try to predict what we will ask in a conversation. If they have legit answers to my questions then it indicates the level of sincerity of the founders - it's clear to me that they they have spoken with customers/stakeholders and have a deep understanding of the problem statement.





Founders today have big dreams.

TITLE: 5 ways to trick your pitch deck into looking professional
TEXT:
5 ways to trick your pitch deck into looking professional

1. leave plenty of consistent margins in every slide- Even when you have to tell your story in 10 -15 slides.

It was also one of the best pieces of advice I received from a senior designer (then working with clients like google and Reddit) who had agreed to review my work.

‚ÄúSakshi your ideas are brilliant but now learn to tell the same thing in less space‚Äù

It was very tough in the beginning as it forces you to think really hard to solve problems most simply and easily.

Every pixel feels like precious real estate but now when I look back at it (after 3 years), it was one of the best pieces of advice as it made all the difference.

2. Pick a colour scheme and stick to it (your own brand colours) if you are not an expert use this trick

-Pick one primary colour and one secondary colour ( for the background).

-For a text and heading use a tone lighter than the usual black.

3. Pick a simple font like Helvetica or Poppins: Use the same font family for all text.

¬†¬†Example: Helvetica bold - Headings.
¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†             Helvetica Regular - Subheading.¬†
¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†             Helvetica Light - Text. 

4. Pick a basic element for your presentation.

Example: A thin rectangle or a circle in the dominant colour you have selected. 

Use them to place below or near the text you want to emphasise on, consistently in different sizes.

5. Good alignment is you best friend and gives your presentations a premium & big brand feel (and takes up the most time)

-Use the self-align feature in presentation software though to let it work effectively make sure you have adjusted all your text box sizes and made the same.

TITLE: I met two 23yo women last night at an event who are already angel investing. This is amazing.
TEXT:
I met two 23yo women last night at an event who are already angel investing. This is amazing.

With a large enough portfolio, they could have a distribution by age 33! 

That's how old I was when I started angel investing. They have a full TEN more years to generate returns.

This is critical because money compounds over time.

Men understand this. They invest early and often.

LADIES - it's never too early (or too late) to start VC fund / angel investing. 

One of my goals in life is to help more women learn about this asset class. I think that when women *really* start to invest, we'll finally make big gains towards gender equality. When women invest, we know that 3x more women founders are funded than when men invest. This directly impacts who is sitting in executive and board seats of the VC backed startups that eventually become some of the world's largest companies.

TITLE: How to accidentally change the world.
TEXT:
How to accidentally change the world.

On this day November 8 a game Guitar hero was released (in 2005).

By a small developer and publisher ( Harmonix and RedOctane) who had decided to come together to try something new and unproven.

With no track record or previous success to back them up.

It was like getting into guerilla, rag-tag, ignoring the adults in the room, putting all the cards on the table, learning how to focus on a project and also kill their darlings.

But It was being made by people working for passion rather than financial gain.

(Though it didn't hurt that the latter came in spades.)

With no notion that the game they were working on would do more than break even, over the course of just nine months the two companies developed a game that altered the course of not only the game industry but the world.

By selling more than 25 million units.

Making more than $2 billion.

It created a watershed moment culturally, with some of the largest bands in the world seeking out their own deals with the company, hoping to cash in on the Guitar Hero boom.

Guitar Hero left a sizeable crater in the music industry and pop culture in general.

As Steve Jobs famously said "Have the courage to follow your heart and intuition. They somehow already know what you truly want to become. Everything else is secondary."

#startup #startupbusiness #business #founders #founder #pitchdeck #presentation #investing #stevejobs #fundraising #inspiration #enterprenuership

TITLE: As a startup founder, did you know 80% of pitch decks are binned by investors within 10 minutes of opening? So for every ten decks they see...
TEXT:
As a startup founder, did you know 80% of pitch decks are binned by investors within 10 minutes of opening? So for every ten decks they see...

- 2 decks have piqued their interest. A long way to go, but you've opened the door. Good luck with your pitch!!!

- 5 were great decks, but it wasn't the right investor, time or place. Keep going, as there is an investor for everybody!!

- 3 decks were not up to scratch. There are so many amazing people ahead of you, so push harder!

There are "experts" on here who will tell you that, whether you're a binman or have a PhD in Bio-AI-Clever-Stuff, you should somehow also be an expert in the #fundraising process and already have a massive existing network of #investors. These people are talking out of their arse! üòä

No one is taught at school how to do the million and one jobs required to be a successful #startup founder. And only a handful went to the right university or spent time at a top consultancy or bank to help build a good investor network.

So my tip of the day is...

üëâ Asking for help, support and guidance is allowed and shows great strength of character

TITLE: What is happening with Twitter?
TEXT:
What is happening with Twitter?

What if it turned out to be better for people who kept seeking opportunities amid these turbulent times?

When the news of adding new features and mass layoffs hit on various news sites, it put a question mark on the future of Twitter employees and also the communities that founders were actively building.

But if you notice Twitter itself was created at the time of crisis and succeeded because its parent company Odeo a podcasting platform experienced a halt in it's expansion due to apple announcing its podcasting platform.

That‚Äôs when Jack Dorsey‚Äôs lightbulb went off and he came up with a social networking site, which was based on a person‚Äôs ‚Äústatus.‚Äù

"After that first presentation about Twitter, Williams then CEO of Odeo put Glass in charge of the project,".

While offering to buy back stock from investors to work full-time on Twitter. ( hoping to save investors a loss)

Odeo's investors accepted the deal as nobody thought that the company could be worth $44billion one day.

While everyone is enveloping themselves around twitter news some might take it as an opportunity and turn the tables around.

As they say, turbulent times build great leaders.

What do you think let me know?

TITLE: Why fourth quater is the best time of the year to raise funding from investors.
TEXT:
Why fourth quater is the best time of the year to raise funding from investors.

If you're looking to raise money for your startup, this is the best time to do it.

This is when most investors are looking to invest in new companies and projects.

There are a few reasons why the fourth quarter is the best time to raise funding.

First, many investors have end-of-year budgets that they need to use before the end of the calendar year.

This means that they're more likely to invest in new companies during this time.

Second, many investors are looking to diversify their portfolios before the end of the year.

This means that they're more open to investing in new and innovative companies.

If your startup is working on something new and exciting, this is the perfect time to pitch it to investors.

Finally, many investors are simply more available during the fourth quarter.

They may be taking less vacation time or working on fewer projects, at this time.

Founders who have been raising from past few months let me know your opinion about it?

#startup #investing #pitchdeck #fundraising #presentation #startup #startupfounder #enterpreneur

TITLE: What is a data room and why you should include it along with your pitch deck?
TEXT:
What is a data room and why you should include it along with your pitch deck?

As a CEO, startup founder, or entrepreneur, you know that having a strong pitch presentation is essential to success.

It is the first introduction to you and your business and in most cases also the last.

But what about including a data room as part of your presentation?

A data room is a secure online space where you can store and share important business documents.

This can be incredibly helpful when pitching your business to potential investors, as it gives them a place to easily access all the information they need.

This gives you control to edit and update data anytime during the fundraising process.

Plus, using a data room can help you keep track of who has accessed which documents, ensuring that only authorised individuals are viewing sensitive information.

So if you're looking  make your startup stand out along with a compelling story and stunning pitch deck consider adding a data room.

It could make the difference in landing that crucial investment.

#business #success #data #entrepreneur #startup #investment #fundraising #pitchdeck #presentation

I have read many pitch decks during my career, I know what keeps me reading. So my question to you is - what makes you keep reading a pitch deck?

TITLE: Here are my top 4 tips for making fundraising easier - fundraising is time-consuming but, here's how to make it more efficient. Number 3 is controversial but you know me üòà
TEXT:
Here are my top 4 tips for making fundraising easier - fundraising is time-consuming but, here's how to make it more efficient. Number 3 is controversial but you know me üòà

Last week Canopey hit our funding target, and whilst the dust settles (and the legalities proceed!) I wanted to share my insights into raising money during these times...

I've written two posts so far - links in comments:

1. The "most" important doc for investors
2. What does "early-stage" really mean?

Today I wanted to talk about time ‚è∞

Now everyone will tell you that raising money is time-consuming, and you'll never truly believe how time-consuming it is until you've done it yourself..and you'll inevitably look back and think:

"Damn son, that was so time-consuming, they were right!"

We certainly did üò∂

Here are my top 4 tips for making it easier - it will still be time-consuming but, here's how to make it more efficient.

1Ô∏è‚É£ Build out a simple database of investors.

Every single investor/fund/VC/institution you reach out to - write them down. Name, email, website, and ticket size at the very least but one absolutely pivotal thing - a simple note on their response.

2Ô∏è‚É£ Build out the data room before you start.

Don't worry you can edit it, and change it. But instead of leaving investors hanging, just have it all ready for them, you'll get a decision quicker. There's lots of stuff that could go in a data room, I'll go over that tomorrow üì£

3Ô∏è‚É£ Controversial one, but important: Spread the meetings out.

Most people will tell you to take as many meetings as possible all the time. They've never pitched, fundraised, or sold sh*t to anyone. Take it from someone who used to fundraise for the world's largest independent environmental organisation.

You NEED to take a break from pitching. Particularly after hearing no multiple times - which you will.

If not, your story will be monotonous and you won't really FEEL it every single time. Because ultimately you need them to be impassioned. 

So, take a breather, go back in refreshed, and get more people fired up.

4Ô∏è‚É£ Start early. I mean it.

Everyone says it, we all doubt it, and it's one hundred percent true. Need to raise money in December? Start prepping and talking about it in May. There are some caveats to this, but a general rule of thumb, give yourself 6 months. 

Our round took 9 months from prep to close. Admittedly, there was a proxy-world war, an economic crash, an energy crisis, and the tech bubble burst...but still, plan, prep, and give yourself time in order to save time.

üéâ BONUS

Take advice.

No one likes to admit they don't know something, but the best founders are the ones who are willing to listen within their confidence.

Fundraising is no different. Speak to your advisors. Read AngelThink by Phil McSweeney as a starting point.

I'm writing about Canopey's experience fundraising. More to come! 

#Fundraising
#Investment
#ImpactInvesting
#FounderStories

Hugo Emma Nathan Andrea Phil
PROFILE_MENTION: Phil McSweeney, Hugo Douglas-Deane, Emma Andrews, Nathan Lomax, Andrea Gray, Phil McSweeney
CONTENT_TITLE: Top 4 things to make your investment round time efficient!

TITLE: The investor's thesis cheat sheet
TEXT:
The investor's thesis cheat sheet

Finding investors is hard, but knowing where to look is the first step.
After seeing all your options, you can then work on making your chances of getting accepted greater.

Before you send your deck to investors, make sure you have read their thesis and previous investments.

It's important to understand what an investor is looking for before pitching your company.

By reading their thesis, you can get a better sense of what they're interested in and what kind of companies they've invested in before.

By doing your research, you'll be able to tailor your pitch more effectively and increase your chances of getting funded!

Free tools to research faster:

1. Funden
2. Visible.vc
3. Crunchbase.com
4. Investorhunt
5. Mercury
6. AngelMatch
7. Investors.tech


#work #research #investments #enterpreneurship #startup #ceo #founder #pitchdeck #pitchevent #presentationskills #presentation

Step 2: Learn how international investments differ for US focused investors. 

There is a special activation energy / hurdle that these deals require. It‚Äôs similar to any domestically focused fundraise, it just requires‚Ä¶more

I‚Äôm working on content to help with both steps but it‚Äôs pretty country specific

Here‚Äôs what I can do now.
