TITLE: Founders who are ready to email pitch deck's  to investors.
TEXT:
Founders who are ready to email pitch deck's  to investors. 

Before you hit "send," there are 5 things you must take care off: 

1. Share your deck in pdf format or include a link to the deck.

Make it easy for VCs to access your deck from multiple devices. (if you already have some revenue or funding, then descend might be a good investment)

2. Personalize each email 

Generic emails are a turn-off and will likely be ignored (Even after demoday). Take the time to research each investor/ VC firm thesis and tailor your pitch accordingly.

3. Keep it short and sweet 

No one wants to read a long, drawn-out email. Get to the point quickly and be concise.

4. Take into account the information they'll need to make a decision 

Including their due diligence team members who may not have been able to attend demo day and has no idea about your business.

5. Avoid animations, transitions or videos in your email pitch deck 

 Make it easy to go back and forth between the slides.

#founders #business #research #entrepreneurship #investment #funding #demoday #pitchdeck #email #share

TITLE: I raised all of Luna's very early ¬£300K Angel cheques by crafting the best story with a great hook so that investors got emotional.
TEXT:
I raised all of Luna's very early ¬£300K Angel cheques by crafting the best story with a great hook so that investors got emotional.  

This is what I've learned from building Luna's story:  
 

1. Telling the story of how the business started isn't enough. It needs to be emotive. It needs to give someone a feeling inside. 
 
2. You know you're telling a great story if early on you get a "yeah I can totally see that". Make sure you hook your story around a common problem which is relatable.  
 
3. Don't overshare the story. My biggest mistake as a first time founder raising money was the classic founder brain dump. It leaves investors wondering what the fuck just happened.  
 
4. Telling your FOUNDER story in such a way that drives confidence is make or break at the earliest stage. You become investable by having confidence in your ability to build.  
 

Honestly, learning how to become a good storyteller is the best thing I've done over the past 3 years üëè 
 
Starting a company always starts with a story.


It's taken almost 300 rejections from investors to get there, but when you do get there, the difference in your rejection : acceptance ration is huge üöÄ

TITLE: Did you know photos can get people connected with your mission?
TEXT:
Did you know photos can get people connected with your mission?



Because they help what you‚Äôre saying resonate in your audience‚Äôs mind without pulling their attention from your spoken words.



Simple, punchy photos in presentations can make a huge difference,


For instance, we recently crafted a pitch deck for a sustainability startup #Superkons 


Where we used this image of a sea tortoise about to eat a  bottle.


The point we wanted to make in the audience's mind  was its URGENT 


While we see this presentation and decide whether to fund this startup idea or not 


Species are dying because of ocean plastic and we need to act now to fund and support sustainable product alternatives like Superkons

---

Pro-tip for your next presentation

Look for photos that

(1) Speak strongly to the concept you‚Äôre talking about and

(2) Aren‚Äôt compositionally complex.

Your photo could be a metaphor or something more literal, but it should be clear why the audience is looking at it,

And why it‚Äôs paired with what you‚Äôre saying.

#startupfunding #startupfounder #startup #pitchdeck #enterpreneurs #fidle #sustainability #presentationskills #presentationtips

TITLE: I‚Äôve spoken to a few founders recently either about to start their funding journey, or struggling during their fundraising round.
TEXT:
I‚Äôve spoken to a few founders recently either about to start their funding journey, or struggling during their fundraising round.

I think the least helpful phrase given to founders is:

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs money out there‚Äù 

We know it comes from a place of good intention. 

We know that it is meant to be the ‚Äúhope‚Äù after a long list of no‚Äôs.

The irony is, we know ‚Äúthere‚Äôs money out there‚Äù.

We wouldn‚Äôt be speaking to you if we didn‚Äôt know that.

What is of more value is‚Ä¶

‚úçüèª Advice on how to improve our pitch
üì£ Feedback on why we weren‚Äôt right at this time
ü§ùüèª At best an intro
üëãüèª At worst something tangible for us to take away and move forward with

And look, I know it‚Äôs mad to assume that investors have the time to give to everyone, or even that they‚Äôre obliged to.

But, if you‚Äôve got the time to write ‚Äúthere‚Äôs money out there‚Äù on a LinkedIn post, on a two paragraph email, on a blog, you‚Äôve got the time to give constructive feedback üëèüèª

In no particularly order here are some fantastic people to follow and listen to:

Astan M. 
Phil McSweeney 
Karina Vazirova 
Robbie Crabtree 
Kevin Withane 
Nick Telson 
Jamie Harford 
Orr Vinegold - Sept Prog Applications open now üî•
Roei Samuel 

Follow them, listen to them, you don‚Äôt have to take every piece of it but I‚Äôd recommend weighing up where you‚Äôre at and what you could do over the next 6 months to make it more likely to succeed.

Yes, ‚Äúthere‚Äôs money out there‚Äù

No, that‚Äôs not helpful feedback.

Who am I missing? Let‚Äôs tag and raise awareness!

#Investment
#Founder 
#Startup

EDIT: just a note to add, I‚Äôm well aware this is a two-way relationship. Investors are not obliged to do anything. And often, founders are taking the wrong approach in the first place (I‚Äôll be writing about this tomorrow!). This is just a general statement about feedback üëèüèª
PROFILE_MENTION: Astan M., Phil McSweeney, Karina Vazirova, Robbie Crabtree, Kevin Withane  (FRSA), Nick Telson, Jamie Harford, Orr Vinegold, Roei Samuel

TITLE: SELL YOUR PEOPLE, NOT JUST AN IDEA
TEXT:
SELL YOUR PEOPLE, NOT JUST AN IDEA

People invest in people:

They want to know they'll be funding highly skilled, deeply-committed founders

And your pitch deck needs to sell your team as much as it does your product.

Especially, if you are pre-revenue/ pre-product market fit 

Then your startup is nothing more than your team, vision, and your ability to tell your story. 

So, don't wait to introduce your team till the last, 

Instead, include your team bio in the first 2-3 slides. 

Plan your story and deck flow accordingly. 


#founders #team #people #funding #startupfounder #startupfunding #startup #enterpreneurship #pitchdeck #powepoint #presentationskills

TITLE: ContigoU is changing the skilled nursing rehab landscape across the whole of California and beyond.
TEXT:

TITLE: Social media is one of the most powerful tools for building a tribe of like-minded and like-motivated thinkers.
TEXT:
Social media is one of the most powerful tools for building a tribe of like-minded and like-motivated thinkers.

But there's a problem:

It's really easy to get caught up in the fear of how we might be perceived by others.

This worry can cause creators to:

- Hold back their thoughts and ideas
- Be extremely vanilla and boring
- Censor themselves altogether

I‚Äôve lived it firsthand: 

I write something valuable that I know can help people, but start worrying about the what-about-ists and the nitpickers who will peck my words to death.

That‚Äôs exactly what happened recently to one of my coaching-clients-turned-friends here on LinkedIn.

He wanted to share a piece of content that talked about how he invested in himself and his business in 2022.

But he was afraid.

He worried it would be insensitive.

So, he didn't share it.

Then, in our call, I pushed him to post it.

And what happened next was pretty magical.

Join 78,000 other subscribers to read about it tomorrow morning: https://lnkd.in/eXv2Mxfg

Have you ever held back from posting because of fear? Why? Why not?

TITLE: Here's what I would do if I were starting on LinkedIn today:
TEXT:
Here's what I would do if I were starting on LinkedIn today:

(and wanted to grow an audience and business)


1/ Embrace An Obsession:

When you embrace an obsession, you rarely need other external motivation.

You wake up each day with an intense desire to become the best in your specific obsession.

What can you research, break down, & share daily, that would feel like play instead of work?


2/ Develop Unique Knowledge:

This is the knowledge you have acquired on your unique journey, that other people want, but can‚Äôt figure out.

The best way to develop unique knowledge is by putting maximum effort into exploring your obsession.

When you do that, you learn more than the average person, and your knowledge becomes uniquely valuable to them.


3/ Challenge Pre-conceived Solutions:

A lot of LinkedIn creators shine a light on problems, but then they fail to create differentiated solutions.

They have the same pitch, same buzzwords, and the same jargon as everyone else.

Instead, you should leverage your unique knowledge to bring a solution that's completely different than anything on the market.

Stand out by promising and delivering on something unorthodox.


4/ Build Distribution By Studying People:

To turn your content into dollars, people must know you exist.

And if you have unique knowledge, you owe it to the world to get it into their hands.

Don‚Äôt copy your competition.

Instead, study human psychology, marketing, and persuasion.

And talk about that unique solution every single day online.

Build a small audience journey that takes people through discovery > trust >relationship > purchase.


5/ Scale Using Compounding, Daily Media:

Take 30 minutes each day to observe what you learned.

Tell stories, show examples, and share behind the scenes.

Content works on your behalf for hours & sometimes even days.

Classic pieces of content have lasted years or even decades.

Have at least 2 pieces of content working on your behalf in the world at all times.


TL;DR

1. Embrace your obsession
2. Develop unique knowledge
3. Challenge pre-conceived solutions
4. Build distribution by studying people
5. Scale using compounding, daily media

TITLE: I've often feel like a phony entrepreneur.
TEXT:
I've often feel like a phony entrepreneur.

I don't know how to code. 
I don't build software.
I don't have a team.

I used to read the Indie Hackers website every day and wish I could be more like the traditional entrepreneurs I saw.

Writing code.
Building SaaS products.
Creating recurring revenue.

Then, something kind of funny happened.

Courtland and Channing Allen, who run Indie Hackers, reached out to me and asked if I'd be a part of their show last month.

Candidly, I was a bit flabbergasted.

This digital course guy? This guy who can't write a line of code?

Being interviewed by 2 guys I've looked up to for a long time?

No way.

But, it happened.

And like a kid in a candy store, I smiled the entire way through it.

If you're interested in hearing it, you can listen here: https://lnkd.in/eCPKqSyd

3. Spend time working on "obsession" projects

Hard to do when burning out.

TITLE: On Sundays, I do a weekly "preview" for next week.
TEXT:
On Sundays, I do a weekly "preview" for next week.

I ask myself these 8 questions:

- What can I remove from my calendar?
- What's on my calendar that can be automated?
- What's something that should be delegated, but isn't?
- Is there anything on my calendar that isn't urgent & important?
- Can any important meetings be 50% shorter?
- How can I get off the computer more?
- How can I maximize family time?
- Is there anything missing?

This is an ever-evolving list for me.

Do you preview your weeks? If so, how?

TITLE: Build your first online micro-business for less than $20.
TEXT:
Build your first online micro-business for less than $20.

(Using only LinkedIn for leads)

Here's how:

1. Choose a skill you want to get 10x better at (example: SEO).

2. Change your LinkedIn profile to reflect your new journey:

i.e. "On a mission to simplify SEO for new creators and online entrepreneurs."

3. Spend the next 90 days devouring everything you can about SEO.

4. At the end of each day, write down 1-2 lessons that you learned.

5. Create content daily sharing those lessons.

6. When people ask you questions, DM them.

7. Ask them if they'd like to talk for free, to see if you can help.

8. Do 10 of these calls to better understand - what are the biggest pains?

9. Create a process you can walk people through in 60 minutes to solve those.

10. Then go to Carrd and build a simple personal website for $19

11. Open up a free Stripe account and create a paid service (Ex: $500)

12. Create a brand new service offering based on the pains above:

i.e. "High-Value Keyword Analysis and SEO Roadmap for New Creators"

13. Open up a free Calendly and create the same exact event.

14. Open up a few slots outside of your 9 to 5.

15. Add a "Buy" button to your Carrd page and redirect it to Stripe checkout.

16. After the payment, redirect Stripe checkout to the Calendly account.

17. Then, add your website to your LinkedIn featured section.

18. Continue educating yourself every single day.

19. Continue sharing fresh, new content every single day.

20. When people ask questions, direct them to the link to pay.

Listen...

This is certainly not perfect.

And there are a million nuances I didn't mention.

But know this:

Getting started is the hardest part.

So, try the above cheatsheet for 6 months.

Tinker around with it, listen to your customers, experiment, and make changes.

Here's a free guide I wrote that goes a bit deeper: https://lnkd.in/e4HWifca

I hope this helps a few people change their lives in some small way. 

Cheers.

TITLE: I signed my first creator coaching client in 2020.
TEXT:
I signed my first creator coaching client in 2020. 

The client was a highly regarded entrepreneur in my space, and when he signed the agreement, I remember thinking,  "what was I going to teach him?"

I prepared for hours to make sure I was ready to have the most robust conversation in history. 

I had workbooks, notepads, excel sheets of information, and formulas.

I was ready.

When the meeting began, we started breaking down his content & business.

- He didn‚Äôt have a marketing strategy.
- He didn‚Äôt have any appropriate technology.
- He wasn‚Äôt measuring his content analytics effectively.

I remember sitting there with my mouth agape.

Needless to say, this has been a very similar story in many of my engagements. 

Remember that the information you‚Äôre familiar with is not always common knowledge.

You know more than you think you do.

And that's what I commonly refer to as "knowledge blindness".

Our inability to see our knowledge as extremely useful rather than, "stuff everyone knows". 

Knowledge Blindness is a big part of why many people never start sharing, never start writing, and never stop building.

It's 1 of 5 things I noticed about my Impostor Syndrome when I started trying to fix it.

If you're interested in learning about how I finally beat mine, you can read my story here: https://lnkd.in/eRrNNGYC

-----

If you enjoy this read, turn on my üîî for more posts about launching, growing, and monetizing your internet business.

TITLE: How to price your online course for maximum impact.
TEXT:
How to price your online course for maximum impact.

My "4 Hypotheses" Model:


My course on using LinkedIn as a business tool has over 10,900 students and thousands of 5-star reviews.

One of the most common pieces of feedback I receive is that it's "a game changer, especially at the price".

That's how I want people to feel!

But deciding what to price the course at is always a really difficult decision.

So I made 4 hypotheses to eventually end up at the right price point:


Hypothesis 1: Make it accessible

I guessed that most people would be at the beginning or intermediate stages of leveraging LinkedIn.

My hypothesis was that pricing should skew low to capture that audience.

Outcome: Needs to be less than $300.


Hypothesis 2: Make it easy to buy, fast

I wanted to make it what I call, a "Quasi-impulse" buy.

Low enough to be easy to buy the first time they saw it, but high enough to be taken seriously and also to earn significant revenue.

Outcome: To make it a quasi-impulse buy, it probably needs to be less than $200.


Hypothesis 3: Driving word-of-mouth & affiliates would make it viral

Word-of-mouth and affiliate sales only make sense at a lower price point. 

Noting hypothesis 1, the majority of users won‚Äôt feel comfortable referring friends to something incredibly expensive.

"Hey, bud - check out this thing I bought. You should buy it too. It's only $2,997!"

Not gonna happen.

Outcome: Drop to $150.


Hypothesis 4: The 3rd hypothesis will accelerate with global adoption.

Make sure to include PPP (purchase power parity). 

This will incentivize purchases from other countries. 

Those purchasers would be likely to enroll in the affiliate program, too.

Outcome: Include PPP discounts.


The results?

- Price: $150
- PPP Discount: 20% to 60% by country
- Students: 10,900
- Revenue: $1.345M
- Timeline: 18 months
- DM's and emails from happy customers: Thousands

And that's it. 

My 4 hypotheses model.

If you enjoyed this method and think it would benefit your audience, feel free to repost it to your account.

TITLE: I've built 2 of my 5 income streams past 7-figures.
TEXT:
I've built 2 of my 5 income streams past 7-figures.

And I have no idea how to write code.

Use these 10 steps to start your journey (without all of my mistakes):


1/ Eliminate the "fallacy of expertise"

When you get started, don't think, "am I an expert?"

If you do, you'll never start.

Instead, make a list of your accomplishments, big & small, over the last 2-3 years.

What skills did you learn during this period?


2/ Identify your interests

Inside the list you just created, will be things you loved & hated doing.

Sorry, but misery doesn't scale.

Choose something you built skills in, that you enjoy doing & talking about.

This will be your focus.


3/ Find the "you" from 2-3 years ago

Your goal is to find people who are just like you, but much earlier in their journey.

Where do they hang out? Try places like:

- Reddit
- Twitter
- LinkedIn
- FB Groups

If you can't find them, use tools like SparkToro to help.


4/ Create content

Next, it's time to establish credibility.

Here are some easy ways:

- Teardowns
- Newsletters
- Step-by-step guides

Document everything you learn & share it!

Show the people 2-3 years behind you that you understand their challenges & have solved them.

This will gain you a small following.


5/ Create a service business

A simple service business can be your 1st income stream.

An MVP landing page + Stripe to collect payments.

The key? Make the pricing a no-brainer.

You're not looking to get rich, you're looking to learn & help.


6/ Promote it

You won't get clients just because you exist.

Instead, find easy ways to promote it.

When your new followers ask you questions, tell them about your business.

When you write content, share a link at the end.

Simple stuff.


7/ Listen for commonalities

This is a key step to creating your 2nd income stream.

Your goal when coaching is to listen for the most common problems you hear.

- Write down every problem you hear
- Dive deeper to understand them
- Keep a running list

This is the gold.


8/ Build a digital product

Your 2nd income stream is your 1st digital product. Focused on the most common problem above.

Take someone from problem to solution in < 60 minutes.

Keep it focused.

Single problem ‚Üí single solution

Price it reasonably to build trust.


9/ Raise your rates

With a lower-priced product, you can now increase your rates.

When people want a service, you can help 1:1.

When they want to learn on their own, you have a product.

You now have an offering for different learning styles & price points.


10/ Set up your systems

- Create useful content
- Drive people to the product
- Upsell service packages to help

With this simple system, it's only a matter of time before you add a 3rd income stream:

- Consulting
- Community
- Physical products
- Cohort-based coaching

Next?

Get started!

If you want to pros and cons of these business models, plus 2 more you can build, read this free article: 

https://lnkd.in/eK8G7f-h

TEXT:
Miserable people have a zero-sum mindset.

Sitting around at the bar with their friends talking about "it should have been me" or "I'm way better than that guy", or "They just got really lucky and I didn't."

That's why they lose. 

Truly excellent people root for others to succeed.

- Make money
- Build a family
- Travel the world
- Get physically fit
- Meet their heroes
- Achieve their goals
- Experience cultures

That's why they win.

TITLE: You should consider quitting your job in 2023.
TEXT:
You should consider quitting your job in 2023.

Here are 10 reasons why:

1. The Internet:

There has never been a better time to start an internet business.

You have access to 4.9B potential customers.

Break your current earnings into weekly chunks.

Can you find enough people to pay you each week for your knowledge or services?

Likely yes.

Get to 60% or 70% of your current earnings before making a leap.

2. Your health:

During the pandemic, many people got significantly less healthy.

Now, we're back at work and also trying to play catch up on our health.

That's not a fun game to play.

Take 12 months and zoom in on your health with more free time.

3. Your family:

Your spouse/partner is getting older and your kids are growing up fast.

Are you going to be happy that you spent more time at the office, or built a business where you can spend the majority of your time with your loved ones?

4. Your Time:

Time moved slowly when I was a kid.

A little faster in my 20's. Then?

Bang. I'm 41.

I can't imagine spending the prime of my life missing my wife, not being able to explore the world or see my parents before they are gone.

5. Loyalty:

In case you've missed it, companies are laying folks off at a pretty rapid pace.

Newsflash: You're a line on a spreadsheet until the math doesn't work out.

The days of 30+ year careers at companies are over.

Employ yourself and you'll get the boss you deserve.

6. Leverage:

If you build a successful online business, you create incredible leverage.

You become harder to control. You can say no more. You can take time when you want.

You control the effort and how big you want to go.

You're the decision-maker.

7. Flexibility:

Want to take Johnny on a fishing trip?

Want to accompany your aging parents to Japan for their dream vacation?

No more "Damn, my boss says no" while telling your friends about the great work/life balance at your company.

Say yes to everything that matters.

8. Purpose:

When you were growing up, did you dream of sitting in a cubicle & talking to customers about some random integrated multi-platform functionality that will probably fail to IPO?

No.

Instead, choose a curious obsession and go find people who need what you're selling.

9. Joy:

We all think we want happiness, but what we really want is joy.

Happiness is fleeting moments. Joy means making an important impact during our lives.

By betting on yourself and aligning with a higher purpose, you give yourself the best shot of living a joyful life.

10. Regret:

Don't look back in 10 years and wish you got started earlier.

Could you fail? Absolutely.
Will you make mistakes? 100%

Will you recover and always be able to find a job again if you're talented? Definitely.

At least give it a shot in 2023.

I'm rooting for you.

TITLE: In 2019, I reached the peak of my startup career, having been named CRO of one of the fastest-growing healthcare technology companies in the country.
TEXT:
In 2019, I reached the peak of my startup career, having been named CRO of one of the fastest-growing healthcare technology companies in the country.

But there was a big problem.

When I talked to other peers of mine across multiple companies, it became apparent that many people at the height of their jobs were pretty miserable.

There is nothing more deflating than spending your entire career climbing a mountain only to find out that the view isn't quite what you thought it was.

The responsibility didn't matter as much.
The money didn't matter as much.
The title didn't matter as much.
The impact didn't matter as much.

In the end, it was long hours, incredible stress, and a goalpost that moved every quarter.

It wasn't a matter of IF you'll eventually get fired.
It was simply a matter of when.

This is the lifestyle that I decided to run away from on August 1st of 2019.

I've spent the last 3.5 years talking a lot about social media, LinkedIn, Twitter, digital products, etc.

But, those are all just tools.

Tools that we can use to equip ourselves in the modern digital world.

Tools that help people design a better life. A more intentional life.

A life where they can spend time with their family & friends, doing whatever it is they want to do while doing very little of what they don't.

A life of limited obligations and increased enjoyment.

It's our one and only shot. 

I want to help people enjoy it.

As I cross 15,000 students in my products, I want to think about new and unique ways to help people redesign their lives.

2023 and 2024 should be really interesting.

I hope you'll follow along.

TITLE: You're not trying to go viral.

TITLE: My 70-year-old Mother is an accidental internet entrepreneur.
TEXT:
My 70-year-old Mother is an accidental internet entrepreneur.

If she can do it, anyone can do it.

Here's the story:

My Mom opened her own small business in 1990.

She taught aerobic dancing to a small group of women who wanted a low-impact, high-intensity way to stay in shape.

But, like many businesses, the pandemic made it impossible for her to continue.

The school she rented space from was no longer hosting in-person classes of any kind.

So, I showed her how to set up a Zoom account.

She bought a little mic she could clip on.

And I helped her upload the music and dance cues to the computer.

Two years later, my Mom runs her business on the internet from a small town called Novelty, Ohio.

Dancing like a maniac on her screened-in porch.

The class is smaller. Maybe 15 people. Maybe 20. I'm not sure.

I don't think she charges more than $15-$20 per month.

And that's it.

She found something she loved doing.
She found other people who wanted the same outcome.
She set it up for almost no cost and brought everyone together.

An internet community of 70-year-old ladies.

Kicking a**, making some money, and staying in shape.

And that's how my Mom became an internet entrepreneur.

I like to think if my Mom were 22 or 27, or maybe 35 or 42, she'd be on Instagram or LinkedIn sharing her workouts and building a 6-figure business.

But she isn't.

Maybe you are?

Maybe there's something you do every day or every week that other people would like to do with you?

If so, you should join 76,000+ internet entrepreneurs in my weekly newsletter here: https://lnkd.in/eXv2Mxfg

And learn to launch, grow, and monetize your own little internet business.

Maybe even a big one.

I hope this gets some creative juices flowing this Wednesday morning.

Cheers.

TITLE: How to flex your Solopreneur muscle:
TEXT:
How to flex your Solopreneur muscle:

Stop telling people what you're going to do.

Go do it, and then tell people what happened.

TITLE: At your job, you might get a 5% pay bump each year.
TEXT:
At your job, you might get a 5% pay bump each year.

$40k salary this year. $42k next year.

That's a 96 cents an hour raise.

Here's another option...

Build income through curious, self-education:

- Solve: Find something you're genuinely curious about and do a deep dive into figuring it out.

- Document: Take notes about everything you tried, what worked, what didn't, learnings, best practices, and surprises.

- Share: Get online and share everything. Tell people who the content is for and what it will help them do.

- Service: Over time, people who want help will ask for it. Set a fair price and start having conversations focused on learning where everyone else is struggling.

- Productize: Take those specific learnings (i.e. biggest failure points) and put your answers in a short video course or eBook that people can buy for a reasonable price.

Congratulations - you now have a small service and product business.

And there are 4.9B potential customers online.

Don't wait for a raise.

Create one.

TITLE: I've been an executive at startups that raised $300M+ and generated $500M+ in revenue.
TEXT:
I've been an executive at startups that raised $300M+ and generated $500M+ in revenue.

But I've never learned more than I'm learning now.

Just screwing around trying to build my own thing on the internet.

Build something of your own.

It's a skill worth having.

TITLE: Every piece of business advice I could think of after 4 years on my own:
TEXT:
Every piece of business advice I could think of after 4 years on my own:

1. Pessimists are often right, and optimists are often wealthy.
2. If you don't respect people's time, they won't respect you.
3. Stop trying to be cool. Be successful. Cool will come.
4. You learn 100x more by trying than by reading about someone else.
5. If you don't know how to sell, you're going to struggle.
6. Thick skin is a prerequisite for building in public.
7. You go 10x faster by supporting people, not tearing them down.
8. No matter how good your product is, someone will hate it.
9. Price whatever you offer at a rate you'd be comfortable paying.
10. Your network can either speed you up or slow you down.
11. Stop reading 50 business books and just get started.
12. Stop asking everyone, and start figuring sh*t out on your own.
13. If people root for you to fail, cut them out of your life.
14. Always over-communicate.
15. Assume you can learn something from everyone.
16. Assume everyone you talk to is also full of sh*t.
17. Your business heroes are regular people who took action.
18. If you can make $1, you can make $1,000.
19. If you can make $1,000 you can probably make $100k.
20. Don't ask random people questions. Ask your customers.
21. You don't need meditation and sunlight. You need action.
22. Don't "find a mentor". Do interesting things & attract mentors.
23. Promote yourself online every day.
24. Write daily for at least 30 minutes.
25. Ignore haters. They are the least interesting people.
26. Help others and let them reciprocate. If they never do, move on.
27. Go to therapy and be honest.
28. Drink less alcohol.
29. Start with one revenue stream, but diversify shortly after.
30. Anyone selling instant results is a con.
31. Systems beat motivation & discipline every time.
32. Quit focusing on tools and tech. Just use what you know.
33. Experiment often, but never with 2 new variables.
34. Use data to create better content.
35. Never plagiarize people but borrow shamelessly.
36. The best entrepreneurs know how to teach themselves.
37. You're a lot less clever than you think you are. Be clear.
38. Be on time for important things. You're not a teenager.
39. Nobody is coming to save you.
40. Arguing online is a waste of time and energy.
41. Don't be arrogant, but have a mindset that you can do anything.
42. Nobody cares about you. They care what you can do for them.
43. Don't argue with your customers.
44. Everyone has the same 24 hours. It's how you use it.
45. It's not helpful to study Elon and Bezos if you're making $0.
46. You can't control your past.
47. You are 100% responsible for your future.

-----

Take every piece of advice in this thread with a grain of salt.

Just because I've learned these lessons won't make them 100% true for you.

But, if there is one major takeaway, it's this: Just get started.

That's how you'll learn your own lessons.

Join 75,000+ other self-starters here: https://lnkd.in/eXv2Mxfg

TITLE: A 30-minute conversation led to a $2,243 piece of content.
TEXT:
A 30-minute conversation led to a $2,243 piece of content.

Here's the story:

A few months ago, I had a 30-minute meeting with a friend of mine named Blake Burge to talk about improving his business's revenue.

Blake has a massive Twitter following and is an Excel wizard who creates helpful threads for other Excel users.

But, Blake was facing a challenge that other creators face: 

He was getting in his own way turning attention into revenue.

He had been selling a $49 Excel course and was hardly getting any traction.

So I asked him to walk me through the most common way that someone becomes a customer of his product.

Here was his previous sales process:

Step 1: Prospect reads a Twitter thread of Blake‚Äôs

Step 2: Prospect moves from thread to website to download free Excel templates

Step 3: Prospect receives the free Excel template & is moved to an email sequence

Step 4: Prospect is pitched a $49 Excel course over several emails

Step 5: Purchase is made or the email sequence ends with $0

This math is extremely challenging.

Even if Blake gets 2,000,000 impressions on his thread, he might get 400 free template downloads.

From there, he‚Äôd be lucky if 10% (40) of those people opened it up and started the template. 

Free products are easy to ignore because there is no skin in the game.

Of those 40 people, he might convert 1.5% for 0.6 customers or $29.40 per thread.

There‚Äôs no way that should be happening.

TITLE: My tech friends are more stressed than ever.
TEXT:
My tech friends are more stressed than ever.

1,600 layoffs per day in 2023.

40-hour workweeks are now 60+ hours.

Picking up the slack because their company fired 10% and now they are leaning harder than ever on the top performers who are still around.

So, everything is starting to blend together.

Their family time is now company time.
Their dinners are spent checking their iPhones.
Their evenings get interrupted by company emails.

Jobs regularly invading family time is the new norm.

Crazy.

I talk to people like this daily who are walking away and choosing to find companies that embrace balance & creativity.

Or recognizing that their side projects can become full-time with a bit more focus.

I hope this trend continues.

Here's to the people saying "enough is enough" and reclaiming their lives üçª

TITLE: Should you quit and storm out of your 9 to 5?
TEXT:
Should you quit and storm out of your 9 to 5?

Probably not. Here's what you should do instead:

1. Check your employee agreement

Can you work on a side hustle while employed?

It's always good to double-check your agreement with your employer first.

If you're good to go, next...


2. Embrace an obsession

Find something you're obsessed with an dive in.

When you love something, you rarely need external motivation.

You wake up each day with an intense desire to become the best in your specific obsession.

So ask yourself this:

‚ÄúWhat am I absolutely obsessed with? What could I research, break down, and share with the world daily, that would feel like play instead of work?‚Äù


3. Acquire unique knowledge

The best way to develop this unique knowledge is by putting maximum effort into exploring your obsession.

For example, there are a million ‚Äúproductivity experts‚Äù and books on building better habits.

But James Clear‚Äôs book, Atomic Habits, stands head and shoulders above the rest.

Why?

Because his obsession with habits led him on a unique journey all his own.

And out of that journey came unique knowledge like:

- Habit Stacking
- Plateau of Latent Potential
- The 3 layers of Behavioral Change

Nobody can compete with James, because in a world of boring academic and scientific studies, James translated his obsession into unique knowledge that only he has.


4. Build distribution

Study human psychology, marketing, and persuasion.

Don‚Äôt copy your competition.

Once you understand how to generate attention, set up a simple customer journey that increases awareness, trust, and relationships.


5. Scale using digital media

Take 30 minutes at the end of each day to observe what you accomplished or learned that day.

What can you share with your audience that's a uniquely specific learning to you?

Tell stories, use metaphors, show real word examples, share behind the scenes, challenge conventional thinking, etc.

Every piece of content works on your behalf for hours, days, and sometimes - weeks.

Classic pieces of content have lasted years or even decades. That's the power of media.


TL;DR

1. Check your employee agreement
2. Embrace an obsession
3. Acquire unique knowledge
4. Build distribution
5. Scale using digital media

-----

TITLE: Every Solopreneur must understand website traffic.
TEXT:
Every Solopreneur must understand website traffic.

Here's a simple breakdown of 5 types of traffic (and how to get some):

1/ Direct Traffic:

Direct traffic basically means users who visit your site by directly typing in the URL.

Why it's good: Shows your brand is becoming popular with searchers.

How to get some: Become known for one specific thing & increase your social presence & social network.


2/ Organic Traffic:

Organic traffic comes from visits to your website through different search engines.

Why it's good: This traffic comes from people searching for something specific, increasing your lead quality.

How to get some: Analyze keyword gaps & low-competition keywords to start.


3/ Referral Traffic:

Referral traffic happens when someone visits your website by clicking on a link from somewhere else.

Why it's good: Sends potentially qualified visitors to your website from trusted sources.

How to get some: Find guest blog post or podcast guest opportunities, or trade newsletter mentions with someone relevant in your space.


4/ Social Media Traffic:

Social media traffic means people visit your website after clicking on a social media post.

Why it's good: Builds a lot more awareness at the top of your marketing funnel!

How to get some: Post regularly, cross-post to relevant sites & drive people to the website on your profile.


5/ Paid Traffic:

Paid traffic comes from people who visit your website after clicking on an ad that you paid for.

Why it's good: Fast, easier to track, campaign optimizations, etc.

How to get some: Run ads (Meta, Insta, LinkedIn, etc.) or hire an agency to run ads on your behalf.


To recap the 5 types of web traffic:

- Direct Traffic
- Organic Traffic
- Referral Traffic
- Social Traffic
- Paid Traffic

Here's my recommendation: 

Attack one channel and get really, really good at it. Then bolt on another.

Start with Social - it forms the foundation for your brand and awareness. By doing well on social, you'll influence Direct, Referral, and Organic a bit. 

Then, consider investing in a long-term organic (SEO) strategy. My opinion is that Paid becomes much easier when you have a formidable brand. Consider that last.

Please don't try to master them all at once.

TITLE: On December 16th, 2018 I had a massive panic attack.
TEXT:

It was the culmination of 10+ years of long hours, stress, and loss of control.

So I quit my job.

I spent the next year losing 40 lbs, working on my mental health, and building my own business.

But then something happened:

In 2020, I started burning out again.

Same grind, same hours, same abuse - all brought on by ME

I was the culprit. The one to blame.

So, rather than look for a quick fix this time around, I worked to improve in different 7 areas.

And the results have been overwhelmingly positive:

A life of intention, far better mental and physical health, time with friends and family, and a drastic reduction in unwanted obligations.

TEXT:
High-performers are burning out & quitting in their prime.

I know 10+ people who reached the pinnacle of their industry, looked around & realized everyone around them was unhappy.

So they quit & pursued something vastly different, armed with their knowledge & an internet connection.

People think the "Great Resignation" is over, but it isn't.

Sure, fewer people are quitting, but not the best talent. 

They are leaving jobs that feel purposeless, and embracing a new journey toward work that is meaningful, fulfilling, and helpful.

I think this is the start of a much bigger trend of high performers impacting people on a larger stage.

How wonderful is that?

TITLE: "Be authentic" is the most common advice on LinkedIn and it's pretty meaningless.
TEXT:
"Be authentic" is the most common advice on LinkedIn and it's pretty meaningless.

Because we all have a limited amount of time to make an impression.

And that limited time is carefully planned & delivered.

Recorded. Re-recorded.
Written. Re-written.
Reread. Tinkered.
Edited.

So, that's what you get when you read content. A tiny bit of edited information.

So, why does any of this matter?

It matters because the top 1% creators know this and use it to their advantage.

Instead of only being "authentic", they are also "intentional".

So, as you go on your LinkedIn journey, remember this:

"Who do you want to be known as?"

Craft that.
Intentionally.

TITLE: Escape the rat race, or embrace it?
TEXT:
Escape the rat race, or embrace it? 

That's the question so many people have. 

For me, the answer became clear in 2018 - it was time to break free from the constraints of the traditional workforce and forge my own path.

My first step? Simple - I let go of ambition.

No more chasing after the next big thing.

No grandiose desire to leave a mark on the world, or the need for external validation. 

Instead, I focused on what truly brought me fulfillment - working on projects I was passionate about with people I cared about, the freedom to travel and spend time with loved ones, and the ability to say goodbye to tasks that drained my energy.

This shift in mindset allowed me to live more intentionally and make choices that aligned with my values. 

As you get lost in 2023, ask yourself:

Is this year about someone else's dream, or your own?

TITLE: Ideas are a dime a dozen - everyone has them.
TEXT:
Ideas are a dime a dozen - everyone has them.

Execution is a bit more rare. Moving from idea to action.

Action over 5 years? 10 years? 20 years?

That's the rarest Entrepreneur, business person, athlete and thinker.

Become a great one by putting one foot in front of the other for decades, my friends.

TITLE: I took an #HIV test today.
TEXT:
I took an #HIV test today.

I tested NEGATIVE.

Why am I writing this here on LinkedIn?

I grew up in a society where HIV and AIDS were taboo topics.

Where people made jokes about sex and disease.

Where parents avoided talking about AIDS prevention.

Where no one dared to get tested.

But this is not a joke. This is a tragedy.

ùüê.ùüí ùê¶ùê¢ùê•ùê•ùê¢ùê®ùêß #ùêàùêßùêùùê¢ùêöùêßùê¨ ùêöùê´ùêû ùê•ùê¢ùêØùê¢ùêßùê† ùê∞ùê¢ùê≠ùê° ùêáùêàùêï. And millions more are living in fear and ignorance.

Because they are too afraid to get tested.

Because they think it is a shame.

Because they don't know the truth:

HIV testing is not a #shame. It is #courage.

It is a way to save your life. It is a way to protect your partner's life. It is a way to save the world.

This post is going to get avoided by most people who read this.

But it is important... 

Let's #normalize getting tested for HIV in India!

Shlok's Shlok

TITLE: This is more than just a lunch box.
TEXT:
This is more than just a lunch box.

At 50, my mom decided to start her own business. 

She noticed many youngsters living in Lucknow who had to settle for education or job purposes were missing their home food.

She decided to provide meals to these youngsters in boxes full of food and, of course, mom's love.

She had enough infrastructure to cook food but had no means of delivering it to them.

That is when she got to know about Porter. Their services were so affordable and easy to book. 

She began by delivering these boxes across Lucknow using services by Porter. Their employees would use bikes to deliver food across Lucknow, cutting through the traffic.

The youngsters were delighted with the quality of the food and precise delivery. She started getting demands from other cities as well.

She made homemade snacks and took the help of a porter whose staff would pack the boxes in secure cartons, pick them up in their trucks and deliver them across Uttar Pradesh hassle-free.

She is now serving 1000s of young people! 

ùêà ùêöùê¶ ùê©ùê´ùê®ùêÆùêù ùê®ùêü ùê¶ùê≤ ùê¶ùê®ùê¶, ùê∞ùê°ùê® ùêûùê¨ùê≠ùêöùêõùê•ùê¢ùê¨ùê°ùêûùêù ùê≠ùê°ùê¢ùê¨ ùêõùêÆùê¨ùê¢ùêßùêûùê¨ùê¨ ùêüùê´ùê®ùê¶ ùê¨ùêúùê´ùêöùê≠ùêúùê° ùê∞ùê¢ùê≠ùê° ùê°ùêöùê´ùêù ùê∞ùê®ùê´ùê§ ùêöùêßùêù ùêùùêûùê≠ùêûùê´ùê¶ùê¢ùêßùêöùê≠ùê¢ùê®ùêß.

TITLE: I took the first interview for my entrepreneurship venture last week. It was not what I expected!
TEXT:
I took the first interview for my entrepreneurship venture last week. It was not what I expected!

During the zoom call, I heard 'Yeh Rishta Kya Kehlata hai' TV serial playing in the background!

Kids were shouting in the background!

The experience was too¬†#noisy.

ùêìùê® ùêõùêû ùê°ùê®ùêßùêûùê¨ùê≠, ùêà ùêûùê±ùê©ùêûùêúùê≠ùêûùêù ùêö ùê¶ùê®ùê´ùêû ùê©ùê´ùê®ùêüùêûùê¨ùê¨ùê¢ùê®ùêßùêöùê• ùêöùê©ùê©ùê´ùê®ùêöùêúùê°.

He looked embarrassed while he was giving answers!

After the interview, I told him I wanted to be more impressed with how he presented himself.

He burst into tears, "I am sorry, Sir. I live in a room with my parents, wife, and kids in a slum area in Mumbai. There's nowhere they could have stayed."

"We used to live in a bigger apartment before I lost my job three years ago. This is all I can afford for now. I have failed my family. I know I have."

He said in tears.

ùêìùê°ùê®ùê¨ùêû ùê•ùê¢ùêßùêûùê¨ ùê¨ùê≠ùêÆùêúùê§ ùê∞ùê¢ùê≠ùê° ùê¶ùêû ùê•ùê¢ùê§ùêû ùêö ùêõùêÆùê•ùê•ùêûùê≠!

I apologized and encouraged him not to feel heartbroken. After all, he's trying his best.

Besides, he did well in the interview.

I gave him the contract.

He will be managing brand deals for¬†Shlok's Shlok from next month!

He couldn't believe it because he thought I would dismiss him.

He shouted joyfully, "Naukri mil gayee." (I got the job)

I heard a happy cry in the background.

I was moved.

During this season when all big companies are mercilessly firing, I learned....

ùêÅùêû #ùêáùêÆùê¶ùêöùêß ùêõùêûùêüùê®ùê´ùêû ùêõùêûùê¢ùêßùê† ùêöùêß #ùêûùê¶ùê©ùê•ùê®ùê≤ùêûùê´.

TITLE: My manager called me on #Sunday at 7 am.
TEXT:
My manager called me on #Sunday at 7 am.

ùêåùêöùêßùêöùê†ùêûùê´: Good morning Shlok. I hope I am not disturbing you! What are your plans for today?

ùêåùêû: (Who was going to sleep all day) I Just completed my daily yoga, sir.

Now I am going to pray, create content for #LinkedIn & then read my favorite book, "How to excel at work."

ùêåùêöùêßùêöùê†ùêûùê´: That's great! I've called to seek your little help.

Actually, there's an onsite #bug after the latest release that needed to be fixed asap. If you could look into the same, it would take half an hour.

ùêåùêû: (Who remembers the last time a similar bug took 12 hours) Sure, sir, no worries. But I guess Prerna did the development; if she looks into the same, it will take significantly less time.

ùêåùêöùêßùêöùê†ùêûùê´: Yeah! I called Prerna ! But she rejected the call! 

ùêåùêû:

One Year Later..... In the next #appraisal...

Prerna becomes "Employee of The Year" with a 20% hike. 

I got a hike of 3%.

TITLE: How did I, at age of 19, got a job offer from Apple ?
TEXT:
How did I, at age of 19, got a job offer from Apple ?

I was walking on road and saw a woman hit by the truck.

No one stopped to check on #woman. 

She was lying there on road...waiting for her death!

I picked up the lady and rushed to a nearby hospital. 

The doctor thanked me for bringing the woman on time. 

He said....I saved her life. 

I felt good ! 

Soon, I learned the woman was a relative of Tim Cook!! The CEO of #Apple 

I was shocked! 

Tim Cook soon arrived at hospital and thanked me. 

To be honest, I was #nervous meeting him but he calmed me down. 

We went on to talk & had great conversation about tech, brand building & society.

And then...all of a sudden he offered me a Marketing job at Apple. 

I was overwhelmed. 

But then, I politely refused him and told him, I want a job based on my skills and not based on my good deeds. 

He looked at me & smiled...and said he is #proud of a youngster like me! 

I dont remember what happened after that.... cz my househelp Kanta Bai came to my room to do jhaadu, switched off the fan, my dream broke & I woke up! üòè


Follow Shlok 's Shlok for more such inspiring shloks!

TITLE: #HR calls to give the final offer letter.
TEXT:
#HR calls to give the final offer letter.

HR - Good morning Shlok! 

Congratulations, you've been selected for the position of Software Engineer I. You'll be getting a CTC of 12 LPA!

Fresher Me - Thank you so much. 1 Lakh per month is really great!

HR - Well actually 2 Lakhs is the retention bonus which would be given to you once you complete 3 years in the company.

Fresher Me - Oh okay! 10 Lpa is good too.

HR - Actually 30% is the PLI.

Me - PLI?

HR - Performance linked incentive to be precise. It would be given to you after the yearly evaluation and could vary from 0 to 100%.

Me - Oh okay. But if I work hard, I'll get the 100% PLI right?

HR - To be very honest, in our last 5 years of work, only 1 of our employee was able to get the 100% PLI.

Me - Wow, he must be very hardworking, would love to meet him soon.

HR - Actually, he's the son-in-law of the CEO.

Me -

HR -

Me - Joining bonus to puura milega na ma'am?

HR - Yes.

Me - Oh gosh. Finally!

HR - But if you leave the company before 2 years, you'll have to return it to us.

Me - Wtf? What is the in-hand CTC I'll get after all the deductions?

HR - A whopping sum of 4.5LPA!

Shlok 's Shlok

TITLE: My mom is a social media star!
TEXT:
My mom is a social media star!

She spent all her life taking care of us and making sure all our dreams get fulfilled while she sat on the side being our biggest cheerleader.... just like any other regular Indian housewife!

She even stayed away from our dad (govt. official hence transferable job) for years so that we kids could get stable education at good institutions! 

Today, my mom is more than just a regular Indian housewife!

She has built a brand around her showcasing her authenticity and cultural value!  (Instagram : Yourregularmom)

My video about her reaction to me buying a 35,000 Gucci belt went viral on the internet last year! 

There has been no looking back since then!

She has been creating viral content since then. 

Today my mom has 166000 followers on Instagram.

She was listed as Forbes India's Top 100 DIGITAL STAR !

She is everywhere... Govt. of India, Aaj Tak, The Times Of India , PINKVILLA, India Today, Brut India , Amazon, Apple, Betterhalf,  ScoopWhoop | Good Glamm Group etc. to name a few.

Recently she got invited to Indian Idol and was featured there! Sony | Live and News Production

Is my mom just a STAR...? No, she is a SENSATION!

She is the face of millions of Indian housewives!

I am proud to be called Anita Gupta's daughter!

# #socialmedia #housewife #forbesindia

TITLE: I was not getting a good appraisal! I was VERY concerned!
TEXT:
I was not getting a good appraisal! I was VERY concerned!

I saw my teammates getting promoted while I sat there!

Soon I realized it was because I didnt go out during¬†#smoke¬†breaks with my boss!

They would all bond socially during smoke breaks!

I was loosing because I didn't smoke!

I finally decided to take the bold step for my career!

I learned how to smoke!

#Result:

Now I have been promoted 2 times in 2 years!

Becoz I smoked? Naah!

Smoking breaks actually helped me learn gossip that my boss who is married is having 2 office affairs!

Now I can blackmail him anytime!

Moral: Smoking may be injurious to your health, but it can be good for your career!

TITLE: PokerBaazi‚Äôs current campaign, titled #PokerTank draws such insightful parallels with my life and Business that I had to speak about it.
TEXT:
PokerBaazi‚Äôs current campaign, titled #PokerTank draws such insightful parallels with my life and Business that I had to speak about it.

As you may already know, I have been very vocal about skill and hard work beating luck.

Taking control of the controllables and not letting the variables stop you from doing
What you want is my current mantra. In order to understand this better, let‚Äôs deep dive into Poker a bit.

For all those who don‚Äôt know, Poker is a card game played with analytics and decision-making as some of the primary skills. When you win a hand, you gain insights.

When you lose a hand, you gain learnings. The sport also teaches you self accountability, which is very important to remove luck and other variables out of the equation and focus only on hard work. 

I learnt this not only in Poker but I learned this during my initial career as well. 

After Class 12, I did what was expected of me by society. I did engineering and while applying to colleges, I got rejected because I‚Äôd gotten 0.01% less than the cut-off of a Tier 3 engineering college. 

Instead of blaming the situation or my ‚ÄòLUCK‚Äô, I learned to manage my time properly and keep pushing forward.

I began prepping for my GMAT exams, worked hard, and actually became one of the top 5% of scorers in the world! 

This helped me get a scholarship at Washington University where I am currently pursuing my MBA.

PokerBaazi Baazi Games has done a good job in diving into every aspect of Business through the lens of Poker and the larger messaging is nothing short of relatable and completely applicable in life, Business and in Poker.


#PokerBaazi # #Poker #pokerkisahivalue 
#Entrepreneurship #Growth #

TITLE: Galgotias University  took Rs 20,000 as refundable security money from me and my classmates in 2012 when I took admission in that college.
TEXT:
Galgotias University  took Rs 20,000 as refundable security money from me and my classmates in 2012 when I took admission in that college. 

They promised to return it in 2016 when I graduate and made us fill all forms upon graduation and promised return on money in 2 months.

It has been 11 years, I have not received even a single paisa from that college! 

Everytime you visit their 5 star hotel looking campus the account department makes some kind of excuse. 

Imagine how much interest they would have made by keeping Rs 20,000 of 10,000+ students for 10+ years! 

Now they have 510 crore to invest in Noida Airport.

This is the reality of private universities in #India:
 
No education.

Only loot the middle class of India.

Shlok 's Shlok! 


.
.

TITLE: I am an #HR. I NEVER emailed anyone, "I will get back to you".
TEXT:
I am an #HR. I NEVER emailed anyone, "I will get back to you". 

I took 17 interviews yesterday.

I selected 6 candidates and had to reject 11 candidates.

I reverted to all the #rejected candidates immediately with details mentioning where they lack and where they can improve.

I believe feedback will help them improve in their careers.

I also didnt waste time drawing #Rangoli on the office floor. 

I also didn't force any employee to sing in "Fun Friday" activities.

Being HR is the best. I love my job. ‚ù§Ô∏è üíõ

TITLE: I realized that our cleaning lady at office gets treated like an #outcast.
TEXT:
I realized that our cleaning lady at office gets treated like an #outcast.

So I made sure I shared my pizza or #tea  or anything with her regularly!

Today, I was in a hurry to get into my office, so she came to my desk with her homemade gulab jamun & awkwardly goes "Bhaiya, mere dost banne ke liye thk ku" (Thanks for being my #friend)

Shlok 's Shlok

TITLE: When I went to #Belgium, I couldn't PEE anywhere.
TEXT:
When I went to #Belgium, I couldn't PEE anywhere. 

There were no free public washrooms. Not even at the railway station! 

They were charging 5 euros.

I had no cash. 

And NO ONE accepted online payments! 

I begged a stranger to lend me 5 euros so I could pee. 

I had a terrible pee day that day! üò¨

--

When I arrived in #India, I went to a village & I wanted to use a washroom. 

I again had #no cash again!

The guy at counter just smiled & showed me the QR code. I #UPI-ied him 2 rupees and enjoyed my pee time!

India: 1; Europe: 0

Mera desh badal raha hai, aage badh raha hai!

Shlok 's Shlok

TITLE: I was in a deep 5 hours zoom call & bored when my #wife rushed to my room and started screaming!
TEXT:
I was in a deep 5 hours zoom call & bored when my #wife rushed to my room and started screaming!

I looked at her, shocked .... and screamed that I was on the call. 

She asked me to stop the call and pay attention to her.

She told me her water broke. We are going to be the #parents of twins!

We both started jumping. I told everyone on the call about this. 

My boss exclaimed, "Wow!" "You go; I will manage the rest of the 3 hours of call". I asked for one week's leave, which was approved instantly.

I looked at my wife, we both knew our lives are about to be changed. I rushed her to the hospital. 

It was a wonderful moment! I will cherish it throughout my life! üíõ üíô üíú

Shlok 's Shlok!

BTW: I don't even have a wife! This was my way to get a week-long leave.

"Dada/Nana Marr Gaye" has become too overused now.! My vision is to revolutionize the leave-excuse culture in #India.

TITLE: India is NOT so developed.
TEXT:
India is NOT so developed. 

That's what I was thinking as I was returning to #India for holidays after spending great time in the US.

As I landed in Delhi, I was craving Gol Gappa. 

And after relishing it, I felt terrible... Gosh!!! I cannot use my credit card here at the stall. I will have to pay cash. 

"ùêàùêßùêùùê¢ùêö ùê¢ùê¨ ùêçùêéùêì ùê¨ùê® ùêùùêûùêØùêûùê•ùê®ùê©ùêûùêù!"

Then I saw everyone scanning QR codes and making digital payments across the market! 

I learned its #UPI that Govt of India introduced in 2016, faster and easier than using credit cards. 

Countries are dying to get this technology from India.

----

I reached home and realized I had forgotten to get eggs.

I thought... Gosh!!! If it were the US, I would have ordered eggs online, which would have been delivered in 5 hours!

"ùêàùêßùêùùê¢ùêö ùê¢ùê¨ ùêçùêéùêì ùê¨ùê® ùêùùêûùêØùêûùê•ùê®ùê©ùêûùêù!"

But then I saw Blinkit, Instacart, etc., and was SHOCKED to see the eggs delivered in freaking 7 minutes! 

How is that even possible? 

I was numb for those 7 mins. 

Indian companies have mastered the supply chain challenges!

----

I was later entering the airport and took out my Id card for the scan. 

The CRPF person politely refused. 

They just scanned my face and let me in because of #DigiYatra. 

I was SHOCKED again! 

I have been to North America, Europe, South America... they ask for Id cards everywhere.

----

That's when I realized we should STOP underselling ourselves!

Be proud of our IDENTITY, our CULTURE & our ability to innovate AND thrive! 

#JaiHind #JaiBharat

Follow Shlok 's Shlok for more shlokingly shlokovacious Shloks!

TITLE: #9am:¬†NarendraModi performed the last rites of his mother.
TEXT:
#9am:¬†NarendraModi performed the last rites of his mother.
#12pm: He was back to work, inaugurating several projects across West Bengal.

God Shri Ram had said, "#Duty is greater than any #emotion."

I saw a real-life example of that saying today!

#JaiHind!

Shlok's Shlok!

TITLE: Stop calling #Indians who moved out of India Anti-National!
TEXT:
Stop calling #Indians who moved out of India Anti-National!

Most bright minds have been leaving India because they did not get a chance to prove themselves historically!

Here, if you ever propose an idea to a boss, you are politely or often impolitely asked to shut your #mouth and called 'Abhi bachhe ho.' 

You should open your mouth only after 30 years of experience in a #job. Only then will people take you seriously.

--

Today, people in their 20s are full of ideas! And it is unfair to shut them up.

That's why they decide to leave the country because they see people outside ARE ready to take a chance on them!

This is why most successful international companies are being headlined by Indians today because these Indians got wings to #fly in a foreign land. 

Shlok's Shlok

TITLE: You need not to take #sick or 'emergency' leave everytime! Such understanding #managers also exist!
TEXT:
You need not to take #sick or 'emergency' leave everytime! Such understanding #managers also exist! 

Let's normalize open conversations at workplace! 

#WorkPlaceGoals

Shlok 's Shlok! :)

TITLE: One of my friend met with a serious car accident and was paralyzed.
TEXT:
One of my friend met with a serious car accident and was paralyzed.

He was #bedridden for an year.

His company was cooperative initially but then asked him to resign in 6 months. 

He was in a bad state of mind. He was jobless & his lower body was not working. 

He applied to multiple companies. They seemed nice but rejected him because of his disability. 

But there was one company that saw him beyond his #disabilities & hired him because they found his skills worthy. 

That company was #Tata

Bless such companies! And such leaders!

#RatanTata

Shlok 's Shlok

TITLE: I am ùóòùóüùóîùóßùóòùóó to announce that ......

.
.
I have NOTHING to announce.

Some days can go without achievements! 

We are all #ùóõùó®ùó†ùóîùó°ùó¶. Not #ùó¶ùó®ùóñùóñùóòùó¶ùó¶ #ùó†ùóîùóñùóõùóúùó°ùóòùó¶. üôè

TITLE: My English is WEAK. I got FIRED because of it.
TEXT:
My English is WEAK. I got FIRED because of it. 

I wrote...

üêí "Thank You, Mummy" instead of "Thank You, Mam" to a 10-year senior female colleague.

üêí "It was gand opening" instead of grand opening.

üêí "The attachments are kissing."

üêí "Hoe are you" instead of "how are you" to a female client.

üêí "It was pressure meeting you," to a client.

üêí I mailed a CEO, "Hope you are doping well." He replied, "Yes, I am; this stuff is really good."

Why we all have to learn English in #India? Its not even our native language !

No country in the world other than India puts so much emphasis on learning a foreign language! 

What should I do now? üò≠

Shlok's Shlok!

TITLE: Meet husband and wife: Shloka & Shlokie. They have a kid Shlok Jr.
TEXT:
Meet husband and wife: Shloka & Shlokie. They have a kid Shlok Jr.

#Shlokie worked as Software Engineer at Microsoft. 

#Shloka worked as a Marketer at Meta.
¬†
In the great economic crises of 2022, they got an annual hike of 0%. 

Also later, both were fired from their respective companies. 

ùêìùê°ùêûùê≤ ùê∞ùêûùê´ùêû ùê≠ùê´ùêöùêÆùê¶ùêöùê≠ùê¢ùê≥ùêûùêù. ùêñùê°ùêöùê≠ ùê∞ùê¢ùê•ùê• ùê°ùêöùê©ùê©ùêûùêß ùê≠ùê® ùêíùê°ùê•ùê®ùê§ ùêâùê´'ùê¨ ùêüùêÆùê≠ùêÆùê´ùêû?

They used their brains. 

Before leaving the companies, they referred each other to their companies, as Microsoft was hiring for a #Marketer & Meta was hiring for #SoftwareEngineer.

ùêçùê®ùê∞, ùêõùê®ùê≠ùê° ùê®ùêü ùê≠ùê°ùêûùê¶ ùê°ùêöùêØùêû ùê£ùê®ùêõùê¨ ùêöùê≠ ùêåùê¢ùêúùê´ùê®ùê¨ùê®ùêüùê≠ & ùêåùêûùê≠ùêö ùê∞ùê¢ùê≠ùê° ùüèùüéùüé% ùê°ùê¢ùê§ùêûùê¨.

Their household income increased by 200%. Shlok Jr's future is secure.

Be smart. Be like Shloka & Shlokie. Fight #recession with panache!

Shlok's Shlok!

P.S. This story is of course, fiction. If it were true, many lives won't be destroyed during this recession!

'Repost' if you agree!

TITLE: I was stuck in Bangalore #traffic & getting late for an #interview.
TEXT:
I was stuck in Bangalore #traffic & getting late for an #interview.

I decided to call my interviewer and begged him "Sir can we shift the interview  for later? I am stuck in heavy traffic" 

Interviewer sighed "Yeah we will have to! I am behind your car"

We ended up doing the interview in my car He hired me from car!  

Shlok 's Shlok:   Modern problems require modern solutions!

TITLE: I added an AI policy to my syllabus.
TEXT:
I added an AI policy to my syllabus.

We discussed the details in class today, and instructors should know that, once students can see what AI does, many are concerned about what AI means for their future. Not in a AI-will-wake-up-and-kill-us way but in a will-there-still-be-jobs-in-my-field way.

We don‚Äôt have many answers yet, but we should welcome discussion. And teach how to use the tools responsibly.

TITLE: If You Want to Land More Jobs
TEXT:
If You Want to Land More Jobs

Stop getting so caught up in the ‚Äúcreative design, layout, or format‚Äù of your resume. Get straight to the point and showcase how you . . .

Create value, through ‚Äì 

- Delivering results
- Measuring results
- Capturing results
- Producing results

All of this is the most impressive thing you can put in front of a hiring manager regardless of the level or years of experience. 

Companies DO NOT hire those who ‚Äútry‚Äù but rather those who execute and contribute to the company‚Äôs goals and business objectives.¬†

TITLE: 3 Ways to Get More Job Offers
TEXT:
3 Ways to Get More Job Offers 

#1 Position yourself as a high-valued candidate
Avoid doing the norm and blending in with other candidates; you are doing yourself a disservice. The market is very competitive, and you must stand out amongst the pack. Think from a bird‚Äôs eye view and not a head on point of view. If you follow the crowd, you will be like the crowd. Go against the grain to strategically stand out. 

#2 Network and Build Relationships
Job boards are great to apply to the roles of your interests, but you are still doing the same as everyone else. On average, there are 250+ candidates applying to the same role as you, so how are you shining bright? 

LinkedIn is your strongest ally and the strongest platform to network. Start connecting NOW to access the hidden gems. Believe it or not, most companies are big on hiring via internal referrals or even through their external partnerships with talent and recruiting firms. Use the resource of networking to your advantage. 

To position yourself better, please apply to the job first ‚Äì then reach out to your network as this will move the process along more seamlessly. 

#3 Tailor your experience and conversation
In the unavoidable ‚Äútell me about yourself‚Äù question, highlight the most relevant and impactful components and skills of your career. This response should be tailored to the role that you are interviewing for. No need to go around the world, get straight to the point and be tactful. 

This is why researching before a job interview is very important because you will understand what the company does and what they are looking for in a candidate. Speak to what they are needing. Your skill set is a service to be offered as a solution to their needs. 
¬†

TITLE: How Often Should You Update Your Resume?
TEXT:
How Often Should You Update Your Resume? 

You should update your resume every 6 to 12 months. 

Each year you will develop new skills and progressive experience. Your resume should reflect any certificates, licenses, or training programs you have earned. Keeping your resume current with skills and experiences will be helpful even if you aren't seeking a new job because you can use it to advocate for yourself when applying for a promotion or requesting a raise.

Throughout this period of time, you will want to keep a log to track your accomplishments, successors, and progression. 

Tracking your progress along the way, will prevent you from having to think back on ‚Äúhow you have contributed through quantifiable accomplishments" and have a real time list where never goes unnoticed.   

A rule of thumb is to always have a targeted resume based on your goals and roles that you are in pursuit of. 

If you‚Äôre able to show your perceived value on your resume, this will allow you to be a competitive candidate and separate you from the bunch. 

***QUESTION***
Why would a company extend an offer or offer a high compensation package if you don‚Äôt consider yourself a high qualified candidate through showcasing your outputs?

TITLE: How to Answer the Common Interview Question
TEXT:
How to Answer the Common Interview Question

Tell me about yourself . . .

The hiring manager/interviewer is NOT interested in your life story but more so of your career highlights. 

What they are pursuing is a quick overview of your professional experience before you move into details. 

Keep your response short, simple, and sweet.

Talk about: 
- Your experience
- Your Strengths

These two quick snapshots should be relevant to the role you are applying and interviewing for. 

SIDE NOTE: It is ok to mention a couple of hobbies or interest just to be more personable but do not overdue or make this the focus of the response. 

Stay tuned for a continuation of more ‚Äúhow to answer‚Äù responses.¬†

TITLE: Resume Hacks
TEXT:
Resume Hacks

Before Submitting a Resume, do this . . .

#1 Thoroughly read the job description and understand what the employer is looking for in a candidate

The job description is DESCRIBING the type of candidate they are pursuing, so align yourself appropriately.

#2 Tell Your Career Story 
- Talk through your scope of work, projects, leadership, etc. 
- Highlight the results
- Go beyond the results and provide further context of the situation and/or challenge

#3 Proofread, edit, and revise your document ensuring there are no spelling or grammatical errors

#4 Save and submit your document in PDF format

*** REMINDER ***
100+ candidates are applying to the same job as you, so be sure to do everything to separate yourself as a candidate. Your only competition is YOU being a competitive candidate in a competitive market.¬†

TITLE: Applied For a Job?
TEXT:
Applied For a Job? 

Now Do This . . .

Message the Recruiter of the job posting

Send them a short and simple quick note that includes: 

#1 The title of the position that you applied for

#2 Why you are interested in the position and company

#3 Why they should meet with you
This is where you want to highlight your skill-set and expertise which I like to call your ‚Äúsuperpowers‚Äù, as they relate to the position you are applying to

*** BONUS ***
Use this in the Subject Line - "Req ID# and Job Title"
Example: Req 12345 Software Engineer

TITLE: Ghosted After a Job Interview?
TEXT:
Ghosted After a Job Interview? 

Use This Email Template:

Hi ____________ [Name], 

It was with great pleasure interviewing with you. I‚Äôm following up to see if there is any update regarding the ____________ [Job Title] position I recently interviewed for on ____________ [Date].

I‚Äôm still highly interested about the opportunity to join ____________ [Company] and would love to talk more about it soon. 

Kind regards, 

____________ [Your Name]

Please remember these 3 core factors before sending a follow-up email: 

#1 The Waiting Period

If they provided you with a specific timeline on when to expect to hear back, please don‚Äôt try to expedite the process. If they say 1 week, then wait for 1 week and a few days before following up. 

If a timeline was not provided, please give about 5 business days before following up. 

#2 You Need a Strong Subject Line

Utilize the best subject line that will be recognized quickly and be opened. 

Simply respond to the last email you received from them or the interview invitation. 

#3 The Body of Your Email Should Be Short and Simple

Consider that everyone is busy, so you want to ensure that you are clear about why you are reaching out.¬†

TITLE: Your Resume Was Rejected
TEXT:
Your Resume Was Rejected
¬†
3 Common Reasons Why & How to Fix It
¬†
#1 You Didn‚Äôt Tailor Your Resume
Recruiters and hiring managers do keyword searches to figure out if a candidate has the experience and expertise they are seeking in a candidate. 
¬†
Review the job description, find the most important or frequent used words/phrases and implement them into your resume. (Do Not Overdo It!)
¬†
#2 You Didn‚Äôt Quantify Your Successors
Instead of saying you are great at you job, show it. 
¬†
Avoid cliches, utilize action verbs and show metrics and results
¬†
#3 Oversaturated Market
Create meaningful and personal connections through networking. A reference won‚Äôt get you the job, but it will get you in the door. Reach out to recruiters and hiring managers to connect.¬†

TITLE: 10 Steps, to get you closer to an INTERVIEW:
TEXT:
10 Steps, to get you closer to an INTERVIEW:
 
1. A Deep Research the role and the company

2. Check company financials, SWOT analysis if available

3. Check LinkedIn Profile of interviewer / Company. Check about their recent orders

4. Keep your LinkedIn profile and Resume updated as per your target job ‚Äì ensure you make yourself a competitive candidate

5. Put your skills as required by job

6. Practice your domain and competency-based interview questions

7. Prepare questions that you wish to ask for company

8. Test audio and camera for phone and video interviews

9. Practice role-play with family member or friend

10. Welcome to a NEW JOB

If you are well prepared, there is no reason of failing.

Avoid the last-minute rush, unless invited to interview at short notice!

Nervousness is inevitable, don't think too much about it.

An interview is a two-way conversation; not an interrogation room.

TITLE: This is NOT Healthy
TEXT:
This is NOT Healthy

Micromanagement in the workplace is the worst thing that you can do to a team. 

If you did not know, then please understand; micromanagement shows a lack of freedom, trust, and better yet lack of respect for your employee‚Äôs skillset. 

If you are not empowering your team to go above and beyond their capabilities, then you need to part ways with this nonsense of a toxic leadership style because it cripples your employee‚Äôs and teams‚Äô success. 

If you want to destroy team culture, then keep it up (sarcasm) but you are considered not the right leader for this team because you will be looked upon as the villain. 

Here are a few tips to fix ASAP: 
1.¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†Articulate expectations AND support your team
2.¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†Empower your employee‚Äôs
3.¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†Focus on feedback and not playing the blame game
4.¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†Create a culture of innovation
5.¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†Set aside the ‚ÄúI‚Äù and focus on the ‚ÄúWE‚Äù
6.¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†Put them FIRST and yourself LAST

TITLE: HIRING MANAGERS & RECRUITERS
TEXT:
HIRING MANAGERS & RECRUITERS

Grover Stewart, formerly the Assistant Director of Human Resources for Four Seasons Hotels & Resorts. Responsible for the strategic direction, vision, growth, and performance of Four Seasons flagship brand. 

As a seasoned professional with 7 years of Senior and Executive Leadership experience, Grover is known for driving performance, maximizing operational excellence, and executing recruiting and retention plans. 

Before joining Four Seasons Hotels & Resorts, Grover served as Human Resources Manager at Clean Uniform, where he led operations, sales, marketing, and managed the company‚Äôs growth and development pipeline. Grover was responsible for the company‚Äôs largest achievement of reducing attrition by 85% and increasing headcount and productivity by 80%.  

Grover holds a Bachelor of Science in Business Administration from Lindenwood University, specializing in Human Resources Management. He is based in the Greater Chicago area. 

Grover is seeking out his next opportunity to leverage his skillset while executing all operational missions/goals. If you have any available or know of any opportunities, please contact Mr. Stewart as he will be an invaluable asset to any company/team.

TITLE: Things to do to get your resume onto the ‚ÄúYES‚Äù pile
TEXT:
Things to do to get your resume onto the ‚ÄúYES‚Äù pile
 
üî• A Professional Summary Not an Objective üî•
 
Objectives are irrelevant in today‚Äôs resumes and if you‚Äôre still using one, stop, do not pass go, and do not collect $200. Your objective is to find a job, but your professional summary should resonate like the preview to the main feature in the movies. Enticing and alluring. 

Creating a professional summary about you includes some of your key character traits with additional keywords that match the job description. Attract the reader with some of your biggest and proudest moments in your career that make the reader want to continue reading on and continue learning more. 

Avoid using dull, repetitive, and overused language that fails to provide examples in your resume. Instead of referring to yourself as ‚Äúresults-driven,‚Äù don‚Äôt cut corners on the proof of those results you drove. 

A resume without numbers is going to fall short of the proof necessary. Be prepared to back up your professional summary with the necessary examples in your professional experience section beyond just your job responsibilities.
 
üí• EXTRA EXTRA: When trying to quantify results in your resume, begin to think of your skills in measurement format. If you cut costs, by how much, and how did you do this? If you drove new products, programs, or processes, explain how you did it, when you did it, and then what outcome occurred. Your job hunt hinges on being able to show results.
 
Please feel free to DM me!

TITLE: ‚ÄúWhen a high performer determines that a situation is unworkable, rather then role up their sleeves and power through, they move on.‚Äù
TEXT:
‚ÄúWhen a high performer determines that a situation is unworkable, rather then role up their sleeves and power through, they move on.‚Äù

That was the advice a friend gave me when I was stuck in an unworkable situation.

It was supposed to be a breakthrough role for me with a big increase in pay.

But the team‚Äôs problems were endless. The engineering team supporting us was toxic and bullying.

The data infrastructure was a crumbling dessicated husk.

The company was operationally inept (I lost database access for 2 weeks over a straightforward issue because IT was so understaffed it took them 3 days to respond to any of my messages).

I wanted it to work, but most of the problems were political or completely beyond the scope of my role to fix.

So I left.

3 out of the 4 members of the team did the same within a month of my departure.

Hard work is no guarantee of success. Espousing hard work feels wise, and like it‚Äôs something you can control.

You have less control over where you focus your efforts, but some of us have some. 

Where you focus is the fulcrum of your hard work lever, and it‚Äôs a virtuous cycle:

The more experience you get at moving the fulcrum to where it will have maximum impact, the more freedom you get to direct your efforts 

At the same time, acknowledge that how much we can move the fulcrum is not something we have much control over, especially in the early stages of our lives, and to practice empathy for those who do not have the same freedom.

How do you direct your focus for maximum effect on the life you want?

#dataengineering # #work #success
