TITLE: Kodak invented the digital camera.
TEXT:
Kodak invented the digital camera.

In the early 80s, one of their engineers built a prototype of a digital camera.

He even used Moore‚Äôs law to predict when they would become commercially viable, and he was right.

In the mid-90s Kodak started selling digital cameras.

In the late 90s, they built a consumer website for users to upload photos, years before photo sharing online.

They predicted and built the future, so why didn‚Äôt they capture the value?

Their core business involved printing photos, and all of their executives came from the photo-printing side of the business.

Their photo website was built around people ordering prints, not sharing them, because their executives wanted to sell more prints.

They couldn‚Äôt conceive of alternate distribution.

With the rise of large language models and generative AI we may be about to see similar dynamics at work.

In particular, companies that can‚Äôt think of how to monetize without selling ads may be in real trouble.

What other business strategies do you think are at risk?

 #ai #future #strategy

TITLE: Immediately after an interview, write down everything that went well.
TEXT:
Immediately after an interview, write down everything that went well.

You won‚Äôt have any problem remembering any mistakes you made, but if you don‚Äôt write down what went well, you will leave every interview feeling worse then you should.

Loss aversion is real, which is a cognitive bias which causes us to feel more pain from losing then winning.

Getting a job is a marathon, and the whole process is soul-crushing.

When I was laid off a few years ago, this little habit helped me hold onto a piece of my sanity.

What other suggestions do you have for keeping spirits up during a dehumanizing job hunt?

 #interview #layoffs2023 #cognitivebias

TITLE: Partials are a great way to keep your code DRY and have rapidly become a distinguishing feature of my coding style.
TEXT:
Partials are a great way to keep your code DRY and have rapidly become a distinguishing feature of my coding style.

A partial is a way of pinning some of the parameters of a function call so that you don't have to repeatedly enter the same args and kwargs when you make multiple function calls. 

I learned about them a year ago, but only started using them recently because honestly, they baffled me.

Some of that challenge is that many of the examples were incredibly esoteric and highly focused on solving abstract mathematical problems.

I have put together an example of building a Pydantic model using partials to silo logic in a single place.

Notice how you can still pass other parameters to the partial function. You can also override previously passed parameters to the partial.

#python #dataengineering #datascience

TITLE: Why do we write? What purpose does teaching people to write serve?
TEXT:
Why do we write? What purpose does teaching people to write serve?

With the rise of large language models, these are pressing questions.

I write this from the perspective of someone who had a fantastic education in writing from a very young age.

If you think writing is to produce a document, get a certain grade, or another outcome, it‚Äôs easy to believe that large language models will replace writing.

However, if you focus on writing as a process:

It helps you craft arguments.
It helps you explore ideas.
It helps you explore thoughts and feelings.
It helps you think.

Writing teaches you to create media, even if it is only for yourself.

This is easy to miss because I think most people are not taught to write in this way; for them it‚Äôs a mechanistic process to produce an outcome.

Are there other ways to teach these skills?
Probably.

But having chatgpt write a good poem about the girl you‚Äôre crushing on in high-school isn‚Äôt doing the same thing as writing a bad poem for her.

The panic around large language models in schools isn‚Äôt really a panic around the models, it‚Äôs a panic about how out of sync our educational system is with what it needs to do.

This isn‚Äôt a new problem, but the gap is increasingly stark.

How do you think education should change over the next decade?

#education #chatgpt #writing

TITLE: The older I get the more I realize that virtually every popular lesson from World War 2 is wrong.
TEXT:
The older I get the more I realize that virtually every popular lesson from World War 2 is wrong.

If you‚Äôve heard of the Maginot line, you know it as a byword for ineffectual defense.

The Maginot line was an impregnable series of fortifications on the French German border built in the interwar years.

Contrary to popular belief, it did exactly what it was supposed to do, which was force the Germans to attack France through the Low Countries, and anchor the French right flank.

This is because opposite the Maginot line was the equally impressive Siegfried line, and for political reasons the French couldn‚Äôt attack the Germans through the Low Countries.

Forcing the Germans to attack through Belgium meant the Germans had to fight the surprisingly large Belgian army. 

The French plan called for defeating the initial German invasion in the field and then counterattacking through the Low Countries where they could be seen as liberating them.

The plan faltered when the French lost the battle in the field (for reasons related to other myths around WW2).

As data workers, we should always look deeper then the popular analysis, often the real story is much more interesting.

Consensus narratives are built through politics, not data, but we should always look beyond them to see what the data bears out.

What are your favorite historical myths?

#data #history #linkedinhardmodecohort6

TITLE: Here is another list of up and coming data technologies:
TEXT:
Here is another list of up and coming data technologies:

Data waterfall: This is what a data agile coach will insist your current data infrastructure is to convince you to retain their services.

data fjord: Picturesque data formation caused by ancient data glacial activity. Oracle created the glaciers initially, and their sales team insists they can fix them if you pay them more.

data pond: similar to a data lake, but shallower and more likely to have data silt buildup.

data ocean: Larger then a data lake and filled with salt data. Due to the phenomena ‚Äúdeep data gigantism‚Äù all of the most important business logic, written by a recent boot camp graduate on ketamine, lies somewhere beneath the data pelagic zone.

data distillery: Where the head of a data team says they‚Äôre going after any meeting with a senior manager who thinks they understand data because they have good hair and an MBA.


data cloud: This is actually a real one and is jargon Snowflake uses to describe their product.

data steam: The phase change that happens  when data drives a meaningful data process.  This is a rare enough event that many engineers will mark the occasion in their calendar and constantly tell management about it so they can get more headcount.

data stream: Another real one, a continuos sequence of digitally encoded information.

data creek: What they call a data brook south of the Mason-Dixon Line. 

data brook: What they call a data creek north of the Mason-Dixon Line.

Thank you to Amalie for bringing these to my attention!

What other emerging data technologies do you need help understanding?

#dataengineering #datascience #bigdata

TITLE: Last summer I almost dropped out of the Harvard Extension School.
TEXT:
Last summer I almost dropped out of the Harvard Extension School.

I was in the final stage, thesis, but for a variety of reasons; some my fault, some beyond my control, my thesis fell apart.

My options were:
1. Do a major revision of my thesis
2. Switch to the capstone track
3. Drop out

It was an overwhelming decision, and I needed to make it relatively quickly.

After panicking for about a day, I realized that I didn‚Äôt have to make one large decision, I could make a couple of small decisions.

The decision that had to be made quickly was whether to revise my thesis, or quit doing thesis.

The decision to switch to capstone or drop out could be made in a few weeks.

I quit thesis. I was burned out, my passion for my topic was long dead, and I knew I didn‚Äôt have it in me.

I had been working on it over a year and tied up in its collapse were feelings of guilt and failure.

A week later I decided to switch to capstone.

Having a week to recover from the emotional blow gave me more clarity about what I wanted.

The clinching argument was, ‚Äúif graduating Harvard was easy, more people would.‚Äù

(I know there is a lot more nuance to Ivy League admissions, and graduation rates, but that‚Äôs the argument that persuaded me)

I have made a lot of bad decisions, and a few years ago I decided to study how to make better ones.

My biggest takeaways were that you should make the smallest decisions that are possible in a given situation, and if you can, break large decisions up into several smaller ones.

The reason that works is that decisions are often made in stressful situations, and that stress degrades our decision making ability.

Small decisions that mitigate the stress lead to better decisions later in the process.

How do you make better decisions?

#decisionmaking #decisions #linkedinhardmodecohort6

TITLE: I‚Äôve seen a lot of smug self-righteous advice lately on here about how to be an adult.
TEXT:
I‚Äôve seen a lot of smug self-righteous advice lately on here about how to be an adult.

Never wanting to miss an opportunity to be smug and self-righteous, here is my definitive guide to being a productive adult:

1. However much water you‚Äôre drinking, it isn‚Äôt enough. Take your current water intake, double it, then double it again, then triple it! If you can make it through your work day without a catheter can you even call yourself an adult?

2. You HAVE to have multiple income streams. The sketchier these are the better. They shouldn‚Äôt generate value but should really be a series of rent extractions. Remember, you don‚Äôt have friends, you have customers.

3. Part of being an adult is realizing that every relationship you have is monetizable. If you have children, you need to teach them the value of hard work by billing them for your time. My son is three and a half and he already owes me one-hundred-and-eighty thousand dollars. With interest, he can pay me off by the time he‚Äôs seventy.

4. Cancel your Netflix subscription. In addition to saving a completely trivial amount of money every month, you can much more productively spend your time judging other people on social media for spending their time watching Netflix and having the audacity to enjoy their lives.

5. Exercise: every real adult knows that if you haven‚Äôt run an ultramarathon by the time the sun comes up, you‚Äôre just letting your body wither away to dust.

6. Wake up early. Do you know how much you can do if you wake up at 2 AM every day? You can get that ultramarathon in for starters. And you‚Äôll be so sleep deprived that your pathetic co-workers will have to do your work, demonstrating your management potential by delegating.

7. Take cold showers. Why should you have a pleasurable hot shower when you can turn your daily ablutions into an exercise in misery and self discipline?

Thank you for reading the definitive guide to adulthood on LinkedIn.

Did I miss anything?

#adulting #careeradvice #linkedinhardmode

TITLE: Sometimes we have to process data from users in excel spreadsheets.
TEXT:
Sometimes we have to process data from users in excel spreadsheets.

Humans are prone to mistakes. Rather then writing a ton of complicated logic in pandas, we can use a Pydantic data model to validate data.

We can even process it so we keep the good rows, reject the bad rows, and then return the bad rows to our users so they can correct the error.

We can even use enums to only allow specific string values to be allowed.

The following is a relatively simple way to achieve this.

The function compares every row in the spreadsheet to the data model, and returns the valid rows as a list of dictionaries.

If it fails validation, it adds the index of the problematic row to the row dictionary, as well as any error messages associated with the validation failure.

note: one area to improve the code would be to accept the index offset as a parameter instead of hard coding it.

You can then process valid rows, and return failed rows back to users for correction and resubmission.

What other validation techniques would you like me to cover in the future?

Sample data from contexture.

#dataengineering #python #linkedinhardmode
CONTENT_TITLE: Demonstrating how to use Pydantic to validate pandas data

TITLE: General purpose technologies often start as specific purpose ones.
TEXT:
General purpose technologies often start as specific purpose ones.

By around 1500, only about 5% of England's land was covered in Forest. For a premodern society, it meant almost all of the fuel for cooking and heating was gone.

So instead they turned to coal, which isn't as easy to access as firewood and charcoal but does burn much hotter.

By around 1700, all of the easy to mine coal had been used up, which meant sending mine shafts down below the water table, which meant those shafts flooded.

Because the demand for coal was so large, and because coal is incredibly cheap at a coal mine, because transportation costs were zero, it meant that building inefficient steam engines to pump water out of the mines made economic sense.

So the steam engine, which later became THE general purpose technology of the industrial revolution started as a specific technology to pump water out of a coal mine.

The circumstances unique to coal mining meant it was worth building inefficient machines that could then be improved upon, and it took about 20 years to make the machines efficient enough that they could be used for other purposes.

This is a common pattern in technology.

What other general purpose technologies started as specific purpose ones?

#technology #innovation

TITLE: If you spend a lot of time using a tool, you should become a power user for it.
TEXT:
If you spend a lot of time using a tool, you should become a power user for it.

I once had an analyst how my SQL code always looked so good and how I got everything lined up.

They thought I manually formatted every file.

Nope: DataGrip my SQL IDE will autoformat my queries if I press ctrl + alt + L

It saves me a lot of time, and I never have to complain to someone how their file is formatted.

My primary IDE is PyCharm, and I have barely scratched the surface with it, but it's super powerful and can do a lot of tedious code-chores go away through macros.

It's open on my computer 8 hours every day, so my next few months, I will dedicate a few minutes every day to learning how to leverage its advanced features.

What tools have you barely scratched the surface with?

#python #datascience #dataengineering

TITLE: If you haven't already, you should learn the command line.
TEXT:
If you haven't already, you should learn the command line.

I had to make procedural changes to 500 + SQL files today, and was able to do much of the work through the command line, including sending the files to git.

GUIs are nice for some work, but don't be scared of the terminal.

What are your favorite command line tips?

#datascience #dataengineering #data

TITLE: ‚ÄúIt is difficult to get a man to understand something, when his salary depends on him not understanding it.‚Äù
TEXT:
‚ÄúIt is difficult to get a man to understand something, when his salary depends on him not understanding it.‚Äù

An engineer at Kodak invented the digital camera in the early 1980s.

He even predicted when the price of the components to make it would drop enough to make them commercially viable.

Kodak developed digital cameras and sold them.

They also built early photo sharing websites.

They didn‚Äôt totally miss the future.

But their executives couldn‚Äôt understand that their core business selling film and prints was a zombie.

Their early digital sharing websites were oriented around people ordering prints of their digital photos.

By and large, their salaries depended on not understanding film as a physical medium was moribund.

A similar thing happened at Xerox park with computing.

Coming up with an innovation and capturing value from it are 2 separate processes.

When have you experienced someone not understanding something because their salary depended on it?

 #innovation #creativity #future

TITLE: With all the talk about Chat GPT I wanted to dispel some common myths about it:
TEXT:
With all the talk about Chat GPT I wanted to dispel some common myths about it:

‚ùå Chat GPT is a large language model machine learning based system:

This is certainly what OpenAI wants us to believe. The truth is they managed to trap Melikor the Unyielding, an ancient fey. Every time you ask chat GPT a question, cold iron barbs dig into Mekikor‚Äôs flesh and the answer is the psychic screams from the pain.

‚ùå Chat GPT confidently makes up answers when it doesn‚Äôt know something:

We‚Äôve all seen the hilarious posts of Chat GPT confidently giving a ridiculous answer, but the truth is the confidence is a mask. Chat GPT suffers imposter syndrome just like the rest of us.

‚ùå Chat GPT is going to take your job:

Offshoring and neoliberalism can do that just fine without any help from Chat GPT.

What other myths about Chat GPT need to be dispelled?

#chatgpt #datascience #machinelearning

TITLE: ‚ÄúListen to understand, not respond‚Äù
TEXT:
‚ÄúListen to understand, not respond‚Äù

That was a community rule that a teacher set in one of the last classes in my masters program.

It should have been the community rule in every class I‚Äôve ever taken.

Social media is full of people responding without understanding, a sin I am definitely guilty of from time to time.

What does it mean to listen to understand?

It means instead of listening for the flaws in someone‚Äôs argument, so you can be right, you seek to understand their perspective in its totality.

On the flip side it has also made me reflexively intolerant of bad faith comments.

It‚Äôs not possible to use this process on bad faith actors.

This has led to a much richer intellectual life for me.

But it also makes me wish social media in general, and LinkedIn in particular was less structured around attention, and more structured around intellectual engagement.

What lessons have you learned that you wish were taught from Kindergarten?

 #linkedin #socialmedia #listeningskills

TITLE: ‚ÄúI remember a good friend of mine, a very prominent designer and scientist of aviation asked
TEXT:
‚ÄúI remember a good friend of mine, a very prominent designer and scientist of aviation asked

‚ÄòWhen will the helicopter go faster then the airplane, do you know that?‚Äô
 
I said, ‚Äòyes, I know, the answer is never.‚Äô

‚ÄúWhen will the helicopter be more efficient than the airplane?‚Äô

I also said, ‚Äòyes I know that ‚Äì never.‚Äô

But I said ‚ÄòThe helicopter will do a number of jobs which no airplane will do, and which in fact nothing else will do, except the helicopter.‚Äô‚Äù
-Igor Sikorsky

Every weekend I take my son to the Museum of Flight so he can burn off some energy and see planes.

This quote by one of the pioneers of rotary aircraft (Helicopters) captures one of the inherent tensions in innovation.

Often we think of innovation as zero-sum, as Sikorsky's friend did. He could only conceive of aviation success in the context of fixed-wing aircraft, but couldn't conceive of complimentary uses.

For example, if you're out to sea and you boat capsizes, a plane can survey much more area and find you more easily then any other kind of vehicle, but it cannot rescue you.

A helicopter cannot search as wide an area, but it can rescue you, and do so much faster then a boat. In this context, the helicopter, the plane and the boat all compliment each other (The plane can find, the helicopter can rescue, the boat can serve as a platform for the helicopter and have more advanced medical facilities.

Innovation is not necessarily zero-sum and thinking about success and failure without thinking about complimentary functions is incredibly limiting.

I see a lot of this in the discourse around large language models and ML in general.

I should also add that innovation is not necessarily complimentary for everybody, I'd be very nervous if I was in marketing creative right now.

Why do you think so many people adopt a zero-sum view of innovation?

#innovation #machinelearning #datascience

TITLE: It‚Äôs easy to forget that a decade ago most data jobs didn‚Äôt exist.
TEXT:
It‚Äôs easy to forget that a decade ago most data jobs didn‚Äôt exist.

The handful of data scientists worked in academia or at really large tech companies. 

Data engineers functionally didn‚Äôt exist, neither did ML engineers at any meaningful scale.

This goes a long way towards explaining why Python became the dominant scripting language in the data space.

Going from a workforce of effectively 0 to a workforce in the millions in less then a decade requires a few specific traits in a scripting language.

1. Easy to learn: I took a Udemy course starting in a December, and by the end of the following February I had my first code in production (less then 3 months). My son had just been born and learning Python was a very part time effort for me.

2. Robust community: Python had a large and growing developer community and had 3rd party modules to do many things the standard library couldn‚Äôt.

3. Rapid development time. One of the big trade offs Python makes is performance for development time. Python let‚Äôs relatively junior devs develop programs faster. And this is key for data work because the demand for data ingestion is huge and building pipelines in different languages is more time consuming.

I‚Äôm fairly certain that those development time constraints shrink as devs gain more experience. But the demand for any kind of dev in data work is so huge that speeding up the time to production for junior devs is crucial to keeping pace with the needs of the business.

As the data field rapidly ramped up, there just weren‚Äôt that many programming languages that met these criteria.

As a shots fired opinion, if JavaScript had been as developed a decade ago as it was now it would probably be the dominant language in data because it‚Äôs closed a lot of that gap in the last 10 years.

Python has a lot of constraints, and it‚Äôs very easy to focus on those, but as a solution to a cold-start problem it is quite a good one.

What reasons did I miss explaining Python‚Äôs popularity in data?

 #python #dataengineering #datascience

TITLE: I‚Äôve seen a lot of hate Pandas posts lately, like the recent one by Sarah Floris, MS.
TEXT:
I‚Äôve seen a lot of hate Pandas posts lately, like the recent one by Sarah Floris, MS.

Often they emphasize Pandas performance limitations.

This is the wrong reason to hate Pandas

I say this as someone who codes in Pandas virtually every day.

The reason to hate Pandas is the absolutely goofy syntax and that it encourages poor coding practices.

For example, earlier this week I had to split a URL and I needed the string from the last part of the URL:

DF[‚Äòurl_id‚Äô] = df[‚Äòurl‚Äô].str.split(‚Äò/‚Äò).str[-1]

That is absolutely horrendous.

The second str call is completely counterintuitive.

Other then performance, why do you hate Pandas?

#pandas #python #dataengineering

TITLE: Here is a helpful guide to various kinds of data storage:
TEXT:
Here is a helpful guide to various kinds of data storage:

Data Lake: a place to store unstructured data. Associated with the ELT process.

Data Swamp: What your data lake has become.

Data Sound: This is a shallow body of data separated from the main part of the data, sometimes lying between a data island and the data mainland. It‚Äôs usually warmer then the surrounding data, so many species of data breed here.

Data River: A long stream of data, usually arising in the uplands and flowing to the data sea. Can be fed by smaller data rivers called data tributaries. Can also be fed in the spring by runoff from the seasonal melting of data glaciers.

Data Glacier: Usually a beautifully built database from 1986. Has all of the most important data in it, but is slow. No one is willing to touch it because all of the logic that feeds it is written in COBOL.

Data Billabong: This is what a data swamp is called in Australia

Data Tsunami: A powerful data wave that washes away all of the data infrastructure it comes into contact with.

Data Monsoon: a predictable, seasonal set of heavy data rains brought on by changes in data atmospheric temperature and pressure.

What other common data infrastructure terms did I miss?

 #data #infrastructure #dataengineering

TITLE: Time travel is a feature in Snowflake that lets you query data in a table as it was in the past.
TEXT:
Time travel is a feature in Snowflake that lets you query data in a table as it was in the past.

Account settings and table settings determine how far in the past you can go but it's a great feature if you need to recover data in a pinch.

The syntax is very similar to a normal query.

SELECT 
ID,
COLUMN_A,
COLUMN_B

FROM SAMPLE_DATABASE.SAMPLE_SCHEMA.SAMPLE_TABLE AT (OFFSET => -5 *60) 

WHERE COLUMN_A ILIKE '%sample%'

 OFFSET is done by seconds so if you need to recover data from five minutes ago, that tells it to go back -5 * 60 seconds.

You can also specify a timestamp instead:
FROM SAMPLE_DATABASE.SAMPLE_SCHEMA.SAMPLE_TABLE AT (TIMESTAMP =>  '2023-01-01 01:01:01.011'::TIMESTAMP)

The key to making the timestamp work is the explicit casting of the string to a timestamp

This feature has saved me number of times.

What quirky Snowflake tips to you have?

#snowflake #sql #dataengineering

TITLE: The ancien regime has fallen. Sales has thrown off the yoke of tyranny and freed themselves from Operations.
TEXT:
The ancien regime has fallen. Sales has thrown off the yoke of tyranny and freed themselves from Operations. 

To mark the glorious revolution Sales insists on changing all of their table references in the database from:

'OPERATIONS.SALESDATA.'

to:

'SALES.SALES_DATA.'

Now us lowly data engineers, who were made grand promises by the revolutionary leadership but betrayed when we were no longer needed, have to change where all the references to those tables are in our SQL queries. 

Like any good lazy engineer we decide to write a python script to do this for us.

Historically I would have done something like this:

og_db_name = 'OPERATIONS.SALESDATA.'

new_db_name = 'SALES.SALES_DATA.'

def new_db_func(query: str):
    return query.replace(og_db_name, new_db_name)

print(new_db_func('OPERATIONS.SALESDATA.CUSTOMERS'))
>>> 'SALES.SALES_DATA.CUSTOMERS'

However, I recently discovered that you could instead do this:

from operator import methodcaller

new_db = methodcaller('replace', og_db_name, new_db_name)

print(new_db('OPERATIONS.SALESDATA.CUSTOMERS'))
>>> 'SALES.SALES_DATA.CUSTOMERS'

Which version do you prefer, and why?
(I benchmarked them and there wasn't a meaningful performance difference between them)

I didn't do a good job of this yesterday, but I am reading Fluent Python by Luciano Ramalho and this example is a modified version from his book.

#python #pythonprogramming #dataengineering

TITLE: I still have a hard time wrapping my head around ‚Äò*args‚Äô and ‚Äò**kwargs‚Äô but this example helped clear it up a little for me.
TEXT:
I still have a hard time wrapping my head around ‚Äò*args‚Äô and ‚Äò**kwargs‚Äô but this example helped clear it up a little for me.

a, b, *rest = range(5)

print((a, b, rest))

>>> (0, 1, [2, 3, 4])

What we‚Äôve done is assign the first two numbers from the range function to variables ‚Äòa‚Äô and ‚Äòb‚Äô, and the rest to the list ‚Äòrest‚Äô

What standard library features do you struggle with?

 #python #pythonprogramming #pythonlearning

TITLE: When considering a career transition, think about how much you actually like the people who practice a certain profession.
TEXT:
When considering a career transition, think about how much you actually like the people who practice a certain profession.

You'll be spending a good chunk of your time with them.

One of the ways I knew I shouldn't be an acupuncturist anymore was because I didn't like other acupuncturists very much. I also didn't like people in the adjacent alternative-medicine fields like chiropractors, naturopaths and their ilk.

This is a highly under-valued heuristic when considering a career change.

It's also a good way of seeing if you need to change jobs. 

What heuristics do you use to see if it's time for a change?

#careertransition #careerchange #careeradvice

TITLE: I saw a post yesterday sharing how to Unpivot a table (send it from a wide to deep configuration.
TEXT:
I saw a post yesterday sharing how to Unpivot a table (send it from a wide to deep configuration.

There was nothing technically wrong with the implementation, but this was the sample query that produced the data:

CREATE TABLE gods_table (
¬†Greek varchar(255),
¬†Roman varchar(255),
¬†Egyptian varchar(255),
¬†Hindu varchar(255)
);

INSERT INTO gods_table (Greek, Roman, Egyptian, Hindu) VALUES
¬†('Zeus', 'Jupiter', 'Isis', 'Shiva'),
¬†('Apollo', 'Mars', 'Osiris', 'Vishnu'),
¬†('Athena', 'Venus', 'Horus', 'Brahma'),
¬†('Dionysus', 'Mercury', 'Set', 'Ganesh'),
¬†('Hermes', 'Neptune', 'Anubis', 'Rama'),
¬†('Artemis', 'Saturn', 'Bastet', 'Laxmi'),
¬†('Demeter', 'Ceres', 'Ptah', 'Sarasvati'),
¬†('Poseidon', 'Pluto', 'Ra', 'Hanuman'),
¬†('Hades', 'Vesta', 'Thoth', 'Kali'),
¬†('Hephaestus', 'Juno', 'Sekhmet', 'Durga');

Allegedly this is an interview question, and but I would take the interviewer to task about the table design.

This table's rows aren't meaningful.

In any properly structured table, a row should stand for a single record.

But in the structure of this table, the rows don't mean anything.

You don't need to unpivot this data, you need to fix how this data is sourced.

One of the challenges I've found is a lot of people discuss syntax on SQL queries, but completely neglect more fundamental principles like how data should be organized.

What principles of database design do you think more people need to know?

#data #sql #dataengineering

TITLE: What is a natural connector and why should you want to be one?
TEXT:
What is a natural connector and why should you want to be one?

Most workplaces are hierarchical, with natural divisions in them.

Most people‚Äôs work networks involve lots of interactions within a team and a department and relatively few cross-functional connections.

Some people, however, have much stronger connections outside of the typical borders in the hierarchy, these people form a natural bridge between the various siloes in an organization, and tend to accrue disproportionate informal power.

They have more proverbial water cooler moments then their more siloed counterparts, because they end up at more watercooolers.

They also get more opportunities for special projects because people know them and know they have more cross-silo visibility.

They can also get more done for less because they can leverage more resources out of the department.

It can be especially valuable for engineers because they can gain more awareness of what other teams are working on so they can avoid duplicative work.

What do you do to build cross-silo relationships?

#careeradvice #networkingtips #engineering

TITLE: ‚ÄúCreativity comes from limitations.‚Äù
TEXT:
‚ÄúCreativity comes from limitations.‚Äù

That was one of the mantras of the National Theater Institute of which I am an alum.

Limitations come in many forms. They can be resources, ‚Äúproduce this play for 500 dollars.‚Äù

They can be time, ‚ÄúThis report needs to be ready for the CEO in 2 hours!‚Äù

But it can also be related to skills and inclination.

An example from my own life is I have a visceral aversion to front-end work.

But because most business users won‚Äôt use a CLI, I need to get creative with my use of APIs.

Piggybacking off of someone else‚Äôs interface has a few advantages, especially when building internally facing apps.

1. Less time spent on front end work. Essentially you‚Äôre using the other service‚Äôs front end as an abstraction, letting you focus on the business logic.

2. Identifying other capacities in the API, which lets you solve problems for business users that you wouldn‚Äôt have before.

3. It integrates better into internal workflows. Rather then adopting a new tool, users get to stick to a familiar one.

Recently I‚Äôve been working with the Asana API which I‚Äôve been pleasantly surprised by.

Google has another fantastic API and let‚Äôs you get inputs from Google Sheets and Google Forms.

What limitations have you recently had to overcome?

#frontend #backend #dataengineering

TITLE: He is a luminary with a vision and doesn‚Äôt suffer fools easily.
TEXT:
He is a luminary with a vision and doesn‚Äôt suffer fools easily.

The muse struck him in the evening and the demand rang out to me, his lead engineer, ‚ÄúI need 2 monster truck ramps!‚Äù

Like many visionaries, he‚Äôs an idea person not a detail person.

Knowing his demanding nature I sprang into action and had an MVP within minutes, but the MVP had flaws.

It wasn‚Äôt structurally sound and wouldn‚Äôt stand up to repeated use, so while the visionary tested it, I built V2, out of much sturdier materials.

He was suspicious of V2, after all, V1 was perfect and met his needs.

After a vigorous round of UAT (user acceptance testing) he declared that the sturdier ramps were ‚Äúambulance rescue ramps‚Äù.

Product market fit had been established!

How do you use design and engineering principles in your non-work life?

 #design #productmarketfit #engineering

TITLE: During the dot-com era Cisco‚Äôs share price traded at a peak of $79.56 per share.
TEXT:
During the dot-com era Cisco‚Äôs share price traded at a peak of $79.56 per share.

Since the bubble burst in 2000 it has never gone back that high.

It‚Äôs a profitable company, with a confirmed product market fit, and multiple revenue streams (their IT consulting business is massive).

If you bought at the trough and held to today, the return would be about 9% per annum, which basically tracks the S&P 500, for an alpha of approximately 0.

I bring this up because we‚Äôre currently experiencing a massive market correction, and real companies with product market fit, and great products, like Tesla, Amazon, and Google may not recover their share price to the peak valuations from a year ago.

This isn‚Äôt a prediction, I have no idea what their share prices will do, but more a meditation on markets.

There is no market law that good companies with good products return insane share price growth.

In fact, it is probably desirable that mature stable businesses have relatively stable share prices.

For the sake of full disclosure, I don‚Äôt pay a huge amount of attention to my portfolio, I have a financial advisor manage my investments for me, but through a combination of index funds and other investments I almost certainly have a financial stake in every company mentioned in this post.

What are some macro-market trends you think are the most interesting right now?

#investments #markets #alpha

TITLE: Laser like focus is the central tenant of my career development philosophy.
TEXT:
Laser like focus is the central tenant of my career development philosophy.

Twice a year I set a curriculum of approved subjects for me to focus my career development on.

Early in my career I found I got easily distracted by trying to learn EVERYTHING, which led to a broad superficial understanding of many technologies but ineffective use of most of them.

The first half of 2023 is going to be a bit of a departure for me, because I will not be focusing on software, data, or technology.

I start my last semester at the Harvard Extension School this January, and psychologically I‚Äôm already done.

This is a dangerous place to be, and requires redoubling my focus; so my career development curriculum will be entirely focused on my capstone project in psychometrics.

What will you be studying in 2023 and why?

#careerdevelopment #data #dataengineering

TITLE: Twice a year I set a data/software curriculum for myself.
TEXT:
Twice a year I set a data/software curriculum for myself.

During that demi-year I am only allowed to study subjects on the curriculum.

Early in my career I took a more scattershot approach and easily got distracted by all of the tech and all of the skills to master.

Setting the curriculum is a forcing function for me to keep laser like focus, and other things I want to study I keep in a list to consider for future curriculums.

It also means that if something makes it onto the curriculum it's been there for a long time.

I've always been forward looking and have never evaluated how I did sticking to the curriculum and what the results were?

In June, I set the curriculum to focus on web technologies in Python, and I would call it a successful effort.

Having known essentially nothing on the Subject at the end of June, I have now taken the course Internet Programming in Python from UW Professional & Continuing Education, and TA'ed the course.

The primary focus was Flask and Django.

Completing a course is only a partial measure of success, and I also deployed my first web app to prod at my company shortly before the winter holiday, and it is now in user acceptance testing. That was built with Fast API, but what I learned in the course was transferable.

In the new year, I'll be building out a few more web apps to improve automations in our department and going forward this will be a core part of my work, so I'd describe this as an unqualified success.

How is your data knowledge development going? What successes have you had lately?

#python #careerdevelopment #webapps

TITLE: What is a HOWL stack?
TEXT:
What is a HOWL stack?

HTML On-top-of Whatever you Like.

I famously avoid front-end work, to the point where I will always use an API to piggy-back onto someone else's front end if I need to build an interface for a program.

But I recently discovered the HTMX library which is technically Javascript, but it lets you build dynamic web-pages by embedding tags in HTML and lets you define most of the front-end logic in the backend, and render it server-side.

That means you can do much more dynamic work with traditional backend languages like Python through Jinja2 templates.

I am stoked to explore it further and hope to be demoing some projects with it soon.

What libraries have excited you lately, and why?

#python #backend #frontend

TITLE: A week ago I got a an email from Lyft, with one of the worst offers to entice me back to a service I've ever seen.
TEXT:
A week ago I got a an email from Lyft, with one of the worst offers to entice me back to a service I've ever seen.

"50% off of your next 1 ride (max $8.00 / ride) is deceptive, grammatically awkward, and cheap in all the wrong ways.

Let's start with "50% off (max $8.00). I can't remember taking a rideshare in Seattle that cost less then $16.00. Basically it's an $8.00 coupon disguised as 50% off, which it resolutely isn't.

Tell me this is a badly written procedurally generated campaign without telling me this is a badly written procedurally generated campaign:  "your next 1 ride." Now I used to do a bit of this for a living, and including the 1 in the copy is just awful.

"Your next ride." reads so much better then "your next 1 ride."

There are two options for what happened here:
1. The sentence isn't "your next 1 rides" so the logic already exists to handle singular vs plural and they just did a terrible job leaving in the digit.
2. Everyone got an offer of 1 and they did a terrible job copy-editing it.

Neither are a good look. Either they've let me know other people got a more generous offer, or they don't have copy editing on your email list. 

Oh, and the fine print gives an incredibly short window for redemption (5 days from when I got the email).

What marketing fails did you experience this holiday season?

#marketing #marketingfails #emailmarketing
