TITLE: ‚ÄúTired, sore, and dressed like a dinosaur.‚Äù
TEXT:
‚ÄúTired, sore, and dressed like a dinosaur.‚Äù

A friend asked me how I was doing yesterday and that was my answer.

My son and I were supposed to be dinosaurs for Halloween at the company office party, but he got sick and the costume arrived late.

I couldn‚Äôt return it, so instead, several times a week I dress up like a dinosaur named Daddysaur and play with my son.

Fatherhood has been an amazing journey, and one that has made me both more grown up and childish at the same time (it‚Äôs been close to 30 years since I‚Äôve dressed up like a dinosaur).

In fall of 2021, I went into the office for a week, and to my son, my most impressive trait was that I went on a bus.

He doesn‚Äôt care what I do at work, he cares that I dress up as a dinosaur to play with him.

So this Christmas, I am unbelievably grateful to my son, for keeping me young, and reminding me what‚Äôs important.

What keeps you young?

Merry Christmas!

#12daysoftribute #fatherhood #parenting

TITLE: I've worked at a number of companies at various stages, and without a doubt, PitchBook Data is the best place I've worked.
TEXT:
I've worked at a number of companies at various stages, and without a doubt, PitchBook Data is the best place I've worked.

They've given me the flexibility and autonomy to let me work on some problems that I identified, and earlier this week, my first web app is now in production, and we're beta testing it now.

The app lets you input two tables into our database via an Asana form, runs it through an API I created with #fastapi and then returns returns the joins to connect the 2 tables to the Asana task created by the form.

Today I want to thank JG, our CEO for creating such a wonderful office culture, Jake Hujar, for seeing the potential in my lunatic idea and greenlighting the work on it, and all my wonderful coworkers who make it a joy to work there most days.

What madcap idea would you build for your company if they let you?

#12daysoftribute #python #webapp

TITLE: "Risk, fail, risk again" was the motto of the National Theater Institute, of which I am one of their least prestigious alumni.
TEXT:
"Risk, fail, risk again" was the motto of the National Theater Institute, of which I am one of their least prestigious alumni.

In my last year of college, I studied at their semester long intensive.

It was challenging. Classes and workshops ran from 6:30 AM to 9:00 PM Monday-Saturday.

Sundays they let us sleep in, so we only worked from 9:00 - 9:00.

We had 4 days off all Semester.

It was a lifechanging experience, and I met so many of my friends there.

The other thing they taught me is "Creativity comes from limitations."

I was working on debugging a failing schema in a database. It turns out there was an upstream job that was failing managed by another team.

I asked them to look into it and the only answer they had was to throw more cluster resources at it, which unfortunately didn't work.

I often think if as a field we get less creative the more computational power is available to us.

So today I want to extend my gratitude to the NTI to me for teaching me how to flex my creative muscles, even if I'm taking them in a different direction then intended.

Have you seen limitations fuel your own creativity?

#12daysoftribute #creativity #creativeprocess

Photo is from our final project, when I was much younger and angular

TITLE: In late 2016, I dramatically stopped paying attention to the news, and instead replaced my daily reading diet with different sources.
TEXT:
In late 2016, I dramatically stopped paying attention to the news, and instead replaced my daily reading diet with different sources.

I stopped listening to the fivethirtyeight podcast and instead started listening to the HBR podcast (Harvard Business Review).

That introduced me to HBX, the Harvard Business School Online, and I completed their CoRE program in 2017.

That in turn introduced me to the Harvard Extension School, where I started my enrollment in Summer 2018 where I began studying psychology.

I start my last semester next month. It's been a journey to say the least, but the education has been stellar.

So today, I want to express my gratitude to the Harvard Extension School for expanding access to the Harvard experience to learners who don't match the typical path to high prestige institutions.

What school's have missions that particularly resonate with you?

#12daysoftribute #education #harvarduniversity

TITLE: We used to train our dogs for k-9 agility. The teacher was an older woman and always braced herself to argue with me when she corrected my technique.
TEXT:
We used to train our dogs for k-9 agility. The teacher was an older woman and always braced herself to argue with me when she corrected my technique.

Except I never argued with her, because she knew more then me and I was there to learn.

Apparently this is unusual for her male students.

And for that I have to thank my mom.

If the media had known about my mom in the 80s they‚Äôd have never dared dub Margaret Thatcher the Iron Lady because next to my mom, Thatcher looks like a wilting violet.

This is a woman who during a robbery with a knife stuck to her neck commanded the man wielding the blade to stop his associates from attacking her first husband, AND HE DID IT!

That‚Äôs Bene Gesseret levels of power right there.

Thank you Mumz!

#12daysoftribute #gratitude #strongwomen

TITLE: ‚ÄúWhatsoever thy hand findeth to do, do it with thy might.‚Äù
TEXT:
‚ÄúWhatsoever thy hand findeth to do, do it with thy might.‚Äù

That was the motto of my incredibly secular private high school The Masters School.

The education I received there was stellar and honestly, college was a let down after my 6 years at Masters.

It was a school that taught us to live our lives turned up to 11.

One of the big potheads in my class now runs a large cannabis farm; he took being a pothead up to 11.

I take on a lot, and it was there that I learned how to.

I think in 99.9% of schools I would have been relentlessly bullied in high-school. Instead I found acceptance and community there, and still have half a dozen close friends from that time.

So for all that, The Masters School has my deepest gratitude!

Did you have a good experience in high-school?

#12daysoftribute #education #highschool

TITLE: A good teacher can change everything!
TEXT:
A good teacher can change everything!

About a year ago, I met Luis, one of the instructors in the Python Program the UW Professional & Continuing Education.

The instructor in the first class was good, but rather anonymous, which is super easy to do in a self-paced online program.

Luis is a teacher at a totally different level, meeting with me just about every week, and graciously answering my questions (don‚Äôt let him hear you apologize for asking a question because he will make you apologize for apologizing!).

I‚Äôve done a lot of online education and it‚Äôs a very different format then in-class instruction, and Luis is a master of it!

Since then he has grown into my mentor and was a driving force in me becoming an instructional assistant.

So for everything you‚Äôve done for me, you have my sincerist gratitude!

Also, he could win a Pedro Pascal lookalike contest!

What teachers have made a huge difference to your life?

#12daysoftribute #python #mentors

TITLE: A year and a half ago, I realized that to become an engineer I needed to have a more disciplined approach to code.
TEXT:
A year and a half ago, I realized that to become an engineer I needed to have a more disciplined approach to code.

One of the engineers at my company who I deeply respected recommended the Python Certificate Program at UW Professional & Continuing Education.

I enrolled in the self-paced program despite my reticence about the first course.

I thought I already knew 80% of the material in it, so I was mostly taking it to take the second and third courses.

I couldn‚Äôt have been more wrong, in the best way possible.

I can confidently say that the program turned me from an analyst who thrashed out bad pandas code into an engineer who thrashed out mediocre Python code üòâ.

In all seriousness, the program filled in a ton of gaps in my knowledge and taught me how to think about problems more systemically.

So for that UW Professional & Continuing Education has my gratitude (they also hired me as an instructional assistant!).

What programs have made you a better engineer?

 #python #12daysoftribute #engineering

TITLE: Anil, is my first mentor in tech.
TEXT:
Anil, is my first mentor in tech.

We met at the Tombolo Institute at Bellevue College where he was teaching a digital marketing analytics course which got this whole data train moving.

Beyond what he taught in class, he gave great advice, and served as a reference for a number of jobs.

He showed me how to become a public data resource (he was a prominent blogger back in the day), gave me a platform to publish a few articles, and got me a few speaking engagements.

I couldn‚Äôt have asked for a better mentor or friend, and for that he has my deepest gratitude.

#12daysoftribute #data #mentorship

TITLE: When I ran my small clinic I was obsessed with patient experience, which I still think is the weakest part of healthcare.
TEXT:
When I ran my small clinic I was obsessed with patient experience, which I still think is the weakest part of healthcare.

This led me to look at user experience design.

Originally I was looking at masters programs. I found a couple of online programs but I was leery of the price.

They were all in the 40k-50k range, to study a field I didn‚Äôt know I‚Äôd like. 

I also didn‚Äôt know how employable I‚Äôd be afterwards; having a masters degree and no experience didn‚Äôt seem like a great way to manage a career transition.

Luckily a random neuron fired in my head and I thought to see if any local community colleges had a UX program. That way, I could see if I liked it without shelling out 40 grand.


The Tombolo Institute at Bellevue College  had a program which was about 4000 dollars, roughly 10% the cost of a masters.

And it was really good that I did that instead because it turns out I didn‚Äôt like a lot of UX work.

It‚Äôs where I discovered my allergy to front end work.

I do love design thinking and many of the processes of UX, and it still saturates my approach to data.

Discovering that you don‚Äôt want to do something is as valuable as discovering what you love.

Part of that program was a course in digital marketing analytics, which launched my data career.

I got my first job in data (and tech) before I graduated.

I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôve had a better ROI on my education.

This is my long-winded way of saying how grateful I am to the Tombolo Institute at Bellevue College and Bellevue College Continuing Education.

They really did set me up for a career which has brought me so much joy.

#12daysoftribute #ux #careerchange

TITLE: Diana has had a titanic impact on my career (without the iceberg)!
TEXT:
Diana has had a titanic impact on my career (without the iceberg)!

I met her at my first data job and she helped me bridge what I‚Äôd learned about self-promotion when running a business to self-advocacy in my career.

She also taught me how to craft an intentional career trajectory instead of simply following a laid out path.

Lastly she introduced ‚Äú100 percent‚Äù into my lexicon and taught me to use the phrase ‚Äúpersonal brand‚Äù unironically.

I am so grateful to have her as a friend and colleague.

Thank you for all you‚Äôve done for me.

Who had had an outsize impact on your career?

#12daysoftribute #yearend #grateful

TITLE: Help other people grow!
TEXT:
Help other people grow!

The best way to stand out as a data jockey is not data, but mentoring.

Helping other people develop technical skills is an easy way to add a ton of value to an organization.

It doesn‚Äôt even have to be other data people.

Helping PMs, managers, and others grow their abilities has incredible impact both for the org and for your own career, and even if you‚Äôre relatively junior in your career your excel and SQL skills are probably better then non-technical ICs and managers.

Mentoring and teaching has a few effects:

1. It forces you to really know your stuff.

2. It demonstrates to management that you help other people grow. In any reasonably healthy culture this is seen as a good thing.

3. It builds a network of advocates, and if you‚Äôre helping people outside of your team, it builds them across the company or department.

That network of advocates is especially useful when it comes time for promotions. Having a variety of people sing your praises to your manager helps them advocate for you. 

It also doesn‚Äôt have to be super deep in the weeds.

Here are some topics I‚Äôve taught to PMs at my company:

Cloud computing basics: Not how to do cloud computing, but what it‚Äôs for and what the basic services are on AWS.

Practical statistics for outlier detection: z-scores, and normality.

The structure and organization of dimensionally modeled databases: what dimension, fact, and bridge tables do.

What ideas do you have for subjects to teach?

#datascience #dataengineering #careerdevelopment

TITLE: Saying ‚ÄúI‚Äôm a medium deal on LinkedIn‚Äù is a bit like saying ‚ÄúI‚Äôm famous, in Japan.‚Äù
TEXT:
Saying ‚ÄúI‚Äôm a medium deal on LinkedIn‚Äù is a bit like saying ‚ÄúI‚Äôm famous, in Japan.‚Äù

But it is incredibly humbling to be included on such an illustrious list. There are people on this list who are legitimate big deals like Sarah Floris, MS and Zach Wilson.

You should check out the other people on the list, and follow them if you want to learn from people who really know what they‚Äôre doing!

TITLE: Many times a day an engineer faces a choice:
TEXT:
Many times a day an engineer faces a choice:
1. Read the docs
2. Blindly copy from stack-overflow and hope for the best.

I choose 2 depressingly often.

What engineering sins have you committed lately?

#engineering #softwaredevelopment #datascience

TITLE: If you want to get the file sizes of the contents of an S3 bucket you can write a bunch of complex code, or you can use the following command line command:
TEXT:
If you want to get the file sizes of the contents of an S3 bucket you can write a bunch of complex code, or you can use the following command line command:

aws s3 ls s3://mybucket --recursive --human-readable --summarize > file_sizes.txt

You can then easily parse the txt file (I use Pandas).

You can also easily integrate this command into a docker container.

What fun command line tricks do you like to do?

#aws #commandline #s3

TITLE: I wonder if people who studied formal grammar make for better programmers on average then people who didn't?
TEXT:
I wonder if people who studied formal grammar make for better programmers on average then people who didn't?

I've only known one programmer who studied classics and they were total dead weight, but that's a single data point.

The reasoning would be that programming languages follow rigid formal lexical structures, so people who spent a lot of time studying formal grammar would have a lot of related experience.

What do you guys think?

#programming #grammar #softwareengineering

TITLE: When using an acronym or abbreviation you should always make sure you don't accidentally imply something else.
TEXT:
When using an acronym or abbreviation you should always make sure you don't accidentally imply something else.

For example, if you're posting a job instead of listing STD in the benefits section, spell out Short-Term-Disability.

It might be widely known in HR circles that STD means Short-Term-Disability but that's jargon, and while jargon can be helpful when communicating within a group, it can lead to misunderstandings when you're communicating with outsiders.

What funny abbreviations have you seen?

Here in Seattle, we have a train system called South Lake Union Transit:
I'll let you figure out how it's abbreviated.

TITLE: If you‚Äôre looking for some good jams to trance out while coding, google ‚ÄúElectro Swing‚Äù
TEXT:
If you‚Äôre looking for some good jams to trance out while coding, google ‚ÄúElectro Swing‚Äù

You‚Äôre welcome!

What‚Äôs been topping your play lists lately?

 #coding #flowstate #music

TITLE: One of the defining traits of the last 40 years is that the interests of IT professionals (Software engineers and their ilk) were aligned with the investor class.
TEXT:
One of the defining traits of the last 40 years is that the interests of IT professionals (Software engineers and their ilk) were aligned with the investor class.

Engineers were technically labor, but generous equity packages led to high-wages and wealth accumulation; one of the last bastions of plentiful and growing good jobs in an economy reorienting around the service and finance sectors.

I think the investor class has finally turned on IT professionals. 

This is the experiment at Twitter right now, can we run this high traffic site on a skeleton crew of largely H1B engineers working long hours for incredibly limited or no equity?

It‚Äôs seen in the letter TCI (a large institutional investor) sent to Google complaining they‚Äôre overpaying workers.

I don‚Äôt know if this gambit will work, or if it will undermine the current tech giants leading to a more competitive marketplace for IT workers.

What do you think? 

Will IT/Software Engineering still be defined by high wages and good working conditions in 10 years?

 #tech # #economy #finance

TITLE: For Thanksgiving this year, Iam thankful for the city of Seattle.
TEXT:
For Thanksgiving this year, Iam thankful for the city of Seattle.

When I originally looked to transition into tech, I wanted to enter UX.

Initially I looked at masters programs, but I was leery of spending 50 thousand dollars on a field I didn‚Äôt know much about.

In a random flash of insight I checked to see if any local community colleges taught UX, and as fate would have it, 1 had a program from their school of continuing education.

It cost 4 thousand dollars (much less then a masters degree), and introduced me to data.

I didn‚Äôt love UX work, but I loved data, so getting that masters would have been a miserable waste of money.

Seattle also had an abundance of data related jobs, which made my transition into tech relatively easy.

As I progressed in data, I found I wanted to become an engineer, and that‚Äôs how I found the University of Washington‚Äôs School of Professional and Continuing Education, who offer a plethora of classes to help people grow their tech career. 

For all that the internet is supposed to flatten geography, where we live is one of the most important factors when determining our opportunities.

The reason I‚Äôm grateful to Seattle (and Bellevue, and the state of Washington) is the schools I‚Äôve studied tech in are all public, and I love leveraging public resources.

What about your community are you grateful for?

 #community #tech #thanksgiving2022

TITLE: Attention aspiring data scientists:
TEXT:
Attention aspiring data scientists:

‚ùå Data science is not Python

‚ùå Data science is not statistics

‚ùå Data science is not visualization

These are just tools

‚úÖ Data science is a bedeviling alchemy where you transmutate a mediocre statistician and a mediocre programmer into someone who is overpaid to use scikit learn.

In short a data scientist is kind of like a Witcher but instead of fighting monsters they frustrate engineers.

üòâ

What else is a data scientist?

 #datascience #dataengineering #data

TITLE: There is a cult of innovation, especially among technologists who think innovation can solve social problems.
TEXT:
There is a cult of innovation, especially among technologists who think innovation can solve social problems.

Innovation can build tools that can be applied to social problems, but social problems are fundamentally political.

Political in the sense that it requires coordinating collective action.

Crypto is the perfect example of when you try to solve a social problem with technology and without politics.

Crypto arose after 2008 out of the sense that there was something deeply wrong with the financial industry (I don‚Äôt disagree with this sentiment).

The idea was a distributed ledger and decentralized systems would democratize finance and take power away from the finance class.

Looking at crypto through this lens, the last 5 years have been an abject failure.

Enormous centralization with the main use case for it being crime.

The technology is cool, but it didn‚Äôt solve the rapacious greed of the finance industry; it gave them one more tool to exploit.

Technology and innovation is easy. You just need a few smart people and they can make something (getting it adopted is a bit more challenging).

Politics is HARD!

Which is why the technology class wants to focus on innovation.

What are other examples of innovation without politics failing to produce social change?

Or the counter factual, what are some examples of innovation without politics succeeding at producing social change?

 #technology #innovation #change

TITLE: These are common mistakes new data analysts make:
TEXT:
These are common mistakes new data analysts make:

‚ùå: Failing to consult Hologram Tupac Shakur.

‚úÖ: Holgram Tupac will make sure your data presentation has the appropriate level of lyricism and poetry.

‚ùå: Using the wrong type of chalk in the summoning circle to bind the spirit of Milton Friedmen.

‚úÖ: While colored chalk makes the whole ritual pop, the impurities introduced by the pigments radically increase the chance that the bedevelled spirit will break free, possess the body of Rick from Finance, and wreak unspeakable evil on the procurement process.

‚ùå: Expensing payments to local mafiosos for ‚Äúnegotiating‚Äù with labor activists incorrectly.

‚úÖ: These should be expensed as ‚ÄúGeneral Business Consulting, Other.‚Äù

‚ùìWhat are some other common mistakes new analysts make?

TITLE: If you have a friend that consistently makes poor decisions, they have bad judgement.
TEXT:
If you have a friend that consistently makes poor decisions, they have bad judgement.

If 10 million people make the same ‚Äúpoor decision‚Äù there is context you don‚Äôt understand.

Across social media I see this theme that no-one wants to work in trades anymore and ‚Äúlazy millennials and/or gen-Z‚Äù don‚Äôt want to work real jobs.

Here‚Äôs the thing, most of those jobs are skilled labor and require extensive training/education to do. You can‚Äôt just walk up to the job site and get a job as an electrician.

I have a friend who‚Äôs a skilled machinist. He has made parts that go into space. 

He‚Äôs been doing it for about a decade, and he‚Äôs still paying off the loans from his training program. He makes somewhere around 18-20 dollars an hour.

The reason he isn‚Äôt doing better is because Boeing intentionally moved a lot of the jobs to southern states with worse labor protection and lower wages, which sent machinist wages down across the entire region.

The best thing to happen to him financially is that friends from his parents‚Äô church let him live in their basement inexchange for odd jobs around the house.

A friend of mine‚Äôs dad worked at a tarmac factory outside Palm Springs in the early 80s. He would work all night at the factory and then spent his mornings building a house for his wife and son. That job couldn‚Äôt get him a mortgage for the land anymore, let alone the building materials.

I also know a guy who is a general contractor and he does quite well. His main job is home renovations, and he boosts his income by flipping houses with his friends who are also contractors.

To do this, they work a full day as contractors, and then spend their evenings and weekends on the house they‚Äôre flipping, working 70-80 hour weeks. 

Back when I used to treat pain for a living, my core patient base were contractors over 40 living in chronic pain.

These are not easy jobs to have, they are skilled labor, most people who have them are underpaid.

If there are lots of open jobs that no one is willing to take, my first suggestion is to identify why that is.

Odds are you‚Äôll find that they aren‚Äôt very good jobs, for a variety of reasons, but pay is one of them.

People haven‚Äôt changed much, if they have the opportunity to build a life, they will.

What are you doing to build that life?

TITLE: Thank you to everyone that has decided to connect with me for a "15-minute exploratory/networking mini conversation".
TEXT:
Thank you to everyone that has decided to connect with me for a "15-minute exploratory/networking mini conversation". 

I am currently working through messages and connections requests.

I also don't think some of you all understand the meaning behind these conversations so I decided to make a quick video to explain the intentionality when it comes to why I'm doing these calls. 

I would highly recommend watching this video before deciding to connect or sending me a message. ‚ò∫Ô∏è

#recruiter #recruiterlife #blackinhr #blackintech #networking #connections

TITLE: I have some good news for my network.
TEXT:
I have some good news for my network. 

Over the next few weeks I will be having exploratory networking calls with people from my network. These calls will be 15-minutes I want to use this time to get to know you and your background. 

My goal as a recruiter is to create a diverse and relented pipeline for roles that I may work on in the future. 

I am currently not working on any roles at the time but that doesn't mean I can't still recruit.

Look at these 15-minutes conversations as a chance to give a pitch about yourself. Don't look at it as an interview. 

If you are interested in chatting with me, send me a message on here with your resume attached. I will then send you a message back and go over next steps. 

I look forward to connecting! ‚ú®

P.S. If you are sending a request or have sent a request please be patient with me. I'm working through them as we speak. 

#recruiter #recruiterlife #blackintech #networking #connections #linkedin

TITLE: Hi y'all,
TEXT:
Hi y'all, 

My name is Jalonni and that's what I prefer to be called. There is no need to put a Ms. in there because I can't stand how that sounds. I know I look young but please don't call me "hun", or "sweetheart" ESPECIALLY during a professional phone call. 

If we decide to have a coffee chat please remember that even though you feel like you "know" me or we are "online besties" in your head, this is still a professional conversation. 

Lastly, I am a normal person with normal bills that normally get paid. There's no need for you to treat me like I'm something special lol. I like the kind words but I also don't like the feeling that I am above other people or idealized. That's weird to me. At the end of the day, I'm really just a 27-year old trying to figure sh*t out. üòÖ

TITLE: I love how when people decide to set boundaries people get offended and don't see anything wrong when they decide to lash out at that person for setting boundaries.
TEXT:
I love how when people decide to set boundaries people get offended and don't see anything wrong when they decide to lash out at that person for setting boundaries.

I love how I make content SPECIFICALLY for my #jobseeker friends, give back to my community, and have a WHOLE podcast dedicated just for jobseekers but when I make a post that is talking about not having the bandwidth to take 15-minute calls from everyone in my network I am called "insensitive", "emotionless" and I lack empathy. 

I had someone tell me that I don't know what it's like to be unemployed because I have a job. I'm glad you all know my life better than me. I was unemployed when the pandemic first happened and people weren't as active as they are now on LinkedIn. I also was in a life-changing bicycle accident. I could barely walk without being in pain and was going to job interviews AND GETTING GHOSTED. I lived off $700 a month for unemployment so don't ever tell me that I don't understand what it's like to be unemployed. I was jobless for 3 months and in grad school. I took a job that I didn't want to do but it made ends meet. I was in grad school so I could get student loans to pay my rent. I KNOW THE STRUGGLE. 

This LinkedIn is my PERSONAL LinkedIn and I AM NOT obligated to answer messages. If you feel some type of way about me being direct or sharing how I feel then unfollow me. 

But what y'all are not going to do is call me names and be disrespectful. ESPECIALLY during Black History Month. 

That's all.
That's the post.

TITLE: I'm finally using my art degree and creative side in my career and it feels so unreal.
TEXT:
I'm finally using my art degree and creative side in my career and it feels so unreal.

I've been doing a Tour of Duty with Slalom Global Marketing team for a few weeks now and they have allowed me to bring my creative juices to the team. 

I have this passion for Social Media Management, Content Creation, and Marketing that I knew I had but I didn't really tap into it until I started using LinkedIn to create content. 

I'm finally getting paid to do the things that I enjoy & I absolutely love that for me. ‚ú®

 #socialmedia #marketing #contentcreator

TITLE: Y'all ever work for a company that:
TEXT:
Y'all ever work for a company that:

PAYS you your worth
ACKNOWLEDGES your worth
SUPPORTS your growth
SUPPORTS your mental health
ENCOURAGES employees to have a work and life balance 
VALUES you, your ideas, and what you bring to the team
ENCOURAGES you to show up as your authentic-self 
Takes a CHANCE on you

Just me? Bet. 

I wish this on all of my #jobseeker friends that are currently in their search for a new job home. Companies like this do exist out there. Once you find this type of work situation you won't ever take anything less. I hope everybody gets to experience this at least once in their career because it's a beautiful thing. ‚ú®

#blackintech #blackinhr #recruiter #slalomproud

TITLE: I love a good hybrid work situation.
TEXT:
I love a good hybrid work situation. 

By hybrid work situation I mean going into the office once a week and make that day optional. üòÇ

Am I the only one that feels this way? Just me? Got it. üëçüèæ

(This post was meant to be funny. üôÑ)

#workathome

TITLE: All the top companies that I once wanted to work for, interviewed with, and got rejection emails from are now laying off their Talent Acquisition teams.
TEXT:
All the top companies that I once wanted to work for, interviewed with, and got rejection emails from are now laying off their Talent Acquisition teams.

The company I currently work for I had never heard of until I started interviewing for my role. The company I work for now has a history of no lay-offs, is debt-free, and doing everything in its power to make sure its TA team is protected and acknowledged for the work we are doing during these times. 

The moral of the story is to look at those rejections as blessings. That role at that company wasn't meant for you for a reason. You've been praying for stability and a good work/life balance but aren't being patient enough to receive it. I'm a firm believer in quality over quantity. Just because it's a bigger known company doesn't always mean that it's better. 

Remember that. 

#slalomproud

TITLE: One of my connections sent me this yesterday and it put the biggest smile on my face. They sent a message along with the illustration that said "I hope this brings you joy."
TEXT:
One of my connections sent me this yesterday and it put the biggest smile on my face. They sent a message along with the illustration that said "I hope this brings you joy." 

& it honestly did. 

I have such a supportive network and I ‚ô•Ô∏è y'all and appreciate all of the kind words and messages that you all have sent me over the last couple of days.

Today, I challenge you to say something nice to someone that you don't know. You never know what a simple act of kindness can do for someone. ‚ú®

Thank you Michelle Engstrom for making this illustration! ü´∂üèæ

TITLE: Recruiting is extremely hard at the moment. So many people are insensitive to recruiters and they think that we are the ones that make the final decision.
TEXT:
Recruiting is extremely hard at the moment. So many people are insensitive to recruiters and they think that we are the ones that make the final decision. 

AS A RECRUITER, I DON‚ÄôT MAKE THE HIRING DECISION. The HIRING MANAGER makes the hiring decision. 

As a recruiter, I AM responsible for the candidate process and making sure YOU as a candidate are having good a good process regardless of if you are hired or not. (I can‚Äôt speak for all recruiters but this is how I think and operate. 

As a recruiter, I am looking for the best candidate for the role. This candidate could be a referral, connection from Linkedin, applied to the role, or I may even have to source for them. I don‚Äôt discriminate when it comes to how I find talent. I believe in a fair and equitable hiring process. If I present a referral to a hiring manager, I always try to present a few people that have applied to the role as well because referrals aren‚Äôt always the best candidates. 

As a recruiter, I don‚Äôt believe in wasting people‚Äôs time. I‚Äôm very transparent when it comes to the process and also leave a line of communication always open between my candidate and me. I try to get feedback from my hiring manager partner as soon as possible so my candidate is waiting to hear back from us. Sometimes I don‚Äôt have all of the answers. Sometimes I have no update on the role and in my eyes, that‚Äôs an update. 

As a recruiter during these times, I don‚Äôt believe in cold-calling candidates if I am not working on any roles. Time is precious. It‚Äôs also mentally draining when you are talking to 15-20 people a week and they are telling you their life story and how badly they need a job at that moment you aren‚Äôt working on any roles.

Lastly, as a recruiter, my goal is to figure out bigger ways to make an impact in the #jobseeker community rather than just having individual 1:1‚Äôs. I use this platform to educate others on the recruiting process and give out free tips and tricks to hopefully enhance people‚Äôs job searches.  

This is what it means to be a recruiter to me. 

#recruiter #recruiting #recruiterlife

TITLE: Rihanna is 34 years old and starting a family. I love that for her. She worked in her 20s and gave us album after album.
TEXT:
Rihanna is 34 years old and starting a family. I love that for her. She worked in her 20s and gave us album after album. 

There's this stigma in America that having kids after 30 is "too old". (I don't want any men's input on when women should have kids or what they should do with their bodies. üòä) Your timing is your timing. I used to think that I was running out of time or I wasn't where I was supposed to be at 27 and now I look at my life and I think to myself that I'm right where The Most High wants me to be. 

You may not have the crib (house/apartment) you want, the whip (car) you want, or, the job you want or think you should have at the moment and that's okay. 

It's okay that you aren't married with kids at your age. And it's also okay if you don't want to be married and/or have kids. That doesn't make you less of an adult. 

The internet gives us unrealistic expectations of where we should be at our big age. I'm here to tell you that you are doing great in whatever part of your life that you are in. ‚ú®

TITLE: Today I am returning to work after being off for almost a week due to depression and anxiety kicking my a**.  This is my "I'm okay enough to show up and do my job" face.
TEXT:
Today I am returning to work after being off for almost a week due to depression and anxiety kicking my a**.  This is my "I'm okay enough to show up and do my job" face. 

Am I doing better? Sure. üôÉ 
Am I 100% back myself? Nah. üòÖ 
Am I in a better headspace than I was last week? For sure. ‚ò∫Ô∏è 

Depression and anxiety aren't just things that "go away". It takes time and it's a process. 

A lot of people ask me how am I so comfortable talking about my mental health on a professional platform and honestly it's life. We talk about everything else in our lives why not talk about how we are doing mentally and emotionally? 

I didn't grow up in a household where we talked about our feelings or emotions. Now that I'm older and I'm going to therapy I'm learning how to better communicate when I'm not okay in my personal and professional life. I learned to listen to myself and my body when I need time off instead of working through my problems. 

I will no longer silently struggle. My mental, physical, spiritual, and emotional health comes before anything. If these things aren't aligned I know I won't perform well at work. I'm no longer afraid to tell my people leaders that I need time off. I need time to reset. I need time to feel how I'm feeling. These things don't make me less of an employee or less capable of doing my job. 

 I'm thankful that I work for a company that is understanding and supportive when it comes to taking care of yourself. 

We often look at mental health illnesses as a sign of weakness and instead it should be looked at as a sign that we are humans with emotions. I wish having conversations about mental health in the workplace was normalized and taken more seriously. 

 #mentalhealth #depression #anxiety

TITLE: Depression is f***** trash. (Excuse my language)
TEXT:
Depression is f***** trash. (Excuse my language) 

Trying to work and live a "normal" life while battling depression is even more trash. When people ask you what can they do to help you, you don't have the answer because you are trying to figure that out yourself. 

My mom recently told me that "The version of YOU that people create in THEIR mind is not YOUR responsibility."

People have been reaching out to me with so many amazing oppurtunities to be a speaker for events, sit on a panels for their company, be guest on podcast episodes, ect. And little do they know that I am falling a part and battling things in my life. Dealing with emotions I can't explain. 

Give the strong people out there grace. Give the people that show up every day a break because sometimes they may not have the energy or capacity to show up like they usually do.  Everybody is battling something. Some people just know how to hide it better than others. 

#mentalhealth #depression

TITLE: Your accomplishments don't determine how you are doing.
TEXT:
Your accomplishments don't determine how you are doing. 

Just because someone "looks okay" doesn't always mean that they are okay. This week, I let my people leader know that I needed the rest of the week off due to my mental health struggling. They asked me no questions and told me to take as much time as I needed. After hearing that, I felt like a brick was lifted off of my chest. I didn't want to be considered weak or a failure because I was taking time away. 

I remember when there was a time I was afraid to take off for my mental health because I knew I may not come back to a job or I would be judged. I wish more employers saw their employees as people and not numbers. 

Employers listen to your employees when they say something is wrong and they need some time off. 

I pray for everyone that is struggling with their mental health during these times. You are not alone and we will get through this storm. üñ§

 #mentalhealth

TITLE: Hey companies,
TEXT:
Hey companies,

Just a little PSA. 

If your company has Black History month events planned for your employees and the events are centered around BLACK culture, PLEASE don't try and censor us from being our true authentic selves when you tell us to show up as our authentic self. ‚ò∫Ô∏è Our history doesn't deserve to be censored and neither do we. The truth can be uncomfortable but we live this life everyday and we don't get to censor our lives or experiences. 

These events should feel like a safe space for Black people to talk and educate others. You can't ask us to talk about code-switching and in the event we feel the need to have to code switch to accommodate others feelings and forget about our own. 

Make it make sense.

That's all. 
That's the post. 

Sincerely,

A Black employee that going to be their authentic self, respectfully. üíÖüèΩ

Happy Monday! ‚ú®

#blackinhr #blackintech #blackhistory #recruiter

TITLE: For my senior year of college I had to do an exhibition of my work to graduate. That whole semester I spent majority of my time in a black barbershop. Capturing our black culture. If you've ever been to a black barbershop you know that it's a whole experience.
TEXT:
For my senior year of college I had to do an exhibition of my work to graduate. That whole semester I spent majority of my time in a black barbershop. Capturing our black culture. If you've ever been to a black barbershop you know that it's a whole experience. 

& if you know anything about a black men you know that they will not cheat on their barber. üòÇ

I watched our men laugh and smile. I saw pure joy and the confidence boost they had after they got their haircut. I watched the brotherhood and exchanges that happened between our black men. 

The barbershop is like a safe space for black men. It's probably the only place where they feel like they can let their guard down and truly be themselves and not be judged. I saw authentic & raw emotions. I heard conversations of men expressing their feelings in an hour. 

Our black men deserve to grow old. They deserve to be happy. They deserve to feel their feeling. Our black men deserve to live long, peaceful lives.üñ§

Happy Friday! ‚ú®

#linkedincreator #photographer

TITLE: Goodmorning! ‚ú®
TEXT:
Goodmorning! ‚ú®

Let's talk about AAVE language. 

I'm lowkey finna give y'all a history lesson. 

AAVE, also known as African American Vernacular English, African American Language (AAL), Black English or Ebonics, is a style of English often spoken in Black American households. AAVE serves as communication among people in the black culture. The language was created by enslaved Black people living in the South who were separated from their native countries. Examples of AAVE: "On fleek,‚Äù ‚ÄúAF‚Äù, ‚Äúsavage,‚Äù ‚Äúshade‚Äù, ‚Äúsip/spill the tea‚Äù, "lit", and ‚Äúwoke‚Äù, "no cap/cap", "sis", "bruh", etc. 

Oh, and did y'all know that AAVE usually has a negative connotation in a white-centric culture and is looked at as "bad grammar", "ghetto", or "uneducated". This is why many of us blacks know how to code-switch so well. We code-switch between AAVE, standard English, and "CJ" which is corporate jargon üòÖ.

I see a lot of non-black creators on this platform nowadays using certain slang on their post and it's "cool" or "trendy". But if I were to use the same words in the same context people would say that I'm being "unprofessional" or better yet "this isn't the platform that I'm supposed to be talking like that on." There is a lack of accountability that has enabled people to participate in digital Blackface.

BLACK CULTURE IS NOT A TREND. üó£Ô∏è
MY BLACKNESS IS NOT A TREND. üó£Ô∏è
AND WE CAN'T TEACH ABOUT OUR CULTURE IN ONE MONTH!!! üó£Ô∏è

I go to bed and wake up like this everyday. I don't get to pick when I want to turn my blackness on and off. Our culture is getting elimanted in schools. Our culture gets disrespected on a daily basis. 

People love our culture but don't love us. Make it make sense. We are never just appreciated for being us. 

Using Black speech for online clout or personality while condemning that same speech in Black people is not only problematic in the digital world, but in the real world, too. 

So to my lovely non-black friends, next time you decided to use the term "lit" or "woke" in your posts remember the history and meaning behind where it came from. ‚ò∫Ô∏è

That's all.
Thank you for coming to my history lesson. ‚úäüèæüñ§

#blackcommunity #blackhistory #recruiter #blackinhr #blackintech #blackgirlmagic #slalomproud #ebonics #aave #blackenglish

TITLE: How come every time a company lays off employees the employees that still have a job have to make a post saying "Although I wasn't affected by the layoffs, my heat goes out to the people that were."
TEXT:
How come every time a company lays off employees the employees that still have a job have to make a post saying "Although I wasn't affected by the layoffs, my heat goes out to the people that were." 

Something about that statement just makes me feel some type of way. Like cool you still have a job but someone doesn't. I feel like there is a better way to go about making those types of post or acknowledging your former coworkers that lost their jobs than announcing that you still have a job. 

Just good for thought. 

That's all. 
That's the posts.

TITLE: Aye Good morning, y'all!
TEXT:
Aye Good morning, y'all! 

Can we talk about referrals?

A lot of you all ask me for a referral or if you can use my name as a referral. If I don't know you and we've never spoken my answer is going to be no. 

Why? 

Because I can't vouch for you. And if you say or do some off-the-wall stuff in an interview that's going to make me look bad. I have a brand that I have built at my job and I just don't let everyone use my name on their application. 

Also, just because someone refers you to a position doesn't mean that you will automatically just be sent over to the hiring manager. I still look at every referral's resume that I receive and if their background and skillset are aligned with the role that's when I will have an initial conversation with them. 

I know nowadays and especially in this job market people rely heavily on getting a referral from someone in their network. Networking and building connections are the keys to getting a referral.

Ask to grab virtual coffee with someone if their schedule permits. 

Make sure that the conversation doesn't feel like a transaction and more so like 2 people getting to know each other.  

Be intentional about who you connect with. 

& lastly, don't take it personally if you reach out to someone and they don't reply. You never know what someone is going through. 

Best of luck to my jobseeker friends on this snowy Tuesday. ‚ùÑÔ∏è

#referrals #networking #hiring #connections

TITLE: Well there is this. The amount of research in the last few years that have validated the trauma that many women of color have faced in the workplace may finally allow many to exhale‚Ä¶but not too much. Your thoughts?
TEXT:
Well there is this. The amount of research in the last few years that have validated the trauma that many women of color have faced in the workplace may finally allow many to exhale‚Ä¶but not too much. Your thoughts?

Please note articles like these are not for choir members who have the sheet music and have sung this song many times but for the directors and those who have members of marginalized communities on their teams. 

‚ÄúThe dismal psychological safety metric arguably highlights the toxic conundrum that so many Black women leaders face‚Äîfrustrated by disparate challenges and barriers but not feeling safe enough to voice concerns. Indeed, one of the most dehumanizing yet durable racist trolls stifling many Black women leaders is that of the ‚Äúangry Black woman.‚Äù As a result, many Black women leaders find themselves caught in a dysfunctional, non-reciprocal relationship with the workplace‚Äîcontinuing to contribute to and support organizations that clearly don‚Äôt nurture us in return. Many are choosing to move on.‚Äù
CONTENT_TITLE: Black Women Leaders Are More Ambitious But Less Supported At Work, McKinsey And Lean In Study Finds

TITLE: I‚Äôve been seeing a lot of #jobseekers posts that have been saying ‚ÄúI have applied to 400+ jobs and I haven‚Äôt received any calls back‚Äù or ‚Äúnobody is looking at my resume‚Äù.
TEXT:
I‚Äôve been seeing a lot of #jobseekers posts that have been saying ‚ÄúI have applied to 400+ jobs and I haven‚Äôt received any calls back‚Äù or ‚Äúnobody is looking at my resume‚Äù.

Let‚Äôs talk about this. 

If you are submitting the same exact resume to 400+ jobs that is a problem unless every job has the same job description and your resume mirrors that job description. 

If you are applying to all types of roles in different industries with the same resume, that could also be why you aren‚Äôt getting any responses back from your application.

I‚Äôm going to give you all some #recruitertea. The job description comes from the hiring manager. Everywhere I have worked the hiring manager creates the job description. So with that being said, look at the job description as a cheat sheet. Tailoring your resume to that job description can make you stand out from other candidates. 

By tailoring your resume, I don‚Äôt mean copying and pasting the job description to your resume because you will get rejected. Look at your skillset and experience and see how it is relevant to what the job requirements are, or if you‚Äôve done the work in some capacity and share those examples. If you are able to use stats or numbers in those examples that‚Äôs even better. 

I hope this helps someone. I‚Äôve always been told that if what you have been doing isn‚Äôt working then it‚Äôs time to change some things up. If what you have been doing when it comes to applying to jobs hasn‚Äôt been getting you noticed, try something else. 

#recruiter #resumetips

TITLE: This weekend, I quietly sat back and observed the media and people's posts on LinkedIn about the murder of Tyre Nichols. The whole world has come together and agreed that these men that just so happen to be all black deserve whatever is coming to them. They need to be under the jail for a very long time. We all have agreed that these men should be punished.
TEXT:
This weekend, I quietly sat back and observed the media and people's posts on LinkedIn about the murder of Tyre Nichols. The whole world has come together and agreed that these men that just so happen to be all black deserve whatever is coming to them. They need to be under the jail for a very long time. We all have agreed that these men should be punished.

All of that is beautiful and I'm glad that we all agree that if you kill someone that is innocent or beat someone to death they should be punished. 

But where was that energy and unity when it came to Derek Chauvin - the man who had his knee on George Floyd's neck?

Where was that energy when those 3 men killed Ahmaud Arbery? 

Where was this energy with Breonna Taylor, Michael Brown, Tamir Rice, Philando Castile, and all the other blacks that were murdered from police brutality? In all of these cases white people don't perceive themselves as aggressive or a threat. In these cases, all of these cops were in fear of their lives. 

These black men have been charged. Fired from their jobs. No paid leave. Nobody is trying to say that these men were "scared for their lives", change the story around, or give them the benefit of the doubt BECAUSE THEY DON'T DESERVE IT. THEY DESERVE TO GO TO JAIL. 

& I know someone is going to bring up black-on-black crime in the comments and I don't want to hear it. There are so many programs, organizations, non-profits, etc that are out there to help the black and brown community stay out of trouble and help them get on track to doing better. 

We live in a society where the law and the system were created for white people. Let's just call it how it is. But we can't be mad at a system that was never created to support or protect us. This is exactly what I mean when I say if you don't see my color, then you don't see me. 

I see all these people saying that color isn't a factor and if that's the case then I need the system to take action and be as swift as they were charging these black cops when a white cop commits police brutality. 

We are tired. 

That's all I have to say about that.

& LinkedIn is probably going to shadow-ban my post. That seems to happen when I start talking about things that make others feel uncomfortable. üòí

TITLE: I've been in virtual corporate america for about a year and something I will never understand is all the meetings that we have a week.
TEXT:
I've been in virtual corporate america for about a year and something I will never understand is all the meetings that we have a week. 

Like...

Can we make it a thing to not have meetings on Fridays? If it can wait until Monday, let's let it wait. 

Can we also make it a thing to not schedule meetings back-to-back on people's calendars unless the meeting is urgent? And if it is urgent can we try to add a 10-minute buffer in between the meeting just so if they are like me they have time to use the restroom, fill up their water bottle, and get their life together. 

Oh, and can we also normalize sending people a message before we throw time on their calendar so people can know what the meeting is about?  

Lastly, if it can be sent in an email or through messenger and doesn't require a meeting please send it on there. 

Thanking for tuning into my Outlook calendar scheduling rant. üòÜüòÖ

TITLE: I'm learning how to be patient.
TEXT:
I'm learning how to be patient.

I'm learning how to receive constructive feedback and not shut down. 

I'm learning how to delegate and allow people to help me with certain things instead of doing everything on my own.

I'm learning how to give myself grace.

I'm learning that timing is everything and just because it doesn't happen on my time doesn't mean that it's not going to happen at all. 

I'm learning how to lead and project manage.

I'm learning how to say no to meetings and reschedule them if I need to.

I'm learning how to better manage my time and set boundaries. 

I'm learning how to listen and understand instead of listening to just hear. (Yes, there's a difference.)

Last but not least I'm learning to think and sit on things before I react. 

This season is the season of learning, changing, and growing.

#professionaldevelopment

TITLE: I been working in corporate america for a year now and I still love my job and my coworkers. üòÇ I know that sounds crazy but hear me out. Usually after a year of working at a company I'm over everybody and everything and looking for something else.
TEXT:
I been working in corporate america for a year now and I still love my job and my coworkers. üòÇ I know that sounds crazy but hear me out. Usually after a year of working at a company I'm over everybody and everything and looking for something else. 

This is the first job where I've been apart of a team where everyone is a team player and we lift as we climb. I've never been able to talk to a people leader about how I feel, but here my people leaders accommodate me to make sure that I'm doing something that I enjoy and that it's intentional towards my career growth. I feel valued. 

Here's an affirmation for my #jobseeker friends, I hope everybody gets to experience a healthy work environment at least once in their life. I hope you get to experience a company that values you and what you have to offer. I hope you find a place that values mental health and supports you when it comes to whatever you are going through. I hope you find career happiness. ü§ç

Happy Thursday! ‚ú®

#recruiterlife #recruiter #corporateamerica

TITLE: Hey Connections. Hope you all doing good. Today I have done SQL Project based on Zomato dataset in Collaboration with my brother Balaji A . We explored the Zomato dataset using SQL and below are the analysis we did.
TEXT:
Hey Connections. Hope you all doing good. Today I have done SQL Project based on Zomato dataset in Collaboration with my brother Balaji A . We explored the Zomato dataset using SQL and below are the analysis we did.
                üéØ ZOMATO SQL PROJECT üéØ

Project Objective :
¬† ‚û°Ô∏è The project involved analyzing customer behavior on the Zomato platform, which is a food delivery, sales, and customer.¬†
¬†‚û°Ô∏è The data used for the analysis was about Zomato sales based on membership, which contained information about sales, customers, products and membership.
 
Provided Task :
¬†‚û°Ô∏è The task was to use SQL queries to answer several questions about customer behavior on Zomato.¬†
¬†‚û°Ô∏è The sample questions included: what is the total amount each customer spent on Zomato, how many days has each customer visited Zomato, what was the first product purchased by each customer, what is the most purchased item on the menu, which item was most popular for each customer, and which item was purchased first by a customer after they became a member. 

Project Approach :
¬†¬†‚û°Ô∏è We approached the project first and had to clean the data to ensure that it was in a usable format.¬†
¬†¬†‚û°Ô∏è Checked any missing values and dealing with any data quality issues.¬†
¬†¬†‚û°Ô∏è Then used SQL queries to extract the data from the Zomato dataset and performed aggregate calculations on the data to answer the questions.

Analysis Report :
  ‚û°Ô∏è The result of the analysis showed that the most popular products on Zomato were product1 and product3.¬†
¬†¬†¬†‚û°Ô∏è As based on the customer membership the Zomato points for user 1 and user 2 earned the Zomato points and the highest points earned as per product was p3 is 3045 points.¬†
   ‚û°Ô∏è These are insights helped to provide a better understanding of customer behavior on Zomato and will be useful for making informed decisions.

Github Repository : https://lnkd.in/grG8e_5P


I would like to thank Ashutosh Kumar and Sagar Prajapati Ajay Kadiyala Sanjay Chandra Sikakollu NAVEEN S Dhaval Patel Hemanand Vadivel Thoufiq Mohammed Shashank Singh üáÆüá≥ Ashvini P.¬†Vinit Sangoi Sachin Kumar Jay Charole Durgesh Yadav  Tagging for better reach

TITLE: I have a confession: coffee chats absolutely drain me.
TEXT:
I have a confession: coffee chats absolutely drain me.

As an introvert, I‚Äôve realized from hundreds of coffee chats over the past year that having small talk with strangers absolutely wiped out my social battery. So much so that I would often have to take a nap afterward.

When I was job searching, I was requesting and having coffee chats almost everyday. But even when I was done with job searching, and as my LinkedIn following started to grow, I started to be on the receiving end of coffee chat requests.

At first, I was all too happy to help anyone and everyone I could. I knew what it was like to be a career-changing job-seeker, so I gave my time and energy out to almost anyone who wanted to learn about how I did it.

But it came at my own detriment. It was not just the time spent in the coffee chats, but also the anxiety I had leading into the call and the refocusing that I struggled to do immediately after the call, that piled up, especially when it got to the point where I was saying yes to 2-3 coffee chats per day‚Ä¶ultimately leading to burnout.

However, coffee chats themselves were not the real reason I ended up burning out. But rather, it was my inability to set boundaries and protect my own time that led me to a point of ignoring almost every DM and coffee chat from LinkedIn over the past 2 months.

I have written in depth about how coffee chats and networking are the entire reason I am where I am today, and I stand by that. To all the wonderful people I have met through coffee chats over the past year or so, I‚Äôm so thankful for every single one of those conversations.

But to everyone else I have yet to meet, please have patience with me as I act a bit selfishly for the time being in my process of learning how to value myself and my own time.


#networking #socialmedia #burnout

TITLE: When LinkedIn meets real life!
TEXT:
When LinkedIn meets real life!

Last weekend I flew across the country to referee a powerlifting competition, and Stephen Tran happened to be competing at the very same meet (this was not planned at all)!

For those who don‚Äôt know, the sport of powerlifting plays a huge part in both of our lives, but Stephen and I would not have found that shared interest if LinkedIn had not brought us together in the first place.

LinkedIn can get a bad rap as a platform for only networking or schmoozing, but in reality it‚Äôs a place that can bring together people from all walks of life who share the same passions. 

Has LinkedIn ever helped you connect with friends IRL? Tag them below! üëá


#connections #linkedin #socialmedia

TITLE: Before I became a data scientist, I worked in the consulting world, and I hated it.
TEXT:
Before I became a data scientist, I worked in the consulting world, and I hated it. 

Coming out of business school, it seemed like investment banking or consulting were the only two acceptable career paths. So when I landed my first post-grad job as a financial consultant, I thought I had ‚Äúmade it.‚Äù

But behind the promised perks of frequent traveling and expensed meals were long nights, tracking billed hours down to the minute, catering to every client request, and lack of ownership over my work product due to being an external consultant. 

When I was making the transition to data science, I kept wishing I came from a more relevant background, and almost resented my time in consulting. What was building powerpoint presentation decks all day good for?

But during one of my previous data science interviews, my interviewer said ‚ÄúWe were interested in you not just for your technical skills, but for the consulting soft skills you bring too.‚Äù

Then when I made the jump to individual contributor at a tech startup, I was too eager to dive into internal work and internal work only. However, the reality was that 50% or more of my current job is handling customer requests and acting as a data consultant of sorts, rather than the 100% heads-down work I had hoped and dreamed for.

I now realize that providing a product or service to customers is not unique to consulting. Prioritizing a client or customer‚Äôs needs is necessary for any successful business, and apparently I had been underestimating this transferable skill because I was so caught up in leaving consulting.

In any career transition, you bring your own unique strengths. Don‚Äôt forget them in the process of gaining new ones because those strengths are what has gotten you to where you are today.


#careerpivot #consulting #datascience

TITLE: For the past two years of my life, I had this unrelenting, borderline unhealthy obsession with advancing my career.
TEXT:
For the past two years of my life, I had this unrelenting, borderline unhealthy obsession with advancing my career.

As a matter of fact, it coincided with how often I was using LinkedIn. For a period of time, I viewed every post, connection and conversation I made transactionally‚Äìfrom the lens of ‚Äúhow can I use this to achieve my goal of landing my dream job?‚Äù

Outside of LinkedIn, I was sacrificing personal relationships and the quality of my life to balance working my full time job, studying, side projects and coffee chats, and justified all of it by calling it ‚Äúa passion.‚Äù

Buying into hustle culture felt great for a while, until it no longer did. Coming out of a 5-year relationship recently was the catalyst that made me reevaluate what made me truly happy (getting really personal here), and it turns out, constantly hustling to chase moving goal posts was not it.

A lot of people checked in to see if I was doing ok during my break from LinkedIn recently (which I appreciate SO much), but honestly, I was having a WONDERFUL time being lazy, shopping, hanging out with friends, re-prioritizing my health, and just being a regular 26-year-old again!

Contrary to what you often see on LinkedIn, you DON‚ÄôT have to chase your goals 24/7 to be successful.

There is certainly a time and place for putting your blinders on and hustling, but what this recent break has taught me is that giving yourself breaks and finding happiness in other facets of life is how you stay successful.


#careers #mentalhealth #worklifebalance

TITLE: I‚Äôve played the comparison game my entire life, and I‚Äôve lost every time.
TEXT:
I‚Äôve played the comparison game my entire life, and I‚Äôve lost every time.

Over the years, I‚Äôve been no stranger to the sinking feeling in your stomach when you hear someone got a better grade, was accepted to a more prestigious school, landed a higher paying job or promotion, or has more followers than you, etc.

Every time, I really thought I could gain an upper hand in the game by using my jealous anger as fuel to do better than the other person‚Äìstudy harder, work longer hours, write better posts, just do MORE.

For a while, it worked. The pressure I put on myself to ‚Äúwin‚Äù in this game I was playing against my unknowing competitor became such a driving force in my life, and I did manage to reach plenty of the goals I had ruthlessly set out to achieve.

But in the process of those blind pursuits, I was losing sight of the fact that I was getting so burnt out and resentful‚Äîmeanwhile my competition was most likely still thriving.

Seeing that the other person still ends up winning, no matter how much I compared myself to them or resented their success, was what made me realize comparison is a futile, zero-sum game.

On social media platforms like LinkedIn, it‚Äôs so easy to compare ourselves to people who seem to be winning. But in that process, we lose sight of our own wins that probably many others would kill for.


#careerdevelopment #careers #datascience

TEXT:
Spotify launched a new AI feature called ‚ÄúDJ‚Äù offering personalised music with AI-powered commentary. Similar to a radio DJ, Spotify‚Äôs DJ feature will deliver a curated selection of music alongside AI-powered spoken commentary about the tracks and artists you like, using what Spotify says is a ‚Äústunningly realistic voice.‚Äù

The idea, explains the company, is for Spotify to get to know users so well that the DJ can choose what to play for you when you hit the button. Or, as Spotify says, it‚Äôs putting an ‚ÄúAI DJ in your pocket.‚Äù

The OpenAI-powered feature is still in beta testing as of the time of today‚Äôs launch and is only available in English for Spotify Premium subscribers in the U.S. and Canada for the time being.

Source: TechCrunch

TITLE: The hyped up startup MyGate has laid off 30% workforce as there is a Funding Winter..!! Yes, funding is important to meet expenses. Yes, those employees were not over hired. Yes, there is nothing such as Job Security. BUT --
TEXT:

- The firm has to plan better.
- The business needs to be profit viable --> MyGate can't run on Ads Revenue only.
- Economic conditions are not an excuse to say we did not get funding.
- You can't rely on "funding" only when you have crossed Series B ($79.5M raised till date)

TITLE: Unfortunately, financial literacy including banking & investing is not part of any school curriculum. While there is immense focus on laws of physics, Pythagoras theorem, etc., concepts such as Savings, Investments, Compounding, and Loan/ Debt are equally important, if not more.
TEXT:
Unfortunately, financial literacy including banking & investing is not part of any school curriculum. While there is immense focus on laws of physics, Pythagoras theorem, etc., concepts such as Savings, Investments, Compounding, and Loan/ Debt are equally important, if not more.

Kids also absorb the important concepts such as Profit, Loss, ROI, Growth, Percentages, etc., well when applied practically rather than learning formulas.

My biggest observation when my kid started investing in stocks(not directly) was that he was relating consumer goods, product launches, and macros with a potential impact on the share price. When Mahindra launched a series of successful products from 2020-22 ( Thar, Xuv700, and others), he could correlate share price movement with the bookings and waiting periods. Mahindra grew from Rs 300 to Rs 1300 per share in this timeframe.

His next question was, "Can I buy Mcdonald's share." His understanding may not be perfect, but he is asking the right questions, and the learning is at near zero risk at his age. (He just turned 11). 

Next, I taught him how banks work. Once he understood the concept, his immediate question was, banks give us 5% interest but lend at 8%. That's 3 percent profit. I learnt this when I was 20 or 21.

Encouraging kids to learn investing is gaining popularity in the west with concepts such as Custodial accounts. 

Most Indian Parents feel that educating kids about money, investments & stock market will take their focus away from studies. But it is also true that an average Indian who starts earning at the age of 20-21 spends at least 3-4 years before they start understanding even simple investment instruments such as PPF, VPF, and associated tax benefits. Stepping into stock markets (direct, mutual, or index funds) happens in the early 30s for most Indians.

Indian Parents teach kids to study and work hard to earn more. There needs to be more focus on how to smartly save & invest that money so that it can grow. 

Awareness about saving money and growing it by investing can go far in teaching children to become responsible adults. Kids will make mistakes early on, but risks will be less as investment amounts will be smaller. The same learning coming with a 10X investment corpus 10 years later can hurt more. 

All I want to say is, "Get your kids started with Savings, Investments, and Stocks."

Here‚Äôs how you can do that:

1) Open a Junio or FamPay account

2) Give them access to a stock market simulator. Once they understand how things work, buy some stocks on their behalf and ask them to track price movements and build a point of view (right or wrong doesn‚Äôt matter).

3) Get them to save money, invest it and see what return they get in 6 months or an year. 

Let‚Äôs bring change.

PS: Here is a snapshot of my kid's investment diary.

#investments #stockmarket #finance #financialliteracy #banking

TITLE: What can you do to maximize ROI with $5, 2 hours, and 3 minutes?
TEXT:
What can you do to maximize ROI with $5, 2 hours, and 3 minutes?

You‚Äôre a student in a Stanford entrepreneurship class. 

You have $5 in funding. 

Your goal is to make as much money as possible within 2 hours and then give a 3-minute presentation.

What would you do to maximize the return? ü§î

I recently read how Stanford students turned $5 into $650 in 2 hours and thought to share my learnings. 

.
.
.

First, let‚Äôs talk about the typical, logical path: buy materials for a makeshift car wash or a lemonade stand, buy a lottery ticket, or gamble. 

With this approach, you can probably turn $5 ‚Üí $8.¬†
The ROI is minimum. 

.

Second, let‚Äôs take a look at the smarter group. 

They realized that the $5 was mostly a distraction, so they focused on making the most money in 2 hours. 

They ended up making reservations at popular local restaurants and then selling the reservation times to those who wanted to skip the wait.

The ROI? A few hundred bucks. 

. 

Now, let‚Äôs look at the winning team. 

They didn‚Äôt just realize that the $5 was mostly a distraction.

They also realized that the 2-hour period was also a distraction, and that the most valuable resource was the 3-minute presentation time they had with a group of captivated Stanford students. 

So they sold their 3-minute slot to a company interested in recruiting Stanfrod students for $650. 

The ROI? 12,900%.

#entrepreneurship #thinkoutsidethebox 

Credit: @NextBigIdeaClub

TITLE: Ever realized what NAVI Technologies has done to emerge as a silent winner in BFSI and how no one is talking about that?
TEXT:
Ever realized what NAVI Technologies has done to emerge as a silent winner in BFSI and how no one is talking about that? 

I am an angel investor in two BFSI companies and really admire what Navi Technologies is doing.

Sachin Bansal, who had laid out the blueprint for a $100 billion plan for Flipkart, set up his venture BAC Acquisitions (later renamed Navi Technologies) in December 2018, immediately after exiting Flipkart.

Bansal‚Äôs diversified portfolio includes companies like Unacademy, Inshorts, Ather Energy, and OLA (to name a few).

And what about Navi? Interestingly, after Flipkart, Bansal has invested in 18 companies personally and through BAC Acquisitions. He has investments close to $1Bn, with a major chunk in Navi.

Navi was primarily set up for investments and acquisitions in the BFSI sector but also includes other sectors.

It has made 7 investments (with one exit) so far that include - 

- $30 million in Infra Market.
- INR 500 million in Kissht.
- INR 200 million in boAt.
- INR 100 million in Bounce.
- INR 1 billion in KrazyBee.
- And $4 million in Bounce.

Apart from investment, Navi itself has raised a total of $582 million in funding from 14 investors.

But what's that Bansal is more fascinated about, and how is he using Navi?

Bansal aims to leverage tech to change the face of the old BFSI giant. So far, banks have yet to cater to consumers at the level at which NBFCs and payment apps do. People rarely use apps from their Banks. Bansal wants to change that through intuitive customer service and an automation-led experience. He might be right to a large extent.

However, technology alone can't fix all the BFSI issues. YES BANK was among the first to offer UPI payments and entered API banking, facilitating the issuance of a commercial paper (CP) of INR 100 Cr using blockchain technology for Vedanta. The bank was at the forefront of tech adoption yet faced an RBI moratorium because of mismanagement. But I am expecting Navi to adapt to this positively.

Not a promotional post but sharing something that should have your attention. Navi aims to bring change to the BFSI sector and I‚Äôm eagerly looking forward to it.

I'll talk more about product and business on LinkedIn. Follow Vaibhav Goel for more such content on Product and Business.

#business #navi #investment #bfsitech
CONTENT_TITLE: Navi Technologies & BFSI

TITLE: Excited to share my latest article on the basics of econometrics, the original data science, and how to perform cross-sectional analysis with Ordinary Least Squares (OLS) in Python! OLS is a widely used econometric tool for estimating the parameters of linear models, providing a powerful tool for analyzing economic data and extracting causal effects.
TEXT:
Excited to share my latest article on the basics of econometrics, the original data science, and how to perform cross-sectional analysis with Ordinary Least Squares (OLS) in Python! OLS is a widely used econometric tool for estimating the parameters of linear models, providing a powerful tool for analyzing economic data and extracting causal effects.

Join me in this hands-on article as we explore the intricacies of OLS by analyzing the effects of select economic indicators on the growth of high and upper-middle income countries. Using data from the World Bank and the statsmodels package, we'll delve into the topic and gain a deeper understanding of the relationships between these indicators and economic growth.

#python #econometrics #machinelearning #economicanalysis #statistics #medium
CONTENT_TITLE: Econometrics in Python: Cross-Sectional Analysis with OLS

TITLE: I have been fascinated by the brain and the complexity of behavior for a while now. This semester, I finally got an opportunity to delve deeper into these topics with neuro-economist Dr. Paul Zak's class on Behavioral Neuroscience. Basically, neuro distilled for economists.
TEXT:
I have been fascinated by the brain and the complexity of behavior for a while now. This semester, I finally got an opportunity to delve deeper into these topics with neuro-economist Dr. Paul Zak's class on Behavioral Neuroscience. Basically, neuro distilled for economists. 

In our recent discussions and assignments, we've explored the fascinating topic of morality and the influence of evolution on our perceptions of fairness. It got me thinking. How has our sense of fairness evolved, that is, how does it work today? How is it related to our perception of corruption? Is there a threshold below which corrupt activity is tolerated? What incentives are driving this? Cultural evolution is much faster than natural evolution; have our brains updated on time to deal with complex societies? In this brief article, I provide an evolutionary argument for why our fairness mechanism remains crucial for humans, and I question our collective ability to take action against corruption in the face of rising levels of populism and social unrest worldwide.

I hope you find the piece intriguing at the very least. If you enjoyed it, consider subscribing or sharing it with your friends! And if you have any feedback, please do reach out or leave a comment.

#neuroscience #economics #behavior #evolutionary
CONTENT_TITLE: The Complexity of Moral Decision-Making: Neurons, Genes, and Populism

As a PhD student in Economics at Claremont Graduate University and a recent graduate from Marist College with a double major in Economics and Data Science, I am excited to share that I am actively searching for paid summer internship opportunities in the field of quantitative modeling, data analysis, economic research, natural language processing, or statistical analysis.

I graduated Summa Cum Laude with a GPA of 3.93/4.0 and currently hold a 4.0/4.0 GPA in my PhD in Quantitative Economics and Econometrics. I am confident that my quantitative modelling and interpretation skills will prove useful to any team seeking to uncover actionable insights from data, both structured and unstructured.

With three years of experience in research and applied Natural Language Processing and my academic achievements, I am confident in my ability to contribute and grow in these fields. I am eager to apply my skills and knowledge in a real-world setting and am open to any research positions or projects that will help me develop my computing and mathematical abilities.

TITLE: In this piece, we explore the use of RL to simulate economic theories of decision-making and how it is being applied to tasks such as autonomous driving, synthetic data generation, and game-playing. We'll also be implementing popular libraries and packages in R to get some hands-on experience experimenting with designing an environment, reward function, and other relevant features.
TEXT:
In this piece, we explore the use of RL to simulate economic theories of decision-making and how it is being applied to tasks such as autonomous driving, synthetic data generation, and game-playing. We'll also be implementing popular libraries and packages in R to get some hands-on experience experimenting with designing an environment, reward function, and other relevant features. 

This article will give you an idea of how chatGPT, Tesla's AI, and chess-champion AlphaGo reason and adapt by interacting with their environments. It also pins down a common misconception: Data is not everything. There are events for which it is very complicated, borderline impossible, to even generate training data. Thus, limiting the kinds of questions we can ask. Reinforcement learning provides an alternative learning strategy based on heuristics that may prove to be a useful complement to the Causal AI framework brewing right now.

#ai #data #learning #strategy #tesla #chatgpt3 #articles #medium #reinforcementlearning #economics #rstudio #behavioralscience
CONTENT_TITLE: Applied Reinforcement Learning in R
