TITLE: Artificial intelligence (AI) is one of the most exciting and rapidly evolving areas of technology today.
TEXT:
Artificial intelligence (AI) is one of the most exciting and rapidly evolving areas of technology today.

From self-driving cars to voice-activated personal assistants,
AI is already changing the way we live and work.

But what does the future hold for this powerful technology?
Artificial intelligence (AI) is shaping the future of the accounting industry with these advantages:

üëâ With the help of AI-powered tools, accountants can automate repetitive tasks, such as data entry and financial statement preparation, allowing them to focus on more strategic tasks. 

üëâ AI-based systems can help detect fraud and improve investment decisions.

üëâ AI can assist in analyzing large amounts of data to provide insights into financial performance and potential areas for improvement.

As AI technology continues to advance, it has the potential to revolutionize the accounting industry and make it more efficient and effective.

While the future of AI is exciting, it is not without its challenges.
One of the main concerns is the potential for AI to displace jobs and create economic inequality.

Additionally, there are concerns about the ethical implications of AI, such as the potential for bias and the need for transparency and accountability.

Overall, the future of AI is one of enormous potential and promise. As we continue to develop and refine this technology, we must be mindful of the potential challenges and work to ensure that its benefits are shared by all.






#technology #ai #futureofbusiness #artificialintelligence
CONTENT_TITLE: The impact of Artificial Intelligence

TITLE: Starting a business is never easy, but starting a startup comes with its own unique set of challenges.
TEXT:
Starting a business is never easy, but starting a startup comes with its own unique set of challenges.

A startup is not just a smaller version of a large company, it's a completely different animal.

Startups are characterized by their fast-paced, iterative nature and their focus on rapid growth and innovation.

They require a different approach to management, a different mindset, and a different set of skills.

So, if you're thinking about starting a business or are already on the startup journey, embrace the differences and embrace the challenge.

Embrace the hustle, the risk, and the uncertainty.

Because in the end, it's these differences that make starting a startup one of the most rewarding experiences you can have.

Let's keep pushing the boundaries, let's keep disrupting the status quo, and let's keep building the future. üí™

TITLE: Want to improve your financial forecasting and budgeting?
TEXT:
Want to improve your financial forecasting and budgeting?

Financial forecasting and budgeting can be a daunting task.

But with the right strategy and tools, you can ensure success in managing your business‚Äô finances.

Here are five tips for creating successful financial forecasts and budgets:

1. Start with a clear goal in mind: Before you start building your forecast or budget, have a clearly defined goal in mind that will guide the rest of the process.

2. Utilize reliable data sources: Make sure you‚Äôre using up-to-date, accurate data when forecasting and budgeting.

3. Track historical patterns: Take note of how your business has performed in the past and use it as a benchmark or guideline for future projections.

4. Analyze potential market changes: It‚Äôs important to consider possible changes in the market that could affect your financial situation ‚Äì both positively and negatively ‚Äì when forecasting and budgeting.

5. Stay organized: Utilize effective systems that allow you to store and easily access all financial information related to your forecast or budget. Doing so will streamline the process and help avoid errors.






#financialforecasting #budgeting

TITLE: This news is a sobering reminder of the challenges many industries are facing.
TEXT:
This news is a sobering reminder of the challenges many industries are facing.

This is a difficult time for workers and businesses alike, and it's important for companies to explore all available options to support their workforce.

One way for tech companies to support their employees and encourage research and development is by taking advantage of the R&D Tax Credit.

This tax credit provides a financial incentive for businesses to invest in R&D, allowing them to maintain their workforce and continue to drive innovation.

In addition, the Employee Retention Tax Credit (ERTC) is another option for companies to consider.

The ERTC provides a tax credit of up to $7,000 per employee, per quarter, to eligible employers who retain their employees and continue to pay them during the pandemic.

If you're a tech business owner, I encourage you to learn more about the R&D Tax Credit and ERTC, and how they could benefit your company and your employees.

By utilizing these resources, we can work together to support the job market and drive a strong recovery from the pandemic.

You can message me to learn more about these tax credits.

TITLE: I just spoke in Dubai on the re-emergence of Pseudonymity. Digital identity is becoming increasingly fluid, reflecting a major shift in the way people identify online. 3 points:
TEXT:
I just spoke in Dubai on the re-emergence of Pseudonymity. Digital identity is becoming increasingly fluid, reflecting a major shift in the way people identify online. 3 points:


1. There are three ‚Äòtypes‚Äô of pseudonyms:

PUBLIC: Public pseudonyms are easily tied to their human author. The author makes minimal effort to distance their identity from their pseudonym. In the case of digital creators, this is a modern way to start a brand. Think: meme page owners, digital artists, selfie-sharing Redditors, YouTubers, etc ‚Äî e.g. Mr. Beast or Dream. 

NON-PUBLIC: Non-public pseudonyms are only tied to their human author in private, known only by very few people or platforms. Think: When a phone #, email, or legal ID is required to register for a service and the pseudonymous user makes no effort to create a burner or use a VPN (KYC). They just don‚Äôt necessarily want to be publicly known, for whatever reason ‚Äî e.g. celebrity artist Marshmello‚Äôs human identity was a closely held secret until 2017. 

UNLINKABLE: Unlinkable pseudonyms have no or near-no connection to their human author. Unlinkable pseudonyms are a powerful device for private expression, yet equally as powerful for malicious actors. While this category is regarded as a problem area for pseudonymity, it also represents a significant opportunity and defined by ‚Äúhow you use it‚Äù ‚Äî e.g. Satoshi Nakamoto, the famed pseudonym who created Bitcoin. 



2. Digital pseudonymity has evolved over the years, spanning multi-user domains, bulletin board systems, internet-relay chat, AOL, forums, blogs, MMORPGs, social networks like Reddit, cryptocurrency, and more. Pseudonymity lost focus with the introduction of Facebook, Google, and other human identity obsessed revenue models, however it‚Äôs now majorly coming back into focus.



3. A new pseudonymity boom can be attributed to the rise of avatars, virtual reality, anime, gaming, and a need for privacy. There are many trending use cases for pseudonymity, including:

‚Ä¢ NFT profile pictures
‚Ä¢ Digital pen-names
‚Ä¢ Pseudonymous apps
‚Ä¢ Artificial assistant developers
‚Ä¢ VR creators (e.g. PHIA)
‚Ä¢ Virtual influencers
‚Ä¢ 2D VTubers
‚Ä¢ PNGTubers
‚Ä¢ AR filter influencers
‚Ä¢ 3D VTubers



While pseudonymity is a powerful mechanism, its uses are double-edged‚Ä¶ for good and for bad. 

However, the vast majority of pseudonyms are Public or Non-Public. People mainly use them casually, often for self-expression or content lurking ends, with varying levels of care for privacy and a general subscription to accountability.

Overall, pseudonyms are a highly personal, dynamic device for digital privacy, expression, acceptance, security, and free speech. 

Pseudonyms are the outcome of society‚Äôs increasing need for an online presence that represents dynamic interests in varied mediums.

Thank you Azra and Tomorrow Conference for inviting me to speak‚Ä¶


Thoughts?


Tap the blue +Connect atop this post for more insights from me or just tap here:¬†lnkd.in/gggHuhHE

~ Christopher

TITLE: An important life update: I have chosen to move on from my position as Co-Founder of Offbeat, the media company we launched over 4 years ago. Unfortunately, this decision also forces my total departure from Virtual Humans org, the open industry resource I personally founded, developed, and matured...
TEXT:
An important life update: I have chosen to move on from my position as Co-Founder of Offbeat, the media company we launched over 4 years ago. Unfortunately, this decision also forces my total departure from Virtual Humans org, the open industry resource I personally founded, developed, and matured...

I am grateful to the talented people who joined our effort to blend technology and creativity in novel, cutting edge ways‚ÄîI already have fond memories of the unique IP and surprising outcomes we generated. I will continue to support Offbeat‚Äôs success as an Advisor at this time, and I look forward to watching the company grow under the continued leadership of my co-founders.

My departure is certainly not ‚ÄúGoodbye‚Äù to anyone I‚Äôve met along the way. Instead, this is ‚ÄúHello‚Äù to everyone who has supported me thus far and to all the people I will meet during my entrepreneurial career. This is ‚ÄúHello‚Äù to exploring value creation in new problem areas, independently.

Ultimately, this is a necessary step in my entrepreneurial journey to recalibrate my best efforts with my best interests.

I am passionate about creativity, community, privacy, and open access. I love building new technology, experiences, aggregators, and digital identities. I am keen on ephemerality, artificial intelligence, fandom, and incentives. I look forward to sharing my insights on all of these subjects, and more.

I will now take stock, reflect, read, write, and soon proceed with a fresh, focused perspective towards solving human problems in new, creative ways.

Thank you to my mentors, investors, and friends for the continued support as I venture into what‚Äôs next.

Reach me at christopher@travers.tech or via DM, or simply tap Follow to keep up with me here.

~ Christopher

TITLE: Speaking in NYC about the metaverse and avatar fashion alongside the legendary Michael Ferraro and Michael Heaven was an eye opening experience. The most humbling takeaway came from a conversation I had with Michael Ferraro, before we stepped onto the panel:
TEXT:
Speaking in NYC about the metaverse and avatar fashion alongside the legendary Michael Ferraro and Michael Heaven was an eye opening experience. The most humbling takeaway came from a conversation I had with Michael Ferraro, before we stepped onto the panel:

Michael, an Animated Film Industry veteran and executive at the Fashion Institute of Technology, told me many stories from his career cultivating the computer graphics industry.

Leaning on his experiences founding and growing Blue Sky Studios in the 1980s, he emphasized that what's old is new when it comes to the metaverse.

Almost every modern idea about "the metaverse", from game worlds to virtual fashion to avatar storytelling, provably parlays 3+ decades of studios, ideas, execution, failures, and exits. 

It's true‚Äîthe metaverse is a rebranding of the old and tried.

That being said, there's a trove to be learned by researching the played-out models from the recent past.

The future potential is also much easier to grasp when you consider the metaverse in this way, in that yesterday's models and mechanisms may have new relevance tomorrow.

Expedite your perspective by speaking with people who already walked your path years ago.

Ignoring the past will prevent you from anticipating the future.

Thank you Sophie, Elizabeth, Ariana, and the whole Bambuser team for including me in such well-produced live events.



For more insights from me, tap the blue +Follow atop this post or just tap here:¬†https://lnkd.in/gggHuhHE

~ Christopher

TITLE: She has 32M+ followers, yet she doesn‚Äôt physically exist.
TEXT:
She has 32M+ followers, yet she doesn‚Äôt physically exist.

Lu "lives" in Brazil and works as a virtual brand spokesperson. 

She‚Äôs the face of Magalu (Magazine Luiza), a leading Brazilian retailer first founded in 1957.

And Magalu is crushing it in recent years:

SALES REVENUE
2016 ‚Äî 2.16 billion USD
2017 ‚Äî 2.76 billion USD
2018 ‚Äî 3.77 billion USD
2019 ‚Äî 5.22 billion USD
2020 ‚Äî 8.33 billion USD
2021 ‚Äî 10.65 billion USD

All this growth with virtual Lu as the "face"

I had the rare opportunity to interview virtual human Lu‚Äôs manager, Pedro Alvim üè≥Ô∏è‚Äçüåà, to peek behind the scenes of this high-impact, virtual operation.

"Building influence is complex and not easy. The focus must be on storytelling, diversity and bravery. We need characters that represent ourselves and our beliefs, and don‚Äôt be silenced about what happens in our real¬†world," Pedro Alvim üè≥Ô∏è‚Äçüåà said during our conversation.

"The fact you create or have a character doesn‚Äôt mean you have an influencer, with an engaged community. Influence is built, not created."

Lu lives on the app icon, in customer emails, on the navbar, in commercials, in the rewards program, and, most importantly, posting daily on social media from a 1st person point of view.

Like a coat of paint, she‚Äôs all over.

She's what the Amazon smile would be if given two eyes, a name (Alexa?), and an active social media presence.

She's the GEICO Gecko on steroids and a pristine example to anyone looking to invent or re-invent their identity online in a timeless, interoperable, engaging way.

Link to our full interview in the comments.




What do you think? Would you follow a virtual human on social media?

~ Christopher

TITLE: YouTube says ‚ÄúVTubers" now hit 1.5B+ views per month üìà
TEXT:
YouTube says ‚ÄúVTubers" now hit 1.5B+ views per month üìà 

On Twitch, the VTuber category has grown 500% YoY for 3 years. To win these animated creators, YouTube put this exploding industry on their top bar for the day:

"The secret to being authentic online may just involve being radically artificial." -YouTube‚Äôs official trends podcast

A VTuber is when someone puppeteers an animated character in real-time, most often by using free, off-the-shelf webcam technology.

VTubers dominantly livestream on Twitch and YouTube, with some using dedicated VTuber apps, such as Reality app, to express themselves. 

With skyrocketing fandoms, YouTube recognizes the massive opportunity to serve and earn the trust of this burgeoning lofi medium.

What do VTubers do, exactly? 

During a VTuber livestream, expect to watch an animated character play video games, react to funny videos, chat with their fans, record ASMR, sing karaoke, browse websites like Reddit, and even appear alongside other VTubers.

Who subscribes to VTubers? 

Weebs, otakus, and anime lovers (primarily Gen-Z introverts) who develop long-term parasocial relationships with the human creators embodying pseudonymous anime characters.

How do VTubers make money? 

VTubers make a living from financially-committed fans in some of the following ways: Subscriptions, donations, tips, merch, sponsorships, and even hosting live concerts.

That's right... some VTubers take their fame beyond livestreaming, parlaying their influential IP into music careers as exemplified by the likes of Mori Calliope, Nyanners, Gawr Gura, Kizuna Ai, and others.

If you manage talent, run an animation-related business, run a gaming company, have a brand mascot, are a creator looking to break out pseudonymously‚Äîyou need to increase your exposure to the VTuber space.




Are you up to speed with VTuber culture? Have you played Needy Streamer Overload yet? Are you looking for a waifu? Look no further than the VTuber industry.

TITLE: Elon Musk shared a photo of a virtual influencer in his "Twitter 2.0‚Äù vision slides. A virtual influencer is any digital character who has a 1st person personality on social media.
TEXT:
Elon Musk shared a photo of a virtual influencer in his "Twitter 2.0‚Äù vision slides. A virtual influencer is any digital character who has a 1st person personality on social media.

In the case of imma, the virtual woman referenced in Elon‚Äôs slide on Video, she first appeared on July 12, 2018 in Tokyo and now has 900k+ followers across the internet.

imma is the brainchild of Takayuki Moriyan's co Aww Inc. 

In my recent interview with imma, she told me that "In the end, I think identity is about what each person believes is real. I always think about who I am. Am I real? Am I fake? Am I not human? But there is no real truth that‚Äôs the same for every single person in this world."

On the internet, your identity is what you make it.

That's how it's been since the start, no matter what scrap-booking website Facebook tried to convince you about online identity in the early 2000s.

IRC, Forums, AIM, Xanga, MMOGs, Reddit, Tumblr, Yik Yak

Twitter is a modern sanctuary for pseudonymity. 

Entire pseudonymous communities burgeon on the platform, from NFT pfps to VTubers, all expressing themselves right alongside human identities‚Äîon an equal playing field.

Pseudonymity is the solution to many problems.

In a world that needs online privacy, data protection, digital expression, and freedom of speech, pseudonymity is necessary.

Any platform, tool, or company who facilitates pseudonymous expression will go far over the next decade‚Äîand Twitter is one of those platforms.




What do you think of Elon's vision for Twitter 2.0? Is Elon the right person to achieve this vision? Do you run a pseudonym?

TITLE: Can you believe this is 100% virtual and made by 1 person? Ian Hubert: lnkd.in/ez7uHuKP. Animation is permeating culture and turning the heads of Hollywood, investors, and streaming sites alike:
TEXT:
Can you believe this is 100% virtual and made by 1 person? Ian Hubert: lnkd.in/ez7uHuKP. Animation is permeating culture and turning the heads of Hollywood, investors, and streaming sites alike:

During the pandemic, love for animation spread within the film, television, social media, gaming, and livestreaming industries, manifesting in the form of virtual production, anime, virtual influencers, metaverse, and VTubing respectively.

Facing a recession, Hollywood executives and streaming services cut back on programming after years of unfettered growth, now optimizing for lowered production costs and investing more into virtual production (LED volumes) to achieve more with less.

Further, ongoing consumer, platform, and investor interests have aligned in a recent shift away from mid-budget films (2 hours in length) and instead towards either binge-worthy shows (10+ hours) or big-name blockbusters ($100M+ budget).

As a result, Hollywood now dabbles in virtual productions like The Mandalorian, Stark Trek: Strange New Worlds, Netflix's 1899, and more to answer to these widescale, high-stakes shifts.

However, virtual production has it's place‚Äîits a midpoint on the medium spectrum between two familiar endpoints: "animated" and "live action"

It's crucial to realize that the virtual production dot on this medium spectrum has an arrow pointing FROM "live action" and TOWARDS "animated" ...not the other way around.

In other words, virtual production's existence is a solution to live action and an admittance to the value of virtualization (animation).

This arrow tells the full story of where incentives originate, where budgets flow, and what Hollywood's future holds.

That future is virtual.

Affordable, accessible, animated storytelling for the masses. The death of live action. The pressure of short-form, exploded. The Creator Economy, matured.

The Hollywood regime, threatened.

A margin of profitability onset by obsessed technical artists realizing more efficient means of animated media production using real-time game engines from batcave-like bedrooms.

In the case of this 1-minute action sequence, legendary VFX artist Ian Hubert leveraged Blender to combine traditional keyframing, physics simulation, and Rokoko motion capture data... on his own.

There's your cocktail‚Äîand your proof.

Sets, cameras, lenses, lights, and more will someday be replaced by assets, bridges, engines, blueprints, viewports, and creative technologists like Ian "shooting" on computers with actors motion-captured‚ÄîWITHOUT dots all over their bodies.

Love, Death & Robots. Gantz: O. Arcane. Belle. Xanadu by cory strassburger. Hubert‚Äôs HyperBole! Countless video game cinematics. Animated storytelling... for adults. Animation... without the gloss, rainbows, and big eyes.

Computer creations‚Ä¶

Subscribe to Ian here: lnkd.in/eGkerq_p




What do you think about this?

TITLE: The Wall Street Journal called me to inform this piece on 'anonymous fame'‚ÄîHere are 10 key facts tech journalist¬†Ann-Marie Alc√°ntara honed from multiple primary sources:
TEXT:
The Wall Street Journal called me to inform this piece on 'anonymous fame'‚ÄîHere are 10 key facts tech journalist¬†Ann-Marie Alc√°ntara honed from multiple primary sources:


ON THE VTUBER INDUSTRY

1. Cartoons, anime characters, and digital pets are taking over Twitch as "virtual streamers" or "VTubers"‚Äîwithout revealing their faces or names.

2. VTuber derives from ‚Äúvirtual YouTuber‚Äù‚Äîsuch people use avatars or images to portray themselves online while keeping their offline identities mostly hidden.

3. Popular in Asia for some years, VTubing has only recently gained traction in the U.S.

4. Viewership for the VTubing category on Twitch has more than quadrupled from January to August of this year compared with the same time frame last year, says Twitch.

5. Full-time VTubers make money from Twitch (donations/subs), merchandise sales, brand sponsorships, and YouTube clips (+ more methods on more channels).


ON "WHY BE FAMOUS AND ANONYMOUS?"

6. VTubers say they can have a big online presence without the unpleasant side effects.

7. Some people have disabilities or chronic illnesses that prevent them from always looking or feeling camera-ready. VTubing can provide income for people with disabilities, since it doesn‚Äôt require people to physically look or act a certain way.

8. Some streamers say avatars help them preserve mental well-being.

9. Some people didn‚Äôt find an audience streaming as themselves, or found being on-camera tiring. 

10. Some people choose to stay incognito to avoid the harassment or negativity that many popular creators face.


Spot on coverage. Thank you Ann-Marie for shedding light on this part of the alt identity space and for seeking primary sources along the way, with banner art by the talented Rebekka Dunlap.

"Ann-Marie Alc√°ntara is a reporter covering internet culture... Her stories explore how our online experiences affect our real lives. Her work illuminates internet trends, the unexpected consequences of social media and the ways online behaviors shape how we see ourselves and others."




What are your thoughts on building influence as a pseudonym? Would you trust a pseudonymous media presence? How do you prescribe trust to everything else you consume in life? To be rich, famous, and anonymous...

TITLE: In my TEDx Talk (the link is in the comments), I talk a lot about dots. Dots, dots, dots. Why would I waste so much of my precious 18 minutes talking about dots?
TEXT:
In my TEDx Talk (the link is in the comments), I talk a lot about dots. Dots, dots, dots. Why would I waste so much of my precious 18 minutes talking about dots?
¬†
Because dots are the building blocks of #innovation, and innovation is an essential trait of a great leader.

So what are these dots? Anything and everything. Experiences. Ideas. People. Something you read. Someplace you visit. Someone you meet. Everything that comes into your world, into your awareness, is a dot. And when you connect two or more of these dots, there‚Äôs a little spark.

And that spark is called #creativity.

Now here‚Äôs the really cool part. The more of these dots you collect‚Äîthe more experiences, ideas, and people you have in your life‚Äîand the more different they are,¬†the more creative your #connections will be. That‚Äôs a really valuable attribute for a leader to have.
¬†
Because another cool thing about collecting lots of dots is that¬†when you have a lot of dots, patterns start to emerge. These patterns can help you see things the competition can‚Äôt see. That makes sense, doesn‚Äôt it? If you have a dot that your competitor doesn‚Äôt have, then that competitor can‚Äôt possibly make the same connection you can.
¬†
There‚Äôs a world-famous collection of dots in room 201 of the Art Institute of Chicago. These dots were put onto a canvas in 1884 by an artist named George Seurat. And when you take a step back to see the patterns, they form a painting called La Grande Jatte.
It‚Äôs a great painting, but it‚Äôs also a great reminder of how dots really work.
¬†
See, when you look at the dots up close, individually, they don‚Äôt seem to relate to each other. There‚Äôs a blue dot next to a yellow dot. Over there is a black dot, and a green one.
¬†
Now, again, think of the experiences, the ideas, and the people in your life as individual dots.
¬†
There‚Äôs your Uber driver, and your 12-year-old niece, and that time you got lost in Ireland, and that article you once read about why shoelaces untie themselves. Separately, these all seem entirely unrelated‚Äîand they are. But you collect enough of these dots, and all of a sudden, patterns start to reveal themselves. And ten years later your niece invents self-tying shoelaces with a built in GPS that will automatically call an Uber driver if you get lost.
¬†
As a #leader, then, you owe it to yourself, your team, and your organization to collect as many disparate dots as you can. Read voraciously. Talk to lots of people. Travel. Because you never know which obscure dot is going to be the billion-dollar answer to your million-dollar challenge.

TITLE: ChatGPT is a horrible product.
TEXT:
ChatGPT is a horrible product.

But don‚Äôt take my word for it‚Äîbecause those aren‚Äôt my words.

They were said by Sam Altman, the CEO of the company that developed ChatGPT, just a couple of weeks ago.

Now, why on earth would a CEO say that his own product is ‚Äúhorrible‚Äù?

Because he‚Äôs not afraid of what author Anne Lamott calls the ‚Äúsh**ty first draft.‚Äù

As he said in the interview from which that quotation was taken (and I‚Äôm paraphrasing here), ‚ÄúWhat you‚Äôre seeing right now is not even version 1.0 of #ChatGPT. It‚Äôs more like version 0.7.‚Äù

And this, my friends, is how you do innovation in the 21st century.

Now, I‚Äôm not saying you should release a ‚Äúhorrible product.‚Äù (Particularly if your product is, say, a self-driving car, a robotic surgery device, or a commercial airliner.)

What I AM saying is that, in most cases, you don‚Äôt have to wait for perfection in order to introduce your product or service to the world. Because if that‚Äôs your threshold, you‚Äôll be eating cat food next to your beautiful‚Äîbut still ‚Äúnot quite ready‚Äù‚Äîversion 3.4 while you watch the person who released version 0.7 become a billionaire.

So go ahead‚Äîrelease your minimum viable product. Release Version ‚ÄúGood Enough for Now.‚Äù And then listen as the universe tells you how to improve it.

Welcome to 21st century #innovation.


I work at the intersection of #leadership, innovation, and #transformation. If that‚Äôs where you and your team want to live, we should have a conversation. DM me and we‚Äôll set something up.

TITLE: I have an idea‚Äîand a question‚Äîfor credit union leaders.
TEXT:
I have an idea‚Äîand a question‚Äîfor credit union leaders.

Over the past several weeks, I‚Äôve been putting together a program specifically designed to help credit union leaders and their teams think differently about their credit union, their members, and their industry. I‚Äôve spoken to many of you about your challenges and your opportunities.

And I have a thought I‚Äôd like to share with you today.

Historically, credit unions were built around the idea of community. Member ownership. The personal touch.

And while the huge advances in digital technology have made transactional banking more convenient, they‚Äôve done so at the expense of that personal touch that set credit unions apart. When fewer members ever even set foot into a physical CU branch, it becomes more difficult to put a human face to the ‚Äúcommunity‚Äù credit union.

Kind of tough to establish and maintain a personal touch without a human face behind it, don‚Äôt you think?

So my idea, wrapped up in a question, is this: How could you incorporate video to better serve your members, and prospective members?

What if you were to create a personal 2-minute video each week giving a financial‚Äîor even non-financial‚Äîtip or message to your community?

No razzle-dazzle. No flashy graphics. No bombastic music. Just you, talking to your community? Creating a connection.

The personal touch.

Your mission this week, should you choose to accept it, is this. Get together with your team for 40 minutes and play with this question: What are five ways that we could use short videos, on a weekly basis, to re-establish a personal touch‚Äîa human connection‚Äîwith our community?

I have other ideas for you as well. If you‚Äôre interested, send me a direct message, and let‚Äôs chat.


#creditunions #leadership #thinkingdifferently #credituniondifference

TITLE: I thought about taking a nap yesterday.
TEXT:
I thought about taking a nap yesterday.

That‚Äôs because I caught a cold last week, and I‚Äôve been feeling a little lethargic.

So I thought about taking a nap.

Here‚Äôs the weird part. After thinking about taking a nap, I didn‚Äôt feel any more refreshed.

So rather than just THINKING about taking a nap, I DECIDED to take a nap.

That‚Äôs right. I made a DECISION.

And here‚Äôs where it gets even weirder. Even after making a DECISION to take a nap, I still didn‚Äôt feel any more refreshed.

I know, right?

I was confused by this, and that confusion tired me out.

So I took a nap.

And you know what? I FELT MORE REFRESHED AFTERWARD!

Now, I realize that some of you might want to take this nice little story and turn it into some sort of metaphor for your own personal and professional life. You know, like, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not growing the business I want, even though I‚Äôve thought about it a lot, and even decided to do something about it. What am I missing?‚Äù

If that‚Äôs what you want to do, go ahead and TAKE THAT ACTION. I can‚Äôt stop you.

Besides, I‚Äôm too busy thinking about writing a book.

*****

When I‚Äôm not napping, I help forward-thinking leaders and their teams think differently about their business so that they can see new opportunities and possibilities. I‚Äôve got some ideas for you; message me if you‚Äôre interested.

#productivity #decisionmaking #takingaction #professionalgrowth

TITLE: Full disclosure: I have never been pregnant.
TEXT:
Full disclosure: I have never been pregnant.

Having said that, I‚Äôm going to go out on a limb and suggest that there are not many pregnant women who could pull off a Super Bowl halftime show.

And I say THAT because I‚Äôve read a few reviews this morning that seem to think Rihanna‚Äôs performance yesterday was‚Äîand I‚Äôm going to paraphrase here‚Äî‚Äúmeh.‚Äù

As a guy who thinks a lot about thinking differently, I‚Äôm wondering: Is it time to rethink our approach to entertainment?

Look, I‚Äôm nobody‚Äôs idea of Rihanna‚Äôs target market. I‚Äôm not very familiar with her work. But what I saw yesterday was an extremely talented woman with a great voice singing very good songs.

Also, she‚Äôs pregnant.

And somehow that‚Äôs not enough.

Because, somehow, we‚Äôve gotten to a place where spectacle trumps substance.

This is also true of our approach to politics.

We vote for the most entertaining candidate, not the most qualified.

Everything is a show, and the more flamboyant, the more outrageous, the more explosive, the better.

We‚Äôre a nation in constant search of the next cocaine hit.

Maybe it‚Äôs time for a reset.

In my professional life, I help leaders and their teams think differently about their business. Now I‚Äôm suggesting that maybe we start thinking differently about entertainment as well.

What do you think?

#rihanna #superbowl2023 #halftimeshow #thinkingdifferently

TITLE: I find myself saying this constantly, to both my audiences and to my private clients:
TEXT:
I find myself saying this constantly, to both my audiences and to my private clients:

‚ÄúInnovation‚Äù is not a ‚Äúprivate club of cool kids‚Äù to which you do not belong!

It‚Äôs not like being one of the jocks in high school (which WAS a private club of cool kids to which I did not belong).

Innovation is for everyone.

Including you.

But too often‚Äîparticularly in the corporate world‚ÄîI encounter people who say things like, ‚ÄúOh, I work in Accounts Receivable. The innovators are in the marketing department.‚Äù

Yes, I have no doubt that there are innovators in the marketing department.

But here‚Äôs the secret: there are also innovators in Accounts Receivable. And Legal. And HR. And every other department, branch, and division of your company.

Because #innovation is nothing more than coming up with new ways to solve problems.

And anyone can be a problem solver.

Anyone can look at a situation and think, ‚ÄúHow can this be better?‚Äù

You don‚Äôt need special skills. You don‚Äôt need special training. You don‚Äôt need a special degree.

There is no secret handshake.

Yes, innovation is for the ‚Äúgifted few.‚Äù But here‚Äôs the truth:

We are ALL the ‚Äúgifted few.‚Äù

Welcome to the club.

I work with forward-thinking leaders who want to leverage the innate innovation that already exists within their teams. If you‚Äôd like some ideas about how you can start doing that TODAY, drop me a message and let‚Äôs chat.


#thinkingdifferently #leadership #problemsolving

TITLE: There‚Äôs an energy that‚Äôs generated when you ask smart people interesting questions.
TEXT:
There‚Äôs an energy that‚Äôs generated when you ask smart people interesting questions.

You see their eyes light up. You can almost hear their brains shift into high gear. You feel their engagement elevate.

I see this every time I work with a team, whether it‚Äôs in-person or virtual.

You‚Äôve seen it too, right?

So let me ask YOU a question:

Why aren‚Äôt you asking YOUR smart people more interesting questions?

As leaders, we tend to ask the same questions of our teams:

¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†How can we increase profits?
¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†How can we decrease costs?
¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†How can we sell more widgets?

And look, these are important questions. But they‚Äôre just not that interesting. And even worse, we ask these same #questions over and over and over again‚Äîand we wonder why we‚Äôre not getting more creative, more innovative answers.

You want more innovative answers? Ask more innovative questions.

Questions that excite smart people. Questions that stimulate deep #thinking. Questions that make YOUR team say, ‚ÄúWow‚ÄîI‚Äôve never looked at it that way before!‚Äù

I‚Äôm finding, more and more, that this is the area of my work that‚Äôs proving to be the most valuable to my clients and their teams.

What are some of YOUR favorite questions? Drop them in the comments below so we can all benefit.

And if you're interested in having me work with your team, let‚Äôs schedule a quick chat. The link is in the comments.

#teamengagement #innovation

TITLE: ‚ÄúWhat are you doing?‚Äù the CEO asked a C-level exec.
TEXT:
‚ÄúWhat are you doing?‚Äù the CEO asked a C-level exec.

‚ÄúThinking.‚Äù

‚ÄúWell stop it. Get back to work.‚Äù

My guess is that, upon reading that, you had one of two reactions:

1.¬†¬†¬†¬†I don‚Äôt believe that would really happen.
2.¬†¬†¬†¬†How do you know my CEO?

The sad truth is that the above dialog, while not universal, is not unusual.

We don‚Äôt value thinking.

Or, to put it another way, we value DOING over THINKING.

What we seem to have forgotten is that ‚Äúthinking‚Äù IS ‚Äúdoing.‚Äù

Now, if you‚Äôre saying, ‚ÄúBill, that may be true for the other riff-raff reading this, but I for one DO value thinking,‚Äù let me ask you one question:

How much time do you have scheduled on your calendar next week just for thinking?

My guess‚Äîand this is just a guess, mind you‚Äîis that the answer is somewhere between zero and naught.

Peter Drucker once said, ‚ÄúTell me what you value and I might believe you. But show me your calendar and your bank statement, and I‚Äôll show you what you really value.‚Äù

Thinking is the most important skill we have. And yet we rarely practice it, and almost never schedule time for it.

Think about that.


I work with leaders and teams that want to think better, and think differently, about their business. If that intrigues you, message me and we‚Äôll chat.

#thinking #calendar #leadership #thinkdifferently

TITLE: My Favorite Landing Page Formula
TEXT:
My Favorite Landing Page Formula


A landing page is a standalone page that a person "land" on after clicking from an email, ad or other digital creation...

Got that?

Here is how I write landing page that converts for my clients...

First, Whether you're selling a digital products, a physical products, services or whatsoever

You need a landing page.

But after studying 100s of landing pages, I've noticed 93% sucks. A lot!

They're awful at

=> Connecting with the right emotion

=> Being specific

=> Saying what exactly they do etc.

But as a copywriter who's worked on series of landing pages... here is a proven framework that I always use...

1. A Headline with value

Make sure your headline has some sort of value attached to it. 

This can be anything from a specific feature about what your product does (like "The only thing that compares to [product name] is [competing product name]")...

To a more general benefit like 

"We'll get your money back in 6 months" or "You'll save $X on this purchase." 

Just make sure whatever you write has some kind of value!

2. A more specific subheadline

Next, we want to make sure our subheadline is crystal clear about what we want the user to do next (or how they can benefit from using our product). 

A good example of this is using ‚ÄúGet started now!‚Äù ü§î over ‚ÄúTake action now!‚Äù because the latter phrase might be too vague for some users.

3.  A value based CTA. 

"Get started now, Learn more, Buy now" are action based CTA not value based

You can make your CTA more value driven... 

For example Gumroad uses "Start selling" Instead of "Get started"

4. Social proof:

Credibility backs up your promise.

People like seeing other people who have already signed up for your service or product‚Äîit makes them feel like they're part of a tribe!

A final note.

When you follow this simple but effective framework, you'd convert more visitors into buyers...

But you still need to do your research to know your auidence... 

What gives her sleepless night and how you can help her overcome the problem.

That's it. 

Hope you got value?

#copywriters #salesandmarketing #mondayinspiratiion
