TITLE: 6 Crucial Lessons I've Learned in 5yrs of Sales
TEXT:
6 Crucial Lessons I've Learned in 5yrs of Sales


No messing around. Straight to the point.

1. Don't create a product before looking for customers instead look for a starving market, look for a need and then  create a business around it.

2. Sell what people WANT to buy... Not necessarily what they NEED to buy

Don't know the difference? Here is it...

Needs are things that are essential and are a necessity while Wants are things people will love to own or experience 

For example... food is a consumer need. However, a chicken burger is considered a consumer want, as it is not necessary in order to live.

You grab?

3. Don't be jack of all trades and try to sell everything to everyone instead be a master of ONE before investing in another.

4. The money is in the follow up: 

80% of sales are made after the 5th contact.

Be relentless at follow up but don't over do it so as not to come across as desperate.

5. You must takes the risk away from customers:

People are afraid that they'll regret buying something

So you have to take the risk away from them and put it on yours

You can do this by offering a guarantee.

6. There'll be bad days

Low sales days

Rejection days etc.

It doesn't matter that much

What do matter is how you react to them.

That's it! It's not that sexy

But you can always scale through.

Hope you find this helpful? Nice! Drop me a comment below.

Happy weekend ü•≥ü•≥

#salesandmarketing #copywriter #myfryaypost

TITLE: "Life is essentially an endless series of problems."
TEXT:
"Life is essentially an endless series of problems."


I entered the year, feeling very unmotivated

Because I had a major blow in business late last year

I'd be joking if I tell you it didn't have a bad effect on me. 

But then, I realized that, the more I wallow in it 

The more the wounds get dipper.

Now here is it...

"The solution to one problem is merely the Creation of another"

It's an endless cycle.

My point is, "don't hope for a life without problems

There's no such thing, instead hope for a life full of good problems"

Yeah, 

To be happy we need something solve

Life itself get extremely boring without problems

Happiness is therefore a form of action.

So, don't believe that there's nothing you can do to solve your problems

In fact, don't try to put the blame on somebody else

It may make you feel better but just in the short term.

Own it up, accept it, take responsibility

And find ways to solve it.

In my case that was what I did

It took me some time to figure it out

But... It's all I've got and needed.

So this new month, I want you to know that....

"Happiness is a constant work-in-progress because solving problems is a constant work-in-progress

The solution to today's problems will lay foundation to the next problems"

It's how you react to it that will determine the end result.

Be good and don't hope for a life without problems

You'll never have one.

Happy new month ‚ù§Ô∏èü•≥

#business #happiness  #newmonthinsights 

Credit: Mark Manson

TITLE: How To Genuinely Get People's Attention
TEXT:
How To Genuinely Get People's Attention 

A few years ago, when I got accepted for my HND program.

I got to class a few minutes earlier for our first lecture. 

But as soon as I entered the classroom, something caught my eye. 

It was a beautiful dark-skinned girl. 

The moment I saw her, my heart skipped a beat 

That moment I knew we were going to get along well. (Yoruba demon vibes hahaha üòÇ)

Instead of going straight up to her and trying to impress her like every other dude...

I decided to keep my cool... Younno üòÉ

I focused my attention on the class activities and regaled my friends with funny relatable stories about my ND days

My friends found my stories quite amusing, and soon enough, everyone was paying attention to me...

Including the girl... 

Her smile alone was the turning point for me. Lol

It was then that I realized something. 

If you genuinely want to win people's attention and make a good impression

Don't create your content for the purpose of winning their attention

Yes!

You just have to bring out your best self, and the rest will take care of itself. 

And that's exactly what happened here. 

I got the girl's attention without even trying, and the rest, as they say, is history.

So listen, it's not about the trends, the algorithm or whatever any bloody guru must have told you

Although they contribute 

But most times, It's about being your real self

Being entertaining and...

Forgetting about the great marketing hacks you inherited from great grandfathers.

Soon enough, they'll start to notice you.

Don't complicate it... 

Be real... It's not every time you try to model someone or do what someone is doing

Try to do yours... Your own way!

 #marketing #content #copywriter #tuesdaytipsandvibes

TITLE: No Niche‚ùìNo Money
TEXT:
No Niche‚ùìNo Money


When I started, the difference between the money I want to make and the money I made was not something one could say out publicly

It was like wanting a Lamborghini Aventador and ending up with an evil possessed 2003 Toyota Camry. ü•∫ü•∫

In short, I used to make very little money

Like I used to be a content writer, a copywriter a digital marketer and whatever the F I think I can pull. Loll

I believe so much in myself.

There wasn't any difference between me and every other average marketing guy out there

But then I decided to focus only on copywriting (and I only take on specific copywriting projects)

Today, people pay me more

And some even call me the copy prodigy ü§†ü§†

Well, a client actually called me that after a FB Ad copy I wrote for him pulled in more sales than he could imagine.

Enough of the hype.

Here's the gist:

To make more money you need to pick a niche

Don't be just about everything... (Content writer, copywriter, lead gen expert, digital marketer etc.) in one bio üò≥

A lot of LinkedIn profiles are like that and it confuses the hell out of your potential clients.

According to James Clear in his book Atomic Habits:

The more you master a SPECIFIC skill

The harder it becomes for other people to compete with you

Even if you're not the most naturally gifted 

You can often win by being in a very narrow category.

My beautiful friend Jummai - The Content Mistress always rings this to my ears every time as well. ü§†ü§†

By niching down you have a good chance of winning

But only if you try.

So you can start by asking yourself

"What are the problems & goals my ideal client has?"

"What am I good at and would like to do for the rest of my life?"

The answer to this is where your niche is.

You can even take it further by being ultra specific.

Makes a lot of sense. 

What do you think?

 #marketing #sales #nichemarket #tuesdaytipz

TITLE: Beware of those jobs that give you the salary and title but rob you of everything else
TEXT:
Beware of those jobs that give you the salary and title but rob you of everything else

4 months ago, I had to quit a job that I think I love on this basis

Not only was the environment not conducive for me...

Mhen, I was verbally abused on a consistent basis ü•∫

At some point, I wanted to go crazy. Lol.

(Would not like to go into details though)

But you see, 

If your job does not make your day-to-day life better

Then you should use the EXIT door

Salary is just one piece of success - don't lose yourself because of it.

Bottom Line is value yourself.

Don't sell your soul for a job where you try to give everything

But only get nothing in the end.

Since resigning, I don't have their salary but I have my mental health

I've gone for what I love

Being in the path to & living a life of fulfilment

Not a life of bondage

And that's what I call success. ü§óü§ó

Happy weekend ü•≥

 #mentalhealth #job #fabfridaypost

TITLE: Struggling to close more sales?
TEXT:
Struggling to close more sales?


Here are some reasons why it feels impossible for you to make more sales 

1. Quality of Leads:

Simply put,
Poor quality leads = reduced sales
High quality leads = Increase in sales 

Poor leads are people who need your products but don't necessarily want it

While quality leads are people who want your product and have a strong desire for it.

2. Lack of trust:

I used to tell my clients,

Every buying decision is like a gamble

People are afraid that they'll regret buying something

So you need to help them better understand that buying from you is the smartest and safest option to fulfill their needs and solve their problems

You do this through testimonials and recommendations from experts.

3. You're selling the process not the solution:

Again, nobody cares about your products and services

When you open, when you close, the quality of your staff...

How long it took you to be where you are and all those craps

The only thing they care about is the possibilities your products can make for them

Instead of saying: The XYZ car delivers 55miles per gallon in the city

Say: You'll save money on gas & cut down on environmental pollution when you use our energy saving high performance hybrid car.

You get the gist right?

When you're not making as many sales as you'd like

Understanding where things are going wrong first is key!

You can send a DM to find out how I can be of help to you.

Enjoy!

 #salesandmarketing #copywriter #thursdaythoughtsandvibes

TITLE: Everyone in the multifamily industry's new favorite topic: Expense control. It's a major theme for 2023, and this chart shows why. First: Look at insurance: Up 17% -- seventeen percent -- in U.S. apartment properties in 2022 versus 2021, and it's going to leap up again 2023. In some markets in Florida, Texas and California, the increases exceeded 20%.
TEXT:
Everyone in the multifamily industry's new favorite topic: Expense control. It's a major theme for 2023, and this chart shows why. First: Look at insurance: Up 17% -- seventeen percent -- in U.S. apartment properties in 2022 versus 2021, and it's going to leap up again 2023. In some markets in Florida, Texas and California, the increases exceeded 20%.

Also big expense increases in turnover costs -- and that combines both a) higher costs for materials and labor plus b) more turnover... which will be an even bigger factor in 2023, and therefore a big reason to focus on resident retention (especially given the uncertain demand outlook plus the upcoming spike in supply). Simply put: Turnover is more expensive than ever. Operators are shifting into occupancy/cashflow protection mode.

And big expense gains in utilities, maintenance and payroll. Staffing and payroll remain major pain points and operational focus areas. Three years since COVID hit, operators are still struggling to hire and retain top talent. Industry leaders are working to control payroll costs through centralization -- which empowers on-site teams to do what they do best (lease units and serve residents), while automating or centralizing back-office tasks.

Marketing was lower growth for 2022, but it's increasing in recent months as operators try to stir up leasing traffic. We're also seeing a lot more focus on driving marketing efficiencies via smart digital marketing tied to leasing and pricing strategy. Market what you need -- when and where you need it.

#multifamily #opex #apartments #CRE

TITLE: I love this idea. I wonder how many mall developers/investors (in hindsight) of years past now wish they had included apartments atop or adjacent to their malls. Seems like a win/win idea -- giving renters walkable access to shopping and giving malls more life / foot traffic. Of course, it also would surprise me if many cities allowed it -- preferring more mattress stores over actual heads in beds.
TEXT:
I love this idea. I wonder how many mall developers/investors (in hindsight) of years past now wish they had included apartments atop or adjacent to their malls. Seems like a win/win idea -- giving renters walkable access to shopping and giving malls more life / foot traffic. Of course, it also would surprise me if many cities allowed it -- preferring more mattress stores over actual heads in beds.

Very few traditional malls offer true live/work/play experience, and I would bet those that do have fared better than those that offer only retail shopping and a food court. In recent years, developers have incorporated apartments into mixed-use developments featuring outdoor shopping as opposed to enclosed malls, but I don't see why apartments couldn't work in the latter if done right.

So the question now is: How do you most effectively add apartments into an existing mall to add life to it? My thought: You'd have to go big. Adding a 200-unit apartment building in a mega mall parking lot probably wouldn't do much, so you'd have to be very thoughtful about the scale/placement of apartments that would add the desired effect on mall retail.

#apartments #malls #multifamily #development
CONTENT_TITLE: By Adding Apartments, Malls Seek to Bring Shopping Closer to Home

TITLE: What are the apartment markets most at risk for potential distress? Debt analytics firm Trepp put out a top 10 "to watch" list. If you expected to see a lot of Sun Belt markets on the list due to the boom of the past few years, you wouldn't be alone in that thinking. But Trepp would say you're wrong. Instead, Trepp's report highlights higher risk in major coastal markets and in a few of the big Midwest markets. The only Sun Belt market to make Trepp's top 10? Houston.
TEXT:
What are the apartment markets most at risk for potential distress? Debt analytics firm Trepp put out a top 10 "to watch" list. If you expected to see a lot of Sun Belt markets on the list due to the boom of the past few years, you wouldn't be alone in that thinking. But Trepp would say you're wrong. Instead, Trepp's report highlights higher risk in major coastal markets and in a few of the big Midwest markets. The only Sun Belt market to make Trepp's top 10? Houston.

Of course, this doesn't mean every or even most investors in these markets will be distressed. Note that most deals are longer-term holds financed long prior to 2022. This list is only signaling potential risk of distress, and barring a black swan event, distress should be more the exception than the rule -- and particularly centered around highly leveraged recent acquisitions with floating debt coming due at much higher rates than initially projected.

The top 10 list includes (not in order) the coastal giants of San Francisco and San Jose, New York, Seattle, plus Midwest markets of St. Louis, Chicago, Minneapolis, Detroit and Kansas City. 

What do you think of the list? There are a few surprises to me. Most notably, I'm optimistic on the Sun Belt overall, but I am surprised Phoenix didn't make the list. (Although Lonnie Hendry, Jr. told me that if CRE CLO loans were included, Phoenix might have been ranked.) 

St. Louis is a pretty big surprise at the top, but I was unaware that >14% of deals already have debt service coverage ratios below 1%. Kansas City was also surprising to me, though it appears KC is included only because of the big volume of 2022 deals (which likely become distressed only if investors used short-term debt).

I'm less surprised by coastal metros, as I've been making the point for years that these markets are not truly "core" anymore from a textbook definition -- only by the standards of old traditions. (For the record, I'm not anti-coastal, but just of the view that most would be more correctly classified as "opportunistic.") Per Trepp, declining cashflow is becoming problematic particularly in the Bay Area.

Trepp's methodology looks at securitized Freddie Mac loans, and is weighted based on occupancy, DSCR, net cash flow, and the share of loans (of total) originated in the first nine months of 2022. Link to the full report is in the comments.

#multifamily #capitalmarkets #multifamilyinvesting #CRE

TITLE: Do you ever wonder why there's a major disconnect in rent-to-income reporting between what rental housing operators say and what some outside researchers say? Well, if you're a cynic, you could claim operators just make up the numbers. But a clear-eyed view shows the truth: Most outside research oversimplifies the analysis. Now, to be clear, there is a real affordability challenge: We need a lot more low-income housing to keep up with demand. But this is not the same thing as the ability of current market-rate renters to pay rent (and that's why rent collections consistently measure ~96%).
TEXT:
Do you ever wonder why there's a major disconnect in rent-to-income reporting between what rental housing operators say and what some outside researchers say? Well, if you're a cynic, you could claim operators just make up the numbers. But a clear-eyed view shows the truth: Most outside research oversimplifies the analysis. Now, to be clear, there is a real affordability challenge: We need a lot more low-income housing to keep up with demand. But this is not the same thing as the ability of current market-rate renters to pay rent (and that's why rent collections consistently measure ~96%).

There are 4 big reasons why most outside research, including one earlier this month from a leading economic data provider, show rent-to-income ratios >30% -- much higher than the low 20% range you'll see reported from publicly traded apartment and SFR REITs (as well as from RealPage and others using lease-level data).

1) Some researchers lean on an "apples and oranges" analysis -- meaning they'll mix private-sector rent reporting (i.e. Zillow) with government data on incomes. The problem? Private-sector data providers, like website listings, tend to be skewed toward more expensive, professionally managed rentals more likely to advertise online. Meanwhile, government data on incomes represents a much broader population. When you combine the two, it grossly inflates the rent-to-income ratio.

2) The reality is that more expensive rentals attract renters with higher incomes, which keeps the median rent-to-income ratio in the low 20% range. One reason this is missed is because it's very difficult for outside researchers (even the Census) to accurately track non-family roommate households, which represent a huge share of multifamily renters. For example, picture two 26-year-olds making $60k/year renting a new 2-bedroom apartment for $2,200/month. Individually, it'd take 44% of income to rent the unit. Together, it's 22%. This is remarkably common yet too often ignored reality of rental affordability.

3) Additionally, millions of renters receive vouchers or access to low-income housing programs that lock in the rent at ~30% of income. (Of course, these programs need to be vastly expanded as demand > supply.) This is a massive nuance that oversimplified outside analyses rarely account for.

4) Just like applying for a mortgage or an auto loan etc., nearly all property managers conduct affordability analyses (of varying types) to ensure the renter is able to pay the rent, and this helps prevent a mass unaffordability scenario.

The only accurate way to do accurate reporting on rent-to-income ratios is to look at the actual incomes and rent among the households actually renting units. Take the ratio for each household, then capture the median ratio. When you do that, you'll find the ratios are much lower than what is reported. That's what we did here.

#multifamily #SFR #housing

TITLE: Here's a fascinating chart from the great Rick Palacios Jr. highlighting an important trend that is widely misunderstood in the single-family rental market. This shows the share of home purchases by SFR portfolio size, and while large institutional investors get 99% of the attention (and blame), they represent a low single-digit share of purchases in Phoenix -- and even that was one of the hottest institutional SFR markets over the last cycle.
TEXT:
Here's a fascinating chart from the great Rick Palacios Jr. highlighting an important trend that is widely misunderstood in the single-family rental market. This shows the share of home purchases by SFR portfolio size, and while large institutional investors get 99% of the attention (and blame), they represent a low single-digit share of purchases in Phoenix -- and even that was one of the hottest institutional SFR markets over the last cycle.

Rick and the team at Johns Burns Real Estate Consulting show that investors with >1,000 homes in their portfolios represented only 1.4% of home sales in Phoenix in Q4, and their share peaked around 5% previously. If you add in portfolios with 100-999 homes, you add another 1% or so. (I would exclude iBuyers simply because most of those homes are flipped back to homebuyers, not put into the long-term rental pool. And btw, also note from this chart that when you exclude iBuyers, SFR investors actually claimed a lower share of total home purchases in almost every quarter of this last cycle compared to what they did back in 2009-2012.)

That means -- which everyone who tracks SFR already knows -- that small local investors continue to dominate the single-family rental market ... not only in Phoenix, but everywhere. Investors with 9 or fewer homes continuously represent >20% of all home purchases there, according to the top-notch research team at JBREC.

Somehow small "mom and pop" investors slide below the media radar while the bigger shops (with a tiny fraction of market share) grab all the headlines -- and all the public/policymaker angst. I'm certainly not suggesting they deserve any blame, as SFR investors of all types provide single-family homes to renters who may not otherwise be able to buy in those neighborhoods. Both home purchase and home renting have their place, and I'm a big believer in "both/and" not "either/or."

But if you do have frustration with single-family rental investors (even if misguided), you should have 20x more angst toward "mom and pop" local investors than toward large institutional investors.

#SFR #housing #rentalhousing

TITLE: Here‚Äôs a critical indicator that renters will see renewal rent increases cool off significantly ‚Äì and quickly ‚Äì this year, leading to a) more competition for renters, b) more renter turnover, and c) challenges for value-add investors dependent on large rent trade-outs. This charts shows ‚Äúloss-to-lease‚Äù ‚Äì the discount an average in-place renter receives versus today‚Äôs market rent for new renters. As a general rule of thumb: The larger the loss-to-lease, the larger the renewal increase. We saw large renewal rent hikes in 2022 as operators tried to bring renewal leases closer to market.
TEXT:
Here‚Äôs a critical indicator that renters will see renewal rent increases cool off significantly ‚Äì and quickly ‚Äì this year, leading to a) more competition for renters, b) more renter turnover, and c) challenges for value-add investors dependent on large rent trade-outs. This charts shows ‚Äúloss-to-lease‚Äù ‚Äì the discount an average in-place renter receives versus today‚Äôs market rent for new renters. As a general rule of thumb: The larger the loss-to-lease, the larger the renewal increase. We saw large renewal rent hikes in 2022 as operators tried to bring renewal leases closer to market.

But much has changed since June 2022, when loss-to-lease measured 10.1%. New lease market rents cooled off in the second half of 2022, ending the year with four straight month-over-month cuts followed by a flat number in January. Meanwhile, renewals ‚Äì which are often priced 60-120 days in advance ‚Äì continued to play catch up. As a result, loss-to-lease is plunging just as fast as it soared upward.

Now the loss-to-lease discount has plunged to 3.3% as of January. That‚Äôs actually below the long-term norm of 4.5%. (It‚Äôs critical to acknowledge there is almost always some loss to lease because there‚Äôs usually a discount for renewals relative to new leases, as operators often incentivize renewals in order to reduce turnover costs, reward good residents, and protect occupancy. A widespread ‚Äúgain to lease‚Äù scenario is unlikely as we'd have what‚Äôs called ‚Äúinverted rents‚Äù ‚Äì incentivizing renters to move from one unit to another at the same apartment property.)

Here are possible implications:

1)¬†Renters renewing their leases today are doing so usually based on terms agreed to 2-3 months ago, when loss-to-lease was still above average. But renewal offer letters going out now are likely much more conservative, as property managers are intently focused right now on retention and occupancy ‚Äì especially given rising vacancy and the uncertain new-lease demand outlook. In other words: It's much harder today to backfill a vacant unit, and since there's no cashflow on a vacant unit, retention becomes even more important.

2)¬†More turnover.¬†Historically, renter turnover is higher when loss-to-lease is lower. Why? Because when turnover plunged in 2021-22, most renters saw their best deal was usually to stay put. Most were still getting sizable discounts relative to a new renter. In a low loss-to-lease scenario, that discount is much smaller ‚Äì and when renters study their options, they are more likely to see attractively priced alternatives this year than they would have in 2021-22.

3)¬†Most operators will adapt ‚Äì and even eagerly adopt ‚Äì lower-priced renewals to focus on occupancy and cashflow in 2023. But value-add investors could be in a tougher spot, particularly those with short-term investment periods facing a double whammy of below-pro forma rent trade-outs and above-pro forma interest rates. We‚Äôll see how it plays out.

#multifamily #apartments #rentalhousing #CPI #inflation

TITLE: As expected, apartment renters began moving around more in January 2023 -- with retention rates dropping back to the long-term seasonal norm. More available supply + cooling rents = incentive for renter mobility/turnover to increase, and we expect that'll accelerate throughout 2023. Indeed, apartment leasing also showed signs of improvement in January, but at least a chunk of that appears to stem from musical chairs.
TEXT:
As expected, apartment renters began moving around more in January 2023 -- with retention rates dropping back to the long-term seasonal norm. More available supply + cooling rents = incentive for renter mobility/turnover to increase, and we expect that'll accelerate throughout 2023. Indeed, apartment leasing also showed signs of improvement in January, but at least a chunk of that appears to stem from musical chairs.

Recent history on retention leading to where we are now:

1) Retention rates skyrocketed during the lockdowns, briefly plunged back to normal in the second half of 2020, and then shot up again throughout 2021-2022.

2) Interestingly, renters renewed leases most frequently when rent growth was at peak levels -- as it was often cheaper to renew than relocate, plus ultra-low vacancies meant there were few attractive alternatives (in any housing type, not just apartments).

3) Front-door leasing traffic stalled out in the second half of 2022 despite strong job growth and strong income growth. Demand for all types of housing essentially froze up due to low consumer confidence. People were waiting it out, even if they were secure in jobs, and renters already in place continued to renew at high frequency.

4) The lack of front-door leasing plus growing new supply levels led to vacancy rates quickly rising from record lows in early 2022 to healthier, more normal levels a year later. That prompted four straight months of unusually large new lease rent cuts (month-over-month) and a flat rent number for January (a period where we typically see modest growth). 

5) And as a result of rising availability and cooling rents, renters now have a lot more options. Unlike in 2021 and 2022, renters facing lease renewals are seeing more attractively priced alternatives. That encourages relocations.

6) I know some folks are itching to rush to judgment that retention is dropping because of affordability challenges, but the data doesn't back that up (not yet anyway). Rent collections actually improved about 50 bps year-over-year and they're back around pre-COVID levels (in market-rate apartments). Additionally, household incomes among new lease signers (many of whom we know were relocating from other apartments) jumped 6% YoY, which was >100 bps above new lease rent growth.

Every apartment operator I talk to is laser focused on keeping current renters and luring in new renters right now. Occupancy = cashflow, and therefore protecting occupancy is critical in a time when new-lease demand is uncertain and new supply is plentiful. 

Renewal rent pricing is going to come down quickly as the gap between new-lease rents and in-place rents has shrunk remarkably quickly. There is no longer a big loss-to-lease gap.

All that means, as we've been saying for a while now, is that the balance of power in the rental market has shifted back in favor of renters.

#apartments #multifamily #rentalhousing #rent

TITLE: Housing is a hot topic nationally, but didn‚Äôt get much attention last night in President Biden‚Äôs State of the Union address. In a speech with more than 7,200 words lasting 1 hour and 13 minutes, here was the single, 20-word line on rental housing: ‚ÄúHelping veterans afford their rent because no one should be homeless in this country, especially not those who served it.‚Äù (I‚Äôll co-sign that.) And here was the one other sentence on housing more broadly: ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs also finish the job and get more families access to affordable and quality housing.‚Äù (Co-sign that, too.)
TEXT:
Housing is a hot topic nationally, but didn‚Äôt get much attention last night in President Biden‚Äôs State of the Union address. In a speech with more than 7,200 words lasting 1 hour and 13 minutes, here was the single, 20-word line on rental housing: ‚ÄúHelping veterans afford their rent because no one should be homeless in this country, especially not those who served it.‚Äù (I‚Äôll co-sign that.) And here was the one other sentence on housing more broadly: ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs also finish the job and get more families access to affordable and quality housing.‚Äù (Co-sign that, too.)

The lack of rental housing talk got me thinking‚Ä¶ If I could imagine a (total fantasy) scenario where I got to serve as the President‚Äôs policy advisor on the speech, what would I want to include? This surely isn‚Äôt comprehensive, but here‚Äôs where I‚Äôd start:

1)¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†Let‚Äôs dramatically expand funding for the highly successful Low Income Housing Tax Credit program to help incentivize a massive increase in need-based affordable housing construction, preservation and maintenance. This has been the most proven solution to deliver housing for low-income families, as the math just doesn‚Äôt work (costs for land, labor, materials, regulatory fees, etc.) without LIHTC.

2)¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†Let‚Äôs establish a Middle Income Housing Tax Credit program to incentivize housing construction and housing maintenance for the middle class ‚Äì who do not qualify for LIHTC units but also cannot typically afford rent for newly built housing.

3)¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†Let‚Äôs dramatically expand funding for housing vouchers to address long waiting lists across the country, and also reform the voucher program to encourage wider adoption. In Los Angeles, as one example, the city re-opened its waiting list recently for the first time in 5 years ‚Äì and was expecting 365,000 applicants for just 30,000 spots.

4)¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†Create incentives for cities and states that remove barriers to new housing construction ‚Äì such as reforming zoning (legalizing more apartments), pre-empting rent control (proven time and again to simply limit supply, benefitting only a few with untargeted benefits at the expense of the majority), removing red tape that adds both cost and time to new housing construction, and reforming building codes to legalize more efficient construction including modular and pre-fab housing.

5)¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†Let‚Äôs codify renter protections that protect renters yet encourages housing providers to maintain properties and build more supply. Protections should include rental assistance and support for those unable to pay rent, such as funded eviction diversion programs. Protections should also address fraud among both landlords and tenants, both of which ultimately limit the volume of quality available housing supply, and compliance with Fair Housing laws designed to protect renters. And programs allowing renters to build credit by paying rent.

What did I miss?

#housing #affordablehousing #rent #multifamily #sfr

TITLE: The rent slowdown continues ... While we typically see a small pop in rents after the calendar turns each year (and saw a sizable bump in January 2022), there was no pop in January 2023.
TEXT:
The rent slowdown continues ... While we typically see a small pop in rents after the calendar turns each year (and saw a sizable bump in January 2022), there was no pop in January 2023.

U.S. apartment rents held flat from December to January -- which was a mild surprise. After four consecutive month-over-month rent cuts to close out 2022, we expected that pattern to continue (even if more modestly) in January.

Still, for the more-watched year-over-year rent change, there's a big impact from replacing Jan 2022's big bump with Jan 2023's goose egg. Year-over-year asking rent growth for new leases measured 15.1% this time one year ago... and now it's at 4.99%. First time below 5% since May 2021.

Why are rents cooling off so fast? Well, it's simple supply (more of it now) and demand (less of it now). After the big demand freeze (for ALL housing types-- not just apartments) in the second half of 2022, apartment occupancy dropped to 94.8% as of January 2023. That's the lowest rate since February 2018, and it'll likely dip lower by year end. Even if demand meaningfully improves (and there are signs that IS happening), it's unlikely demand can keep pace with the 40-year high in new apartment supply scheduled to complete this year.

Of course, this doesn't mean the sky is falling. The long-term tailwinds for multifamily (and rental housing more broadly) are still very much intact. The discount to rent versus buy (entry costs for a new renter versus buyer) is higher than ever. Demographics remain favorable, and unemployment is at 50-year lows. And after big job growth last year coupled with very little housing demand, there's certainly pent-up demand out there that will be unleashed as people feel better about the economy and their place in it.

But that being said: 2023 could be a tough year, especially for Class A apartments in or near downtown neighborhoods (all across the country) competing with this big wave of new lease-ups.

And lastly: There's a persistent myth that the slowdown is concentrated in the Sun Belt. That wasn't true before, and it's still not true now. Other than weakness in the Desert region (Vegas, Phoenix, Reno), there isn't a consistent regional story playing out. In January (month-over-month), the deepest cuts came in a hodgepodge of markets: Detroit, Anaheim, San Francisco, Phoenix and Jacksonville.

#apartments #multifamily #rentalhousing

TITLE: Like many people, I love the idea of converting under-utilized office buildings into apartments. But there's a problem: Financial math doesn't like the idea as much as people do. Office-to-apartment conversions -- while wonderful -- are 10,000x more buzz than reality. Per CBRE, there will be a total of just 34 such projects nationally in 2023. Just 34. That likely amounts to <1% of all apartment units currently under way.
TEXT:
Like many people, I love the idea of converting under-utilized office buildings into apartments. But there's a problem: Financial math doesn't like the idea as much as people do. Office-to-apartment conversions -- while wonderful -- are 10,000x more buzz than reality. Per CBRE, there will be a total of just 34 such projects nationally in 2023. Just 34. That likely amounts to <1% of all apartment units currently under way.

Here's why office-to-apartment conversions are so challenging despite our love affair with them:

1) Building floorplates. Office buildings are much deeper than residential buildings. That means many buildings won't work at all, and those that do will require long, rectangular floorplans that would likely need to include window-less bedrooms. That's OK for affordability, but some cities won't even let you call a room a bedroom without a window.

2) Plumbing and mechanics. Office buildings have 1-2 bathrooms per floor. Residential buildings would need bathrooms in every unit, which requires re-plumbing the entire building -- meaning significant work through drilling through concrete flooring. Office buildings also typically have more elevators and different HVAC requirements (every unit needs individual HVAC), which means re-working building layout too.

3) Cost. Conversions are expensive. In many cases, developers will tell you it's easier/cheaper just to demolish the office building and start over from scratch. That would assume you're buying the building for essentially the cost of the land, which -- even in today's weak office market, is a big stretch. To make conversions work, developers need to score a deal on an office building way below market price. Additionally, the building must be empty in most cases -- meaning you can't assume any income during the conversion. (Also, higher building costs = higher rent.)

Of course, office-to-apartment conversions can happen -- and thankfully some do. They often work because of generous public subsidies (i.e. historic preservation tax credits or opportunity zones) and city incentives. If you think about the best office-to-apartment conversions, you'll likely be thinking about very historic, regal office buildings that had reached functional obsolescence, and the city then worked with a developer to subsidize the conversion. The good news is that there are serious efforts both at the local and the federal levels to incentivize more office-to-apartment conversions. Other regulatory clean-up work is needed around zoning and building codes.

When they do happen, office-to-apartment conversions can be super cool and beautiful projects. Count me as a fan.

But also count me skeptical with the increasingly popular idea that office-to-apartment conversions can be more than a drop-in-the-bucket plan to create supply and aid affordability.

#multifamily #CRE #housing #affordablehousing #apartments

TITLE: The late CEO of Zappos, Tony Hsieh, used to offer new hires $2,000 on the spot to leave the company.
TEXT:
The late CEO of Zappos, Tony Hsieh, used to offer new hires $2,000 on the spot to leave the company.
¬†
Highly unusual but helped weed out people that weren't a fit.
¬†
He would also fly candidates to their HQ for final round interviews.
¬†
Pick them up from the airport, give them a tour, then they spent the day interviewing.
¬†
After the interviews, the recruiter circled back w/ the shuttle driver to ask how they were treated.
¬†
If the driver wasn‚Äôt treated well, they don‚Äôt hire that person.
¬†
Even if they crushed their interviews.
¬†
Even if they had all the right skills & qualifications.
¬†
He believed that a candidate's behavior and attitude towards others, especially those in lower positions, was a reflection of their overall character and how they would interact with customers and colleagues.
¬†
He was right.
¬†
Zappos became well-known for its exceptional customer service and employee satisfaction
¬†
Takeaways?
¬†
- Small actions and interactions can have a big impact.
¬†
- Treat every touchpoint you have with a company as part of the interview process.
¬†
- Having the right skills and experience are important, but kindness, empathy, and respect also matter (more IMO).
¬†
#jobsearch #jobinterviews #careers

TITLE: Everyone talks about increasing your salary but I had a client take a paycut for their new job.
TEXT:
Everyone talks about increasing your salary but I had a client take a paycut for their new job.

In return, they got:

- a better manager
- a better team
- a better quality of life
- more useful skills
- more growth opportunities in a new industry

Sometimes it's the 'non-financial' factors that can offer the biggest rewards.

Oh, and after a year they made back their old salary and then some.

One step back. Two steps forward.

#jobsearch #jobinterviews #careers

TITLE: If there‚Äôs a chance you could be laid off (pretty much anyone),
TEXT:
If there‚Äôs a chance you could be laid off (pretty much anyone), 

Make sure to document all your wins:

- results
- other key metrics
- rankings you achieved
- awards & accolades
- client successes 
- praise from your manager or other leaders

It‚Äôll help with your resume, interviews, and overall narrative. 

A lot. 

I recently worked with someone who had trouble updating their resume with numbers from their last job.

Unfortunately they (along with their entire department) were laid off and locked out of the company system & email immediately.

If you haven‚Äôt done this yet, start collecting that info now. 

And regardless of whether you think you‚Äôll be laid off, it‚Äôs a good idea to do this exercise at least 1x quarter.

You got this.

#jobsearch #jobinterviews #layoffs

TITLE: As a hiring manager, I can tell when someone isn't confident.
TEXT:
As a hiring manager, I can tell when someone isn't confident.

It often sets the tone of the interview.

Here are 6 science-backed ways to be more confident in your next interview:

1/ Don't be like other candidates who just skim the website and call it a day. Dig deep, research the company's history, products, and values. The more you know, the more confident you'll feel.


2/ Nonverbal cues are your secret weapon. Nod your head, lean in to show you're engaged, look the interviewer in the eye, smile, etc. 

(Research shows only 7% of our message is conveyed through words, while 55% comes from body language and 38% from tone of voice)


3/ Don't expect your skills and experience to be enough. Using the STAR (Situation, Task, Action, Result) method can help you structure your responses and provide specific examples to stand out from the crowd. 


4/ Use positive affirmations to pump yourself up before the interview. Tell yourself you're confident, capable, and ready to crush it. Positive self-talk is proven to work. 


5/ Good communication is a two-way street. Don't just focus on what you're going to say. Listen carefully to the interviewer's questions, and show you're engaged by nodding, asking follow-up questions, and making thoughtful responses.


6/ Practice...always. Don't just wing it on the day of the interview. Rehearse your answers to common questions, and role-play with a friend or family member. You'll be more prepared and relaxed.


You got this. 

üí™

#jobsearch #jobinterviews #careers

TITLE: Feeling triggered today.
TEXT:
Feeling triggered today.

Just talked to someone who got fired after 4 weeks.

3 weeks in they were put on a PIP (Performance Improvement Plan).

1 week later they were let go.

Was it a layoff disguised as a performance issue or something else?

She was a talented individual so it didn't make sense.

I dug in to see what happened.

They received 1-day of training (if you can call it that).

Expectations weren't clear from the beginning.

And it sounds like there wasn't much interest in coaching her to success.

Red flag city. 

I also found it ironic that the manager who let her go has a LinkedIn profile littered with language like "leader" "people builder" "inspiring greatness" and my favorite..."be the light for others."

The reality is:

- bad leaders are everywhere
- toxic work environments are everywhere
- people telling you one thing but then doing another are everywhere 

For anyone considering a new job, it's so important to:

- fully understand the training & onboarding process up front 
- do due diligence by talking to current & former employees before accepting any job
- ask the 'hard' questions to hiring managers during the interview process (more on this in the comments)

I wish no one has to go through this kind of experience. 

#jobsearch #careers #jobinterviews

TITLE: Been seeing this on more job postings over the years.
TEXT:
Been seeing this on more job postings over the years.

And I'm here for it.

Because I've seen how our self-confidence can betray us.

Letting a potentially great opportunity slip by.

If I waited until I had 100% of the qualifications for a job, I wouldn't have landed my dream job at LinkedIn and broken into the Tech industry. 

#jobsearch #jobinterviews #careers

TITLE: Harsh Reality: the person you work for can 'make or break' your career.
TEXT:
Harsh Reality: the person you work for can 'make or break' your career.

3 questions you can use to identify a good or bad boss in your next interview:

1) "Of all the people who‚Äôve worked for you, how many have been promoted and how did you help them get there?"

This can reveal a lot about how they develop and support their people.

The best managers will have specific examples of how they did this.


2) "Can you share a time when an employee gave feedback on something that can be improved or changed?"

This can reveal how they accept and implement feedback (or not).

The best managers make people feel heard, understood, and respected when accepting feedback.


3) "What leadership development opportunities exist here?"

This isn't just for you, but it reveals how the company is investing in its leaders.

You'll likely have multiple managers at your company so this is important to know.

--

You're not just choosing a job, you're also choosing a boss.

Choose wisely.

#jobsearch #careers #leadership

TITLE: People chase after jobs at companies Google, Amazon, Meta.
TEXT:
People chase after jobs at companies Google, Amazon, Meta.
 
But should chase after:
 
-> taking vacation/PTO without feeling guilty 
-> environment of trust vs. micromanaging
-> managers that support you
-> opportunities to grow
-> learning new skills
 
Maybe those big name companies offer these. Maybe not.

(Not to mention those companies are laying off thousands right now)
 
Make sure you look past 'the brand' to focus on what matters to you.
 
You'll be a lot happier you did.

--

ps - if you've been impacted by layoffs from these companies (or maybe you want to hire these people) I have something for you in the comments üëáÔ∏è

TITLE: 10 pieces of life advice I wish I knew earlier in my career:
TEXT:
10 pieces of life advice I wish I knew earlier in my career:
¬†
1/ the best work ethic requires a good rest ethic

2/ about 99% of the time the right time is right now

3/ ask anyone you admire: their lucky breaks happened on a detour from their main goal
¬†
4/ nothing beats small things done every day
¬†
5/ don‚Äôt keep making the same mistakes; try to make new mistakes
¬†
6/ don't bother fighting the old; just build the new
¬†
7/ speak confidently as if you are right but listen carefully as if you are wrong
¬†
8/ no one is as impressed with your possessions as you are
¬†
9/ the biggest lie we tell ourselves is ‚ÄúI don't need to write this down because I will remember it‚Äù
¬†
10/ you can be whatever you want so be the person who ends meetings early

I don't know about you,

But I'm definitely going to start doing more of #10 this week. 

--

Credit: Kevin Kelly

#mondaymotivaton #careers #lifeadvice

TITLE: 5,184 people.
TEXT:
5,184 people.

That's how many people from our layoff list landed a new role.

With thousands more in interviews. 

My team spent the last month collecting this data.

Not a small number.

But pales in comparison to the tens of thousands that lost their jobs.

We can do better and will.

Our list still has at least 6,000 people actively looking for work (and growing each week).

Talent all across the board - engineering, product, design, sales, marketing, ops, HR, recruiting, and more. 

So today we're officially relaunching our layoff list and rebranding it to just "The List."

Candidates will be added weekly. But we'll also be filtering out everyone who lands a job so companies can focus on those actively looking.

We could use your help spreading the word (again).

Feel free to like and share this with your network if you think it could be helpful to anyone. 

We got this.

üí™

TITLE: Will AI take our jobs?
TEXT:
Will AI take our jobs?

I get asked this question a lot. Especially, from recruiters who see our new AI powered features we launch on Cutshort.

My answer - AI will actually make your job MORE valuable. How?

Take chatGPT for example. With it, now every recruiter can make a good JD, draft a decent email, send good rejection letters etc. However:

1.  Are these AI generated things saying the things you really want to say?

2. After all the great AI work, when you actually come face to face with candidates, are you able to plugs the trust/information gaps left by AI and build trustworthy relationships with the candidates?

In short, configuring AI to say right things the right way and establishing a human relationship after AI has done its work are two new skills that will make your job more valuable. 

It's not AI that will take our jobs. It will be our inability to upshift.

#ai #chatgpt #recruitment

TITLE: Had an interesting Twitter space discussion on layoffs yesterday.
TEXT:
Had an interesting Twitter space discussion on layoffs yesterday.

As someone who was laid-off once, here are my tips:

üëâ Do NOT rush to get hired asap. Think about your interests and strengths and pick the right roles. Getting into a wrong company/job again will make things much worse.

üëâ Don the consultant hat, if possible. Talk to your friends/connects and start adding whatever value you can. It's okay to do it for free. What's more important is to psychologically have work again. (Don't forget to update your LinkedIn profile and resume with a title such as "Independent Consultant - XYZ". )

üëâ Don't question your worth. You are NOT your job. Explore your interests and spend time with people you care about. Layoff is not a stigma - it's just an event that might give you more than you have lost. 

Anyone wants to add any other tips?

#layoffs #jobs #careers

TEXT:

Bootstrapping to profitability and then $1M revenue, going from 5 customers to welcoming 1000, we have crossed many business milestones in the last 7 years. 

But what achievement is defining and dear to me? It's building a honest team that loves to learn, perform and boost each other every day.

Yo Cutshort team: This year was a roller coaster ride. You have worked smart, hard and long. You have won some and lost some. But heck, the time we had was well worth every minute. Let's enjoy some time off and create magic again in 2023. ü•Ç

TITLE: Simple and sensible advice. Thanks Anil Peter Monteiro!
TEXT: Simple and sensible advice. Thanks Anil Peter Monteiro!

TITLE: I know this is a bit deep but then today is Monday, so let it be :)
TEXT:
I know this is a bit deep but then today is Monday, so let it be :)

Who do you want to be?  ü§î

All of us have this in our mind, right? A unicorn founder, someone with $10M in bank account, the best sales person, the go-to industry leader on marketing, etc etc.

But did you notice that this focus on "what we want to be" often takes us away from "what we love doing". 

For e.g. to be become a "very rich and powerful person", we might stop doing things we love such as teaching school kids or learning from others. On the flip side, we might start doing things that we don't love - such as attending networking parties and projecting a successful image outside.

Focussing on "what we want to do" vs "who we want to be" can be a happier and more successful path.

Inspiration: "Ego is the Enemy" - a book by Ryan Holiday

#learning
